author: Happy In Hilo
title: Transformational!
content: I LOVE my new pair of Bose QuietComfort 35 II Wireless Bluetooth Headphones!  I purchased these in the Rose Gold color and appreciate that Bose offers a color apart from the usual black and silver.  I'm not up on all the features and intricacies of this technology, but what I can share is that there is a significant difference in what you're able to hear/not hear as soon as you put them on.  I put them on while the volume on my tv was in the 20-25 range and although the noise cancelling feature was on high, I was still able to clearly hear the speaking coming from the tv, just at a much lower volume--comparable to hearing a quiet conversation in the background and just enough to eliminate it as a distraction.  Once I started to play music, the sound from the tv was totally eliminated and I heard sounds, tones and acoustics I had never heard before--the clarity of the music and melody was much more apparent.  As I mentioned, transformational!  I can't wait to try them out on a long flight!

author: Extract0r
title: Very comfortable but sound quality is mediocre at best
content:
My silver QC35 II arrived with a deep crease in the right ear cushion.  You can say it is a minor cosmetic issue, but it is annoying on a brand new product.  Anyway, here is my brief review of this product.

1.  These headphones are very comfortable to wear, but when the noise callenation is turned on, I feel a weird pressure sensation and minor pain in my ears.
2.  The iOS app is minimalistic and there is no EQ adjustment option.
3.  The volume is way too low.  I have to crank it up to 85-90% to achieve what decent earphones put out at 60%.  (Btw, I have a very good hearing and never use excessive volume when listening to music.)
4.  The system voice has a horrendously funny accent.  Everytime it connects to my iPad, it makes me giggle.
5.  The biggest problem is the poor audio quality.  Everything just sounds very flat and unremarkable.  High and mid range sound very dull and muted and bass is just average.  Shockingly, the sound quality of these $300 headphones is comparable to the $10 Apple earphones that came with my iPhone.
6.  Multi pairing is very convenient when swapping between an iPhone and an iPad.  You don’t have to disconnect and reconnect the bluetooth connection, but sometimes it gets confused and wouldn’t play from the correct source device.
7.  Nice clicky physical buttons for controls.
8.  Bose should have killed the Micro USB.  Micro USB is DEAD.

Here is my score for Bose QC35 II and Sony 1000XM3.  I have owned both and this is my subjective opinion.
Bose QC35 II (9.5/9.5/10/5/8)
Sony 1000XM3 (8.5/8.5/9/9.5/8)
(Design/Build Qualify & Material/Comfort/Sound Quality/Features)

author: hockeyANDfootball
title: Bluetooth Connectivity is Awful
content:
Do NOT buy these. The headphones are an embarrassment at $300. I've used various $50 headphones that have 100 times the reliability of these Bose headphones when it comes to keeping a bluetooth connection. I initially bought both these and the Sony XM3s with the intention of comparing sound/fit/noise cancelling/etc. I haven't even tried out the XM3s yet (I'll update this after I do), but regardless, I will be returning the QC 35 II no matter what.

Here's how my hour of usage has gone. Opens box, connects headphones to phone in 30 seconds. Good start. Noise cancelling is great. Sound is good, but not too much better than some cheaper pairs of headphones I have. Then I proceed to walk 10 feet away from my phone and the connectivity starts to cut out. At 15 feet it disconnects completely. WTF is this? So I unpair headphones and restart everything. Maybe it was a fluke. Nope...the range on my pair of headphones is literally 10 feet. Pretty unbelievable.

I routinely use 3 other bluetooth devices with my phone and I've never experienced connectivity issues.

author: Nikoli Kolesnikov
title: Excellent noise cancellation, premium sound, exceptional comfort!
content:
As a college student I spend around 15-20 hours in my college's library writing papers, studying, or making video calls. At this particular campus the HVAC system is very loud, making it hard to concentrate on my work. After researching about Bose and their high reputation in noise cancellation, I knew that I had to try this product out.

Once I received this pair of headphones, I was immediately blown away at the noise cancellation performance, and reminded of how much my ears ring. 95% of the sound I was exposed to during my study sessions were now gone, making my sessions much more productive than before.

In terms of sound quality, I have heard from Sony users that their product is superior in sound quality compared to bose, with much deeper bass. If that is your main concern, I would consider researching that product to determine if that fits your needs. However, Bose has tremendous bass and the highs and lows hit just fine for my liking!

For gaming, I use these mainly to chat in discord with friends, but the "in game" sounds are very similar to a High-end pair of Astro headphones, if that means anything. Overall, I rate this product 5 stars, as I am still impressed with the performance in noise cancellation, audio quality, battery life, and durable build quality.

author: joe
title: First time going with Bose and wow!
content:
The noise cancellation is outstanding! I can have 3 large fans set to high and these will completely cancel them out. I can't wait to try these on an airplane! The sound quality is the best I've experienced so far in my life. My "top of the line" gaming headset is a bit of a let down compared to these. I bought a Bluetooth dongle just so I could use these with my computer, yeah I my MB doesn't have BT.

They breath well and don't make your head/ears hot or sweaty. I think I have larger ears but these fit just fine. I do have to adjust about every hour or so because they press on my Tragus but that's it. They are nice and light weight.

I am still looking but haven't found anything better than these. I do recommend them!

author: erd
title: Excellent headphones
content: I LOVE these headphones. I’ve had them for a year and 8 months and they’re still working great. I got them to help concentrate in a loud, open floor plan office and they do cancel out a lot of noise. Now I wear them while walking my dog and I really don’t hear anything around me. They connect easily, I wish they didn’t connect to multiple devices at once because that only makes things more complicated- you can only really be connected to one at a time or another device might interfere. I’ve also had a few instances where the headphones have worked improperly and started picking up ambient noise from my surroundings, or the audio gets fuzzy, but that is not a common occurrence. But other than that, they’re very sturdy and durable and worth the money.

author: C. Fraley
title: Great noise cancelling, comfortable fit
content:
I was thrilled at how comfortable and light-weight these headphones are!  I purchased them primarily for air travel, as the drone of the engines really irritates me.  I was expecting some neck stiffness due to wearing these for six hours, but they are so comfortable I've had no problems at all.

I also had the opportunity to wear these at night (in a dorm for a conference, and construction started outside before 6am!).  Again, I was amazed I could sleep with these on, and still get a good night's sleep, even laying on my side.

The sound reproduction is very good--nothing like studio headphones (Sennheiser HD 650s or the like), but certainly way better than any ear buds.  There are now more choices out there than when I bought mine (others have temporarily taken the noise cancelling crown, or sound a little better), but these are still worth serious consideration due to comfort (and the noise cancellation and sound aren't bad either!).

author: Jackson Roykirk
title: Excellent product
content: Really like these headphones.  Bought them for travel on airplanes.  Noise reduction freak'n excellent.  All the noise is cut out but yet I can hear the announcements.  Use them to watch TV also.  The only down side to these things is for Apple products, you can only have two devices enabled to be connected to them.  So if I want to use my iPad, iPhone, and Apple TV, one of these I have to disable and then when traveling switch to the devices I have with me; this (feature) is active no matter what device you are using to connect to the headphones.  So for the iPhone and the iPad, you need a Bose app to configure the headphones.  The app is the same for each device.  Each app will only allow you to connect to two devices and they are the same for each device if this makes sense.  This must be a limitation of the headphones and I can't figure out why there would be such a limitation.

author: Donald S.
title: The best!!!
content: Bought these pending an international vacation and knowing I'd be on an airplane for hours.  Took them with me, listened to an entire book and was worried they'd go dead part way through.  No way, they were still 70% charged.  I listened to the book, watched 2 movies and a tone of music and I never recharged them.  They just kept on working.  They're so quiet to outside noise.  Love them, can't recommend them enough and if you travel or are around others where the noise is bothersome, they're the only way to go.  Well worth the money and they're quality in their design, materials and comfort!!!

author: Keith Goreham
title: Wonderful Hardware Let Down By Poor Software
content:
This review would be 5 stars if not for one very bad flaw in these headphones. The moment you make a call, the noise canceling turns off and you (and whoever you're calling) will hear everything around you – amplified – while you're on the phone. It's so bad that I have to use my old QC25 wired headphones for calls (which work perfectly for this), and only use the QC35-S2's for wireless listening to music/podcasts/tv while doing other things. This is beyond ridiculous for headphones of this price.

As for their performance purely as listening devices, the noise canceling is slightly (but only slightly) better than the wired QC25's, but the tonal range is slightly worse in the base tones. Their ability to connect to multiple devices is great, but suffers from a tendency for them to want to connect to multiple devices AT ONCE (iphone + something else, for instance), which about half the time causes no audio to be played through them at all, even though the source is muted when they're selected. You then have to remove them from each device you've paired them to, and start over to get sound back.

author: DaveH
title: Garbled when used with Sony AV amplifiers
content: I use a Sony 1080 AV amp. After initial bluetooth pairing, the Bose were almost unintelligible. After going thru the logical troubleshooting, like checking sound quality with other devices (which sounded fine), I began looking for posts on the Sony specific problem. Lo and behold, on the Bose community site, others have posted the same issue of sound quality with Sony amps. Bose response to the issue is "must be a Sony issue, call them". But my older Bose  AE2W bluetooth headphones work perfectly with the Sony amp. Don't you just love it when something doesn't work and companies point fingers at each other? So in the end, these Bose are going back, and ordering some M3s.

author: Austin
title: Against the Sony MX1000 its a very close race - But QC35 comfort has no equal
content:
Having tested the Song MX1000x for a long while in Bestbuy and these at the next booth over, it was clear in that moment which I liked better - but i cant help but wonder if the MX1000x had just focused more on comfort what this review would look like instead.

Bose is all about comfort, as the name suggests it is built around the policy of supreme comfort, a factor that the MX1000x can't even come close too. Within 30 seconds of wearing the sonys in bestbuy, my ears began to burn and felt the nauseating sensation of a headache growing... and that was only after 30 seconds of listening. Bose on the other hand, even in those few seconds of testing at BestBuy - I could barely tell that I had a pair of headphones on my head.

So Bose wins comfort, and i think everyone can agree on this... but that's really about it. Sony has far better noise canceling, you should have seen my face when I pressed the calibration button in BestBuy (and as loud and busy at it was, and i didn't even have music playing) it was dead silent. And dead silent in a way, where even my own excited squeals of laughter were invisible. It was truly like being deaf, unable to hear a thing and nothing was even playing yet. Upon turning on the tunes though, aside form the neddle-like precision of notes, I felt something was missing from them. It was a strange feeling, and I think its the fact that the MX1000x are so good at separating sounds from one another, that music sounds sort of hollow when you really listen to something. It can turn a symphony into a bland practice session, because it's so good at separating notes.

QC35 on the other hand, left something to be desired on the noise canceling ability. The loud roar and chatter of bestbuy, became a dull to silent roar, with most sounds around me muffled out. With all music and sounds turned off I would rate the BOSE as more a "Sound Dampening" headphone, than a true noise cancelling headphone (at least when compared to the technology of Sony). Still when turning on the music the sound felt full. My face was shocked at the clarity of the notes produced by these headphones. music had feeling with these on, tension, emotion - something I felt the precision of the Sony's sort of took away. The music sounded more like a symphony, than a audiophile picking apart every single note and separating them so you could hear it individually (as the sony's did). This lead me to hear that the BOSE produced better sound to my ears with the test tracks provided. However using truely uncompressed audio, you will be able to hear much more notes and instruments with the MX1000x.

Reviewers constantly raved about how the Bass on the MX1000x was much better than the QC35, but to be completely honest I don't really hear that at all. I've ramped up my QC35 against a friends MX1000, and I prefer the Bass tones of my Bose over his, every time (even with uncompressed audio). Even the sound quality of the Bose I sort of prefer, even with the clarity that Sony produces.

In the end Bose wins in comfort hands down, there is absolutely no equal in this regard and really the QC35's shining quality. As far as bass and music quality go... its really a toss up on what you prefer. Sony hands down has the best noise cancelling possible, but are extremely uncomfortable and will give you a headache from how close they placed the speakers to your ears so they get squished!

If i were placed in the same position again of buying either, I don't think there's any change I would have changed my purchase. However if the MX1000x had been as comfortable, I would own a pair of sony's instead.

author: DTodd
title: Bose hits it out of the Park with these!
content:
I was in the market for a new set of premium headphones and I agonized for days over whether I should choose the QC35s, the Sony WH1000XM2s and the Sennheiser P550s. They all had their strong points.  I finally broke the logjam by selecting according to what I wanted in a set, versus cool but unnecessary features that I would probably seldom use or need.  And as you can probably guess, I ended up selecting the Bose QC35s.

I recieved my QC35s within 48 hours or ordering from Amazon.  Upon opening the package I was both pleased and underwhelmed with a few features.  Let's talk about something good first.  The semi-hard case really rocks.  -Well-built and padded to keep the QCs relatively safe.  However, the provided USB charging cable was ridiculously short. Without measuring, I guess-timate the cord to be a out 8 to 10 inches.  The included headphone cable was less short but still a bit underwhelming in length.  Bose is a premium company, and for the price of entry to purchase these headphones, there is no reason why they could not include cables that are at least a serviceable length. Without checking, but having owned many Sony and Sennheiser headphones over the course of my lifetime, I'm willing to bet they would not make such a remedial mistake.

Fortunately, the QC35s made up for the cable issue with outstanding sound characteristics and excellent noise-cancelling capabilities.  The sound stage of these headphones is expansive.  I can hear separation between instruments that sounded muddled and undefined in my previously award-winning Plantronics. In fact, I would say that you probably would be hard-pressed to make a pair of headphones that were siginificantly better using a Bluetooth connection.  And that's just because you get to a point in sound quality that is really only limited by the Bluetooth standard.
As for the claims that I've seen in other reviews that these don't have any bass response, I will tell you that anyone that thinks these headphones don't have bass needs to immediately get their hearing checked. And anyone who needs more bass than these are capable of producing are probably causing themselves some real hearing damage.
In terms of sound quality, will these compete with my wired Sennheiser HD 380 pros?  No way.  Not even close.  In fact, any Bluetooth headphones I've ever tried, no matter how much money you throw at them will get stomped by a decent set of wired headphones. And that's just the reality of Bluetooth, until a new technology takes its place.

BUT what you're getting here is an excellent portable set of headphones that sound pretty sweet and have excellent noise reduction.  I ride the Washington DC Metro (subway) to work every day, and once I set the ANC and turn on the music, I never hear another sound other than the music.  They're also reasonably comfortable and actually fit my big ears and head very well too. Bose claims 20 hours of use from a single full charge and I am inclined to believe that figure.  I can charge them on Monday, and by week's end, I have ridden the train a combined 15 hours, and have plenty of juice left. If you've owned a decent set of Bluetooth headphones before, these probably won't blow you away, but they certainly won't disappoint either. Bose gets it right here, and I'd wholeheartedly recommend these to anyone looking for premium set of headphones.

author: MAVRIK
title: Bose knows Noise canceling!
content: I was going to get a much cheaper headphone but I see Bose headphones used by a lot of travelers.  I did a little research on them and they were a bit too much but I figured I would get them at the $299 price.  I also saw that the SONY ones that are much like these were also on sale at $299.  Anyway, i ordered them and I got them Monday afternoon as promised.  Everything was in tact and no damage to the box or the headphones.  I opened them up and charged them up while I got ready for work.  I took them with me along with my iTouch.  I took my phone and downloaded the Bose+ app to my phone and went through the process of setting up and pairing it to my Galaxy 7.  It did not take long and it also had to download some firmware which did take a few minutes for it to download and then install to the headphones.  Once completed I walked through the features and it added Google assistant so I can use one of the buttons to initiate and ask Goggle assistant questions or have it do something.  They are very comfortable on my head and on my ears.  They don't cause any discomfort or stress out my ears after wearing them for a long period of time.  Just have to get use to the location of the buttons.  The Noise canceling is pretty good and you can turn it off if you like and save on battery.  I have yet to see how long the charge lasts in prolonged use.  Overall on my first use and test of it I really like them and glad I ordered them.  Well worth the money in my opinion.  Will give a more detailed update on them after I have had some time to test them out and see how they perform.

author: Boba Fret
title: Light, comfortable, and sound great
content: I've owned a LOT of headphones and try out headphones fairly often. I love AKG headphones for the sound quality but after a while they can physically start to wear on my ears. These are super comfortable and sound great. The noise cancelling is really nice. I tried the competing Sony pair and they just aren't comfortable at all for me.

author: O. B. Juan
title: Pairs With Cisco Model 9951 Office Phone
content: FYI, I did not purchase these Bose headsets but received them as an award at work.  My desk is in the middle of a call center, but I'm not a call center rep.  Therefore, my day is filled with the constant chatter of other people's phone calls.  I do lots of math so to minimize the distractions I paired my Bose QC 35 II headphones with my Cisco Model 9951 office phone.  I pretty much wear them all day, and when I do get/make a phone call they work great.  That said, I use my Sony WH-1000MX3 headphones at home to listen to music, the TV, Audible, etc.  I prefer the noise cancellation and sound quality of the Sony's a bit more than the Bose.  I give the Bose 4 stars when compared to the Sony's which I give 5 stars, but the Bose are great headphones!

author: Jason B.

content:

But they're deff worth the price I paid for them.  When I first got them I had to download the bose connect app.  After the initial download, it updated firmware- I'm guessing to get the Alexa feature on the app.  I've had them for 4 or so days now.  I was just about to leave a bad review until I finally realized what I was doing wrong.  Turns out the action button is on the left side.  So this whole time I thought Alexa wasn't working and it was just google assistant.  So remember the action button for alexa etc is on the left ear, folks.  Now.... I won't leave the house with these headphones... too expensive.  Neighbor was getting upset that my music was too loud one night.  So I needed a solution.  These bose headphones was it.  So here I am typing this while wearing the bose headphones with noise cancellation on.  I can't hear my fingers type/click on my keyboard.  I feel like i'm in an airbubble with nothing but music.  It's futuristic af.  I wan't to say they could be a little louder, but being in bands all my life around music pretty much shot my hearing anyways, so they're just fine.  They're comfortable af.  Ears don't hurt. Just what I wanted, over the ear.  I swear to God i was just about to write a bad review about the alexa feature not working after spending days without itworking, come to find out there's a dang button on the left! I really do feel like I'm sucked in a box with nothing but music playing.  Can't hear nothing from the outside. You got 30 days and Amazon is good for it.  i love amazon so much.  Merry Christmas, folks!

UPDATE: BEST HEADPHONES EVER!  BEST THING I'VE EVER BOUGHT ON AMAZON IN THE PAST 2 YEARS! USE THEM EVERY DAY WHEN I GET OFF WORK.  NEIGHBORS ARE HAPPY!  SO GOOD! BUY THEM! 7/14/19

author: skyforce95
title: Video Unboxing and Review!!!
content: Watch its unboxing and review video in HD on my Youtube channel: skyforce95

author: Trevor
title: Glad I finally made the purchase!
content:
I work in a noisy office environment and went back and forth as to whether these would help and were worth the money. I also had to decide between the latest Sony and Bose models.
I finally made the decision to spend the money and to give Noise Cancelling technology a try. Based on all the reviews on Amazon I decided the Bose was a better choice. So far I am extremely happy; the battery life is awesome, the sound quality excellent and the noise cancelling abilities have really surprised me. I wish now I had purchased earlier. My only complaint - the ridiculously short charging cable that comes in the box! Come on, these are $350 headphones!

author: Scott Lemon
title: Will not work right with Windows!
content: I love the headphones. They are very light weight. The big drawback is that they are not compatible with windows. To use them with a windows computer you have to use the stereo plug and it kind of defeats the purpose of wireless. I wanted to use them on a gaming computer but to no avail on the Bluetooth front. I wonder if they will work with windows phones (we will never know as no one owns a windows phone:) ). Bose needs to make their devices compatible with all OS's. not just the most popular mobile platforms.

author: lowjumpingfrog
title: Google Pixel 2 Users Beware
content:
The noise cancellation is fantastic. The sound is great as well. However, Bose does not deliver on all functionality. The multifunction button does not work to pause/play or skip track on current version of Android on Pixel 2 or Google Pixel Chromebook. Plus, don't bother using it to make a phone call. The call quality is poor and there is a constant echo of every word you speak on both Android and the iPhone.

Update: After restarting my Pixel 2, the multifunction button works for pause play for now but, using this this headset for for making phone calls on Android or the iPhone is unusable. Unless of course you are calling yourself. Everything you speak into the microphone is repeated back in the headphone about a 1/2 second later. That wouldn't be so bad if the echo was faint. The echo is louder than the voice of the person you are calling.

author: Dana
title: Really really bad
content:
If you're looking for a sign whether you should buy these or not - this is it! DO NOT PURCHASE THESE! It was unimaginably bad!!! I've had the QC 25's for several years and use them in my home office to block out my neighbor noises. These QC 35's are basically like having your loud neighbors shouting in your ears! No matter what I did the talking wouldn't stop. The moment I opened the box I was excited to use them and get some work done but unfortunately the voice kept telling me I HAD to download the app and would not stop repeating every 60 seconds until the app was installed. I called Bose support and their suggestion was to turn off the headphones then turn them back on....voice still there. Also what kind of a suggestion is that? I also brought up the fact that the Bose rep here on amazon said you didn't need the app to use it, so why would it not let me use the headphones without the app?  They say that is incorrect, you do NEED to install the app (clearly, unless you want the voice yelling at you to install it). Ok fine, i'll install another unnecessary app on my phone. After spending so long with bose support and installing the app, my battery was drained, so I  plugged my phone into charge, then sat down to get some work done. The talking started again! The voice said it could not register the connection to my phone. My phone was too far away. All I wanted was noise cancellation, I wasn't trying to play music or do literally anything, just sit there in silence with noise cancellation and type on my computer and it would not let me. After that I had enough, I reboxed the headphones and sent them right back. I was excited to go wireless but it's not worth it when the item is not easily usable. I don't want to have my phone on and next to me every time I want to use these headphones. I travel a lot. Am I expected to keep my phone on during a 15 hour flight?

IN SUM:  These headphones are ONLY usable with the app turned on and your phone nearby to pair with. You cannot just use noise cancellation with no active phone. Of course I would like to use my bluetooth on my phone occasionally, but not every time I use these. I'm joining the rest of the world and buying the new Sony headphones. Bose is no longer what they were.

author: iMinnesotan
title: High quality expected from Bose
content:
I love these headphones! I especially appreciate the ability to pair with multiple bluetooth devices and swap between them by simply bouncing the power switch. It announces each device that it connects to by name.

I got these headphone to replace my Beats Solo wireless model 2 headphones that are utter garbage for noise cancellation and are now my at-work headphones. I am able to use an old pair of wired Bose QC 2s to mow the lawn but the Beats were terrible at blocking ambient noise and could not be used for lawn mowing. I expect the QC 35s to perform like my wired QC 2s in that respect but won't know until summer.

These Bose headphones are also far more comfortable to wear than the Beats Solo wireless 2s. The last time that I flew I noticed that I could wear the Bose for the entire flight but had to take off the over-ear Beats after about an hour to give my ears a rest.

Sound quality is great, although I cannot offer any technical review. Any noise canceling headphone alters the sound somewhat.

author: matt hohertz
title: The "best" to Sony's "rest"
content:
I use these headphones primarily to listen to podcasts and Google Play music: in particular, I am not a musician, audiophile, or expert on acoustics, and I am at most an infrequent and casual gamer.

That said, I enthusiastically recommend these headphones over Sony's -- hands down, no contest, no questions asked.  Let me count the reasons:
* Idle timer that switches the headphones off to preserve battery (as opposed to running until the battery dies if you pause and forget to switch them off)
* Low battery warning (as opposed to just kind of turning off when the battery is out)
* Multiple-device compatibility, with one-button switching (as opposed to manually-disconnect-from-first-device-then-manually-connect-to-the-second switching)

Noise cancellation is good enough for my needs.  Assuming that the headphones are playing sound (at which point their noise cancellation will function optimally), they will dampen -- but not fully cancel -- loud ambient sounds (e.g., a screeching subway, loud PAs, traffic).  On the other hand, they do an excellent job of muting distracting noises, including nearby conversations, which makes them excellent supplements to a day of rigorous study.

author: ancient uchiha
title: Last only for 9 months
content: The Bose Qc35II works great when it works. However after using it for 9 months it starts to disconnect from your phone and resetting constantly. From what i heard it was because of a firmware update that killed the Bluetooth connection on my phone. If you do buy it do not update. At the moment I am thinking whether I should return it because it is still within my limited warrantly. Will update on the status on it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Notifications voice and beeps have piercing noise that cannot be lowered
content:
The headphones are comfortable and sound quality great.  But the voice notifications and beeps are deafening!!!  There is no way to turn them down.  I purchased this for noise cancellation and soft music.  When notifications come through, my reaction is to pull the headphones away from my ears because it is so piercing.  I have followed threads of others with the same complaint and Bose has provided no fix.  You can only turn off notifications, not lower volume.  For headphones of this price point, that is very disappointing.
If you are seeking noise cancellation headphones, look elsewhere until they have a fix for this.

author: VirtualWatts
title: Bose QuietComfort 35 Series II – Bose SoundLink II – Microsoft Surface, FAIL in an open office
content:
I was looking for a pair of headphones to help me with video/VOIP calls in a noisy office environment as an upgrade to my Jabra 370 – I tried Bose QuietComfort 35 Series II – Bose SoundLink II – Microsoft Surface and all three failed.

Bose QC35 best sound quality
Surface failed to work with iPhone X and iPad Pro
Soundlink isn’t noise cancelling
All three have microphones that amplify ALL VOICES IN THE ROOM – fail
Turns out the Jabra 370 really is the best for office communications, but not for taming noisy office.

Our company just moved to a new open office design. That means no walls, no offices, all open space with desks, work stations and huddle areas. I had an office until we moved and was going from speakerphone to headphones. We are a global company thus video conferencing and VOIP con calls are constant on Zoom, Skype, WebEx etc.

I already have a Bluetooth wireless headset Jabra 370, it is “on the ear” with a boom microphone, I thought an “around the ear” would help better with the new noisy office. The Jabra 370 uses a USB transmitter and is pretty much tied to desktops/laptops.

Now, about my special circumstances, I have a hearing disability and wear a hearing aid and Cochlear Implant. For this review what that means is that I hear from things that sit on my ear rather then inside my ear and because I already have the hearing aids cannot wear an ear bud arrangement. I am an IT professional.

This review is of all three subject headsets:
1) Noise Cancellation for Other Party – (FAIL) that is, when on a call what does the other side hear? And here all three failed, on calls the other parties could hear voices from all across the office because the microphone arrays would pick up every voice in the room. For the QC35 weirdly it was only when I was speaking – deathly silent when I wasn’t, but the moment I began to speak all the other voices in the room came through loud and clear, very distracting to the folks on other end of the call, at one point they could hear a conversation 35 feet away very clearly that I couldn't hear because of the headset

2) Noise Cancellation for Wearer– The Soundlink is not noise cancelling (I thought all Bose were) and therefore, it cannot work in a noisy open office environment, the Bose QC35 did the best job of noise cancellation, the Surface okay
But about noise cancellation – Bose is made for like a plane non-voice noisy environment, in an open office where the “noise” is other people talking on phones or in groups, the Bose actually makes the problem WORSE by amplifying surrounding voices

3) Call Quality – all three had good call quality on Win10 bluetooth, but the Surface had terrible quality for other party on the iPhone X and iPad, the other end and con calls could not hear me like I was in a tunnel

4) Pairing - All three headsets paired easily with my Win10 Lenovo corporate laptop, Win10 Surface Book 2 personal laptop, iPad Pro and iPhone X

5) No boom microphone – all three use a microphone array in the ear cup rather than boom microphone, my voice was clear on all three, but other side said QC35 was best sound
But note other voices are picked up as well

6) Surround the ear – all three styles are designed to fit around the ear entirely instead of on or in the ear, I was worried about discomfort based upon other reviews and the Surface has small ear cups, but all fit well over my (somewhat) oversized Obama type ears. The Bose were the most comfortable, in a warm office I can tell the Surface would have a sweat issue

7) Sound clarity – all three had very good voice sound clarity, but the Bose QC35 did so with less volume turned up, volume of 8 – 10 for others while volume of 5 on Bose QC35 to hear the same thing

8) Interoperability – all three operated fine on all manner of video, voip, UCaaS and web calls

9) Multi-device – in theory all three are supposed to connect to both phone and computer for dual inputs, I guess to hear music and then take a call or conversation, in reality that is horrible because my VOIP calls were constantly interrupted by the alerts and messages from my phone, the headset was constantly switching back and forth, and once, my iPhone randomly began playing music during a VOIP con call

10) Digital Aid/Cochlear – all three work fine with digital hearing and BTE hearing aids, and Advanced Bionics Cochlear implant

11) Sound Quality – my focus was on voice clarity not music, all three have excellent sound quality, The QC35 the best, then the Surface and then the Soundlink, the volume on the QC35 did not have to go as high to get the same results as the other two

author: JMP
title: Big improvement over QC15/must have for frequent flyer
content:
I had a pair of QC15 for years and they quit working after a lot of use and replaced them with these.

A big improvement over the 15's.  The bluetooth is very nice over having to use them corded (I wish airlines would start enabling bluetooth on their IFE's so you didn't have to break out the cord.  It's nice having the rechargable battery, I love the auto shutoff feature and noise control level they added.  They fold up nicely to fit in the case.  Sound quality if good.  I lost the cord one time on my 15's and it was expensive to replace and this cord looks like it's a simple audio cord like you would use to connect an external MP3 player to a car so should be very cheap and easy to replace if it's loss.

A couple small things I don't like is there no plastic business card/ID holder to place a business card or contact info in case the headphones get lost and there is no airline adapter (fortunately my QC15 had one and I am just going to use that and sometimes airlines will give you one).  Most airlines have the regular plugs but a lot of airlines use the two prongs in business and first class when they furnish the headphones (probably to deter people from stealing theirs) so you will need the adapter in these cases (I prefer these over the crappy airline ones).

I'd recomend these for anyone that flies once a month and does a lot of redeyes.  For the occassional short-haul day time flyer there are cheaper headphones that work great.

author: Digitally Enabled
title: Very Happy With My Choice 2019
content:
Read multiple reviews in my quest for wireless headphones.
Decided to put out the extra $ for the noise cancellation, around the ear headphones by Bose.
Very happy.
While I had not yet experienced noise cancellation, that Bose technology is simply outstanding.
Note, it does not cancel out all sound. It appears to focus on certain frequencies, such as road noise & air vents (the hi end freq). Pretty much anything that has a shhhhh or hissing sound....gone.
A jet flew over me on take-off (around 1,000 feet), and I could just barely hear it. Amazing.
As for me, the bass is deep, rich and smooth. Crisp and tight treble, with full rounded mids.
Wireless works flawlessly, and I can't say enough about the build and materials of the product. Well engineered!
Battery life is just as advertised. A coworker of mine uses these, not only for music, but also as a functional tool to eliminate undesired sound, such as jet engine noise while taking a flight, the road noise from public transportation, and to create near silence during sleep. This prompted me to Google "noise cancellation" to try an understand how it all works. Fascinating!

While it was at the top of my price point (actually well over it), I splurged on my personal audio enjoyment. The ear cups are super comfortable, almost like there is some sort of gel in them. I will agree with a few other reviews in regard to the inside of the ear cups getting a little warm with extended use. But not really a problem for me.
The battery does last longer if you connect the cord and drop the Bluetooth (for a direct connection) , plus it sounds a little better, although most people may not notice a difference. Conclusion: Full satisfaction from this user. The rich sound of this Bose is at stellar level. Enjoy.

author: Michele Wierman
title: CONSTANT CLICKING NOISE
content: Just received and tried my new quitecomfort 35 II headset and there is a loud and constant clicking noise when I try to listen to music.  Which I now have a headache.  I just noticed the back of the box states made for ipod, iphone & ipad.  I have an LG phone.  If this is the reason why I get the clicking noise, than maybe when purchasing an option should be given regarding if your phone is apple or android for no where on the product description does it state for Apple.  So disappointed.  Will definitely be returning.

author: Ricardo Epps
title: Noise cancellation is key, solid sound performance, and comfortable to wear!
content:
If you live in an apartment with noisy neighbors, the noise cancellation feature on this is a godsend. For example, over the last four months, when the gardener revs his lawn mower motor or the parents next door scream at their toddler-aged children, I've put these on and the noise is reduced by 80%.

The sound quality is 2x better than Apple EarPods. If you're looking for the absolute best sound on the planet, this is probably not it. That being said, it does produce a sound that can vaguely be described as robust with bass performing very well on a sound quality test and treble not far behind. So, unless you're a sound engineer or hardcore enthusiast, I think sound quality is as good as you would need.

The headset is comfortable to wear— even 4+ hours at a time. There is padding on the ear cup, which I find to be quite nice, and on the headset that rests on your head. While I personally wouldn't wear these during workout sessions, they seem perfect for home and travel use, and because they’re wireless, it’s easy to multitask.

author: IanM
title: Some initial issues but Amazon came through!
content:
The first set that I got had some dried hot glue or something on the ear cup.  I called Amazon and they transferred me to the Bose customer support.  As you would probably not expect with a "straight out the box" purchase they wanted me to send them to them let them do whatever then wait to get my headphones back.  Nope.  I bought these and I want to play with them.  Hung up, called Amazon back, told them what had happened, had a new pair the next day!

TLDR - Bose customer support is blah and Amazon is Yay!

The headphones themselves are fantastic.  Not too tight (and I have a big head) and the cups are very comfortable.  The sound is crisp as any headset I have ever owned.  I've never owned noise-cancelling headphones so I can only say that I really like the feature.

Recommended purchase.  I am buying my wife a pair.

author: Yash Parikh
title: Crisp & Clear Sound with Active Noise Cancellation  - Bose Way!
content:
I have had an eye on this headphones for almost 6 months since their launch and was waiting for the “Black Friday Discount” (that’s the only time Bose offers any discount on their products). Got it today and it’s absolutely gorgeous both in the look and feel. The “silver” is preferred color for these masterpiece.
As far as the sound is concerned, Bose knows the science behind the Acoustic Noise Cancellation (heard they have the best engineering team behind this invention) it totally separates and unwanted noise from your surroundings and gives you a clear and crisp sound.
It comes with three different Noise Cancellation modes/settings: High, Low, Off
You can choose/select/switch between these modes at a press of an action button situated on the left ear cup.
Right ear cup has three built in buttons, two for volume and one to pause or receive an incoming call.
The QC 2nd series comes with inbuilt Alexa and Google Assistance. So if you owe iPhone: you can actually have 3 services at your disposal: Alexa, Google Assistance, and of course Siri! You can use action button to switch between the selections. (have to download Bose app)
You’ll not go wrong with this choice. The closest to this is Sony WH1000. One time purchase and will last for years to come as it has Bose’s warranty and technical support.
I would highly recommended this product.

author: J. M. Doloboff
title: Wow, Wow and Wow - Bose Knows (how to make outstanding headphones)!!!
content:
I had a pair of Bose wired, noise cancelling headphones for several years, and they were my cans of choice when flying or otherwise in an environment with unimportant background noise.  With these wireless headphones, Bose hits the mark once again.  The music plays as it was recorded and mastered.  Isn't that what we all want?

Apparently not, given the success of Beats headphones, a marketing machine created by Jimmy Iovine and Dr. Dre.  Beats headphones enhance the bass, to the point where I feel that I am trapped in a car with a driver who has the treble level but the bass turned up to the max.  If you MUST have overly-compensated bass in everything that you listen to, then Beats are for you.

But if you want clear sound, together with a package that lets you easily choose the amount of exterior noise cancellation, then these Bose headphones are your best choice (at least with a price point less than a nice used car).  You also get simple volume controls and easily found buttons to skip forward or backward on your song list.

I have not yet tried Bose AR, so I cannot comment on that aspect of these outstanding headphones.  I expect great things from Bose.

So you won't be wearing the hot Beats headphones.  Even the NFL, which has a marketing deal with Bose, has trouble preventing the players from wearing Beats.  The Beats headphones are part of a well-planned marketing machine, and Bose just isn't as "cool."  But if you want to hear the music the way the musicians and engineers want you to hear it, forget about what the market views as "cool."  Go with Bose.

author: BatteryKing
title: All around really good
content:
I am updating after close to a year of use as things have changed with firmware updates to warrant adding the last star to make it 5/5.  Something up front I think I should say about noise cancelling as there does seem to be a bit of a debate over it, is it does not block out all sounds and it does not muffle sounds equally, but for practical purposes it does do a very good job at noise cancelling striking a good balance of things and being most effective where it is needed the most to make an enjoyable listening experience.  At least this is my experience using this on a daily basis in many different environments.  I have noticed on airplanes I need to fine tune how the headset rests on my head for best results, but once finding the proper adjustment it is almost like I am in an isolation room.  Fantastic.

Overall I am seeing this as well worth the money, a big step up over a much older generation of this product line I had been using, and definitely a huge step up over what came with my phone.  I bought this right after upgrading my phone, so in the past week have found some issues were not the head phone's fault, but instead default sound settings I have since adjusted.  Also been getting more adjusted to the noise cancellation, which is really a great feature of this headset.

For some things I really like about this headset:
1. I have a huge head and this fits nicely on it; even covers my large ears comfortably.  Almost no over the ear headphones do this and I have looked far and wide.  My head is just too big for pretty much all except this particular line of headphones / headsets.  In the ear headsets irritate my ears after a while, causing my ear canals to swell up.  So having something tolerable let alone comfortable to the point that I almost forget they are on is a huge plus.  They also fit on my wife's normal sized head just fine, so it covers a wide range of head sizes pretty well.

2. The sound quality and frequency range is great.  While I would like frequency sliders in their app, the hard coded balance across the range is pretty darn good.  Some reviews say there is a different headset that sounds better, but especially after this latest update, I am having trouble finding room for improvement; it sounds excellent across the range, even deep bass.  The main limit I hit is a streaming service I use defaulted back to low quality when I upgraded my phone, so deep bass was crushed a bit and overall was not sounding as good as my home computer which has been the same machine for a while now (where I got the quality options set right a while back), but resetting the values and clearing the cache has fixed this issue.  Really with noise cancelling mixed in I am hearing a lot more detail that would normally get washed out from background noise and my desire to keep volume levels down in order to preserve my hearing.  Have the best of both worlds now.

3. In call sound quality is reported to be good across a number of calls now, even from the datacenter floor.  Especially considering this does not have a boom mic, that is pretty good.  I remember in the past getting a call on the datacenter floor with a lesser headset and nobody could hear anybody.  Then again they have been moving servers to the cloud and the remaining servers are running cooler with the reduced heat load on the CRACs and thus their fans have slowed a bit, bit it is still really loud in there, so both parties hearing loud and clear is pretty amazing.

4. The battery really does go the distance and I would venture to say the 20 hour rating would be for harsh use cases where my main use case is mellow office building use.  I am thinking more like 25 hours in an office.  I just love how my newer devices can just go and go on batteries, at least initially where in the past battery life started off too short an then quickly became frustratingly way too short.  Starting off with plenty of time I have some room to do some battery life extension tricks like limiting the charge window manually.  Now if this was something built into the product like what you can do with a Tesla car, that would be really nice as changing out batteries every two years or so, especially with how devices are built these days is a bit of a PITA and too often goes badly.

5.  For sound cancellation, I have to say there is something to be said for pretty much all of the ambient noise just going away and it just being dead silent.  Seems to weird some people out, but I think it is great.  Can still hear people talk and other loud sounds, but I seems to be rather muffled.  Also it seems to be good at figuring out what is white noise and clearing that out completely where some other frequencies that are more useful get through better.  Also love being able to walk down a busy street and hear my music, especially without having to sacrifice my eardrums in the process, especially as a lot of really loud noise around freeways and such are really muffled down.  Found in a noisy data center that if I were to go to the barber, they would work better, but still work quite well with the hair I have, just little bit of bleed through sound from the excess hair around my ears.  Pressing the headphones down causes things to get a lot quieter.  Plenty good for easy on the ear drum music listening while in the data center.  Have used for other things like muffling noisy power tools and having my wife watch her TV next to me and not be distracted by anything at all.  Beginning to think this could be the beginnings of a great relationship... Oh wait a sec.

My complaints so far are:
1. My #1 complaint is removed as it seems to have been fixed with the latest firmware update as I thought would be possible.  Star added back.  Thanks Bose!

2. I have noticed doors around the office that automatically slam shut while this headset muffles the higher frequencies, the lowest frequencies seem amplified and so it is like my head is getting hit with a sound pressure wave.  Been thinking about this more and I have been moving in the direction of what this does muffle, it does so well that what it does not effectively muffle seems quite loud as the ears adjust to the greatly reduced sound levels hitting them overall.

3. The radio antenna seems to be on the right side only.  Being a lefty I like putting my phone on the left side, but that just does not go well.  Have to use the right side when going for a walk.

author: Bobbie Digital
title: Bose is not what it used to be save your money there are just as good headphones for a lot less
content: I have always been a Bose girl, everything i have bought in terms of sound has been Bose for the last 25-30yrs for me so I bought this headset because of my loyalty. I am very pleased with the noise cancellation but the overall sound quality just sounded Tinny to me, no bass either and the volume does not go that high, so out of curiosity to compare, I purchased a different brand, ITeknic for less than $50 bucks and the noise cancellation is just as great as Bose but the sound quality is more superior and it has great bass and a loud volume. I am keeping the iTecknic and returning the Bose and saving myself $300 bucks. What happened Bose?

author: Jeremy Young
title: Sony WH-1000X M3 are (surprisingly) better, sorry.
content: Just ok, the latest Sony WH-1000X M3 NC are superior head to head. Sound quality was fair, NC is good, battery life is ok. They are like the Cracker Barrel of headphones, bland at best. If you just need $350 NC ear plugs and don't care about sound, you found these Bose, so buy them. If you like music, movies, games, audio etc. the Sony are vastly superior, and the NC is honestly on par. I bought a pair of both headphones for my wife and I, for an upcoming trip to Thailand. She doesn't care about audio, so the QC35II's are good for her. They aren't terrible or anything, they just aren't the best available for the same price.

author: RTM135
title: Decision Depends on Priorities
content:
Like many of you, I was torn between the Sony WH 1000XM2 and Bose QC35 II.  The decision is going to come down to your priorities.  Sony's headphones overall sound better, especially with dance or bass-heavy music.  If you have FLAC or ALAC tracks, you'll notice the Sony sounding better since they support the LDAC Bluetooth codec, which is more advanced and uses higher bandwidth than Bose,

However, if you're heavily invested in the Android ecosystem and need the headphones to travel, the Bose are more comfortable and have better controls as the touch controls on the Sony are hit and miss.  The built-in Google Assistant is actually very helpful once you learn it's capabilities.

So overall I give 4/5 stars since the sound technology is not as advanced as the Sony's but overall the best choice if you need a good home/work/travel solution.

author: djsh4dowfan
title: Bose QC 35 vs Sony WH-1000XM3
content:
I purchased both both Bose QC 35 and Sony WH-1000XM3 headphones. I ended up returning the Sony headphones. Here is my comparison of the two:

- Both have very good active noise cancellation (ANC)
- Both have good sound, although the Sonys probably have more base, which I personally liked
- Both come with an app you can install on your phone to configure them to an extent. The Sonys are more configurable, with an EQ and more granular noise cancellation.
- The Sonys have an adaptive noise cancellation feature that will change the ANC level based on where you are and what you are doing (e.g., sitting vs traveling). I personally don't care about this feature or find it that useful.
- I found the Bose to be more comfortable and easier to fold up put away. The Sony earpads weren't as soft, and the headphones clamped down on my head with more pressure.
- I found the Sonys to have more intense ANC overall. My ears are sensitive to ANC, and I get the feeling of having pressure in my ears with ANC enabled. That feeling was much less intense on the Bose, even on high, despite the Bose having very good ANC, which gave me the impression that the Sony ANC was more brute force and less accurate.
- The Sonys have neat touch controls for volume, play/pause, prev/next, etc. While it's a cool feature, it wasn't something I cared that much about, and I was often worried I was going to accidentally change something when taking the headphones off and on. I don't think the buttons on the Bose headphones detract from their looks.
- The Bose can connect up to 2 devices at once, which is pretty nice. I can be connected to both my phone and my laptop and seamlessly switch between them.

Ultimately I returned the Sony headphones because I found the Bose to be more comfortable. My biggest gripe about both pairs of headphones is they do not save your last ANC setting! I cannot believe this feature was overlooked. I don't plan on using ANC all of the time. If I turn the ANC to low or completely off, when I turn the headphones off and on again, it will reset to high. The Sony app even allows you to configure the ANC at a granular level and allows you to configure the ANC for different usage patterns when the adaptive ANC is on; however, those settings also didn't persist, making them basically useless. I found the Sony Android app to be pretty buggy in general. I would strongly prefer an actual physical switch for the ANC setting instead of just having the setting be software controlled.

author: Robert J. Cote
title: Had to go wireless with iPhone X
content: So I broke down and went for the high end Bose QuietComfort 35 at close to $350, and then went for a second pair of Bluetooth devices, the SoundCore Spirit X Sports Earphones by Anker for about $30.  For sound quality alone, the Bose wipe out the Ankers, no surprise.  Comfort also is much better with the Bose, although the multiple earpieces with the SoundCore really are helpful.  Noise cancellation - I can weedwhack while wearing the Bose and actually hear the music!  So no question, the Bose, is the first choice to be on my head.  That being said, the SoundCore take a close second place.  Why?  Working out they are much cooler on my head!  I do a lot of yard work, and it doesn’t take much in 70 degree plus weather for the full Bose ear muffs to get too hot.  Also, there are many circumstances when sound blocking is a very bad idea, such as being out walking or running along any trafficked road, etc.  And sometimes having something not so obvious on one’s head isn’t a bad idea.  Yes, for $30 you don’t get mind blowing sound, but the SoundCore’s are respectively fine for listening to podcasts, news, and music when needing to be aware of the external environment.  So my suggestion is to buy both.

author: RandomEstablishedHuman
title: Painful, sound cuts out constantly
content: I have really good hearing and bought these to help me concentrate. Hardcore buyer's remorse. Don't get these. They're heavy, uncomfortable on my jaw and the top of my head. Worst of all the sound cuts out at anywhere from 3-minute to 30-second intervals. Troubleshooting forums suggest this happens when then Bluetooth signal encounters a wifi signal? The noise cancellation isn't bad (low works ok, high setting creates a painful pressure), but these particular headphones are not worth the hype at all. I wish there were a try-before-you-buy option -- noise-canceling headphones are great; just not this design.

author: acujules
title: noise cancellation is not good
content: I had high expectations for the noise cancellation on these headphones, given that they are the most highly rated on the market, but they got a big fat FAIL from us. With the noise cancellation on High, the ambient noise disappears, but you can still hear talking, snoring, and keyboard typing. What's up with that? With the music on, the talking and sounds are diminished a bit more, but you shouldn't have to have music playing to make the noise cancellation work. We just bought the Beats Studio 3 for our son for his birthday, and the noise cancellation on them is outstanding. You cannot hear anything when they are on. We are returning these and ordering the Beats Studio 3.

author: Scottso
title: Best headphones on the market
content:
Bose does it again!  Without question, these are THE best headphones on the market.  The sound is balanced, battery life is long, build quality is excellent and the noise cancelling is best in class.  Dare I say they might even be underpriced.  If they're marked down, grab them.  This may be the last set of headphones you buy!

I was not compensated for this review and have no relationship with Bose.

author: Carlos Bel
title: Great wireless NC headphones! Bose is the best for NC.
content:
I have every QC generation that has been out there, and this one is top two due to the wireless feature.

Here’s a brief summary after a few months of use:

Pros:

- Wireless: living without cables is great! You don’t have to battling with tangled cables, or cables getting stuck around your things while you’re on an airplane.
- Battery life: I went back and forth between the US-Europe with one charge, so the 20ish hours is true and most of the times enough.
- Noise cancelling: the NC on this pair is good enough, most of the times work great and work at the level of corded QCs. Sometimes is useful to have the two levels option on, as you might want to use them in areas where you need to hear your surroundings. It works so good, that speaking over the phone might sound weird with no background noise.
- Firmware updates: Bose keeps posting updates for the firmware, so the performance and quality of connection improves over time.

Cons:

- Noise cancelling distortion: when I’m close to a window and the panels vibrate too much (landing), the NC causes a lot of white noise. Firmware updates have improved this, but it is still noticeable. So, if you like window seats, keep this in mind. In my opinion, the QC25 NC is the best from Bose.
- Cable needed: eventually, you will need a cable. Let’s face it, the airlines are slow to adopt and the backseat screens can only work with a cord... so make sure you don’t loose it or leave it behind! Also, Bose stopped putting the double plug adapter in this version, so if you’re flying in an older airplane you might be stock with mono sound.
- Charging cord: The case comes with its charging cable, a standard USB-micro USB cord. So if you have apple devices, you will need to carry it too.

I don’t use google assistant, but it works well with Siri. It just needs different command options.

author: John
title: Bluetooth Connection to Microsoft Surface and Windows 10 is a disaster
content: The Bluetooth connection to my wife’s iPhone is seamless, as it should be.  We have struggled with the connection to her Microsoft Surface and Windows 10 since we got these headphones at Christmas last year.  Today I spent 7 hours working on this, as I determined I would get them to work on the Surface.  I talked to two folks from Microsoft Support, each for well over an hour, plus waiting for software updates and other stuff it was a legit 7 hours.  I gave over the control to my computer and watched the support folks try to figure this out, but in the end they couldn’t get it to work.  The last thing we tried was updating the Bose software on the headphones, but that didn’t fix it either.  To be fair, the Windows 10 searching through many different screens and settings was not convenient and was very confusing.  At the start of this process, I was not able to connect to an Amazon Echo, which we did get to work.  I was using the connection to a Yamaha Sound bar as the bogie, and that worked from the get go.  At this point I don’t know who is at fault, Microsoft or Bose.  All I know is we were not able to get them to work on the Surface.  As I said, they work great with an iPhone, and also with an iPadPro.  Maybe the Apple developers at Bose can swing over and help the Microsoft developer team???????  Or maybe Windows 10 just is what it is.

author: Wayne H. Wilson
title: Great at noise cancelling. Horrible to set up. Music sound is meh.
content:
Never experienced such effective noise cancelling. Really great at that.

Did not expect such an annoyingly intricate setup hurdle, especially for such an expensive product. Had to go find and load an app that includes a sort of bizarre navigation and that sometimes just does it own random thing. Finicky Bluetooth connectivity, and difficult to switch between devices. Poorly identified/labeled Left & Right. Non-intuitive controls. I was seconds away from just sending them back, and will never again buy Bluetooth headphones. I will not use them for music... they aren't even close to the frequency range, depth, and clarity of my wired Sennheiser headphones.

Also did not include battery charger... only the USB cord for charging on a standard mobile phone charger. The sound connection cord is pathetically cheap.  Wish I had bought the Bowers & Wilkins or Sennheiser unit. It is just too much of a hassle to return these.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Witchcraft Involved in Noise Cancellation?
content: I am forced to the conclusion that witchcraft must have been employed in the creation of the noise cancellation in these headphones. Just now I had nothing playing on them while lying in bed and out of curiosity I turned off the noise cancellation. I was confused when I suddenly heard a loud rumbling. I took off the headphones and realized it was my white noise machine on my bedside table. I keep it pretty loud to drown out noises from outside the house. I turned the noise cancellation back on and the sound completely disappeared. How in the world can it do that? I mean, maybe white noise is something particularly easy for them to cancel out, but that is still incredible. Is someone playing a prank on me and just turning the noise machine off as soon as I hit the noise cancellation button? I might think so, but if I lean in really close to it, a bit of the sound gets through. A seemingly unrealistically small amount... and yeah, yeah the headphones sound amazing when you play stuff in them or whatever too.

author: Spacemom
title: Not Impressed with Customer Support
content: I called Bose support when the power button on my  head phones stopped working after 6 months. I took really good care of these head phones. When they were not in use or charging, they were in the case.The support guy (obviously not in the US) said all would be taken care of. When I did not receive my mailer I sent an email to Bose support. The response I got was that they had no record of my call. The call took an hour. Beware of Bose and their new international support.

author: Wild-Haired Gurl
title: Noise-Cancelling may be a slight exaggeration
content: I splurged on this rather pricey product for one reason, and one reason only - so that I could listen to my Mindfulness meditations (my daily attempt at post-work stress relief), while drowning out the irritating sounds of the reality shows my boyfriend likes to watch. Unfortunately, noise-cancelling is a bit of a stretch... they do a pretty good job of cancelling out mechanical sounds, like the washer, dryer, and air conditioner; however, they are not as adept at cancelling voices.  I still hear his reality shows. I have decided to keep the headphones, as they do provides pretty good sound and are better than any other earbuds than I've tried. They are comfortable and allow me to increase the volume higher than Bluetooth earbuds. I haven't used the Alexa/Google button much, other than some initial testing. I like the fact that I can switch from one to the other, depending on which virtual assistance I wish to use. The battery seems to have a pretty long life. I have recently used it to listen to some audio books and it seems to barely make a dent in the battery usage, providing it is reporting the accurate battery level.  Overall, these are a keeper, and a decent purchase, given Amazon's flexible payment policy.

author: B. Zenith
title: Best, but 1 negative
content:
I've had my for I think 10 years, then just bought this for my son who's 18.  Why anyone would choose 'Beats' is beyond me.  ok... maybe cooler colors that match your shoes with the Beats, but for noise reduction on a plane, playing music these are the best on the market.
My only complaint is the 'leather' on the ear pieces do wear out.  easy to replace but for this price they could use something of better quality.  It's for that I give them 4 stars.  I can't confirm if this was fixed for this version, but in 10 years on my last pair I've replaced them twice.  I think about $15 to replace is all.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Failed after 6 months
content: Worked flawlessly for about 6 months and then began dropping and reconnecting bluetooth connection. Many others are experiencing the same issue and no solution from Bose. The wireless feature is now useless.

author: T. O.
title: Interesting to use. White-noise pressure. Little sweaty during long use.
content: It works excellently. I routinely work in data centers and server closets, and as anyone else who has done this can tell you, it is noisy. Not quite 'jet engine' noisy, but noisy. These headphones blocked out that noise and with noise cancellation on, it was reduced to "windy day". The active noise cancellation felt like it added a bit of pressure. Using them for a long period of time (4-10+ hours) led to frequently removing them to towel the sweat off from around the ears. Battery life is excellent. During phone calls, the person on the other end said they could hear me clearly.

author: Mehmet Yorulmaz
title: Good headphone with multi device connection problem...
content:
I was in between Sony WH 1000XM2 and Bose QC35 II. After spending hours on watching/reading all the reviews, comparisons, I chose Bose over Sony, although almost all professional reviewers rated Sony higher than Bose. Let me do a quick review and explain why I did so:

i) Sound Quality: 8/10. Very "clean" sound. Definitely high quality and pleasing. In fact, it can be described as "calming". Not very base heavy. But my main use for this headphone is to cut the background noise and listen to a relaxing music while I am working/studying in a cafe. Therefore, keeping my aim in mind, the sound quality is right on target.

ii) Noise Cancellation: 8/10. It cuts out most of the outside noises. But, don't expect miracles as some people describe. For example, if somebody talks, you definitely hear them. There is also a slight pressure in my ears due to ANC, but I got used to it pretty quickly.

iii) Comfort: 9/10. The best one in the market in terms of comfort. Especially compared to my Plantronics Backbeat Pro. However, after wearing it for an hour or so, my ears still get warm to a level that I have to take off for a while. This was a surprise to me given all the positive reviews regarding the comfort of Bose QC35II.

iv) Call Quality 6/10: As mentioned in most of the reviews, Bose pick up external noise during phone calls. It is not to a level to prevent communication. However it certainly disturbs the other party. Compared to my Plantronics, this was not an issue at all on my Plantronics. People could not figure out whether I was using my headphones or not. So, if you are purchasing Bose for all day long phone calls at work, chose another headphones.

v) Features: 3/10. We all know that Sony has many more features (touchpad control of songs, adaptive noise cancelling, quick attention mode, etc.)  than Bose. To me they are not essential but nice to have. Especially quick attention mode. When somebody talks to me while wearing Bose, I do have to remove it which is a hassle. In my Plantronics, I could have handle those situations without removing headphone. Another important feature is multi-device connection simultaneously. That was one of the reasons why I did not chose Sony. I was hoping to connect to both my laptop and phone at the same time. However this feature is not working as it should. When I connect both my laptop and phone and try to listen to a song on my laptop, it doesn't play smoothly at all. It stops and starts at every 3-5 seconds by itself as if there is a problem with data transfer speed. And after 1-2 mins, my laptop (Dell XPS 13) crashes (it crashed 4 times within 30 mins). And let me tell you this. I have been using my laptop for the last 2 years. And it has not crashed even once until now. It is also up to date; all Windows & Dell driver updates are installed. Long story short, I can't connect Bose to both my laptop and phone as of now. I hope Bose solves this with a firmware update ASAP.

Regarding bluetooth connection strength, it is worse than my Plantronics. It disconnects at shorter distances that Plantronics and once it does, it does not automatically reconnects when I get closer to my device which Plantronics always did without any problems.

vi) Final Verdict: 7.5/10: Bose is a good headphones with some flaws and major weaknesses. It is far from perfect as many reviewers/users wholeheartedly claim. To be satisfied with your purchase, you need to decide what features in a headphone is  most important for you and what will be your main use. If it is the best sound quality or call quality, or if you want the most feature packed cook headset, skip Bose. You will hate it. If you more care the noise cancellation and comfort and then a clean sound, then go for it.

I hope this helps...

author: Fitness fanatic
title: Can't hold a bluetooth connection
content:
Update, so I reset them after the firmware update, and that fixed the problem. They work and sound much better. Added two stars. Still waiting to make sure the problem is really gone before I decide whether to keep them...

.....

So I just bought these a week ago, and the bluetooth connection constantly drops. It started every 5-10 min and now is basically every minute. Tried updating the firmware, but that actually made it worse. They don't even play for a minute now. They also don't sound any better than my $20 crappy earbuds, and they get a weird pop in the music in the limited time I can get them to play. Luckily, I still have the box at work. These are going back.
I'm pretty disappointed in these, considering how much they cost.

author: Tammy
title: Problems with the connections
content: I purchased these headphones having heard nothing but good in the past.  I bought these in the hopes they would work well.  I connected them to my samsung galaxy x.  The sound is good, the noise cancellation is good and the volume control are good, but my major problem with these are every 2 minutes, the voice comes on like it disconnected from my phone and I have to restart the song that it's playing, physically on my phone, then it'll go for another few minutes and do the same thing.  What a pain. I did research and thought these were the best, I was wrong when you have to reconnect it every few minutes.  I don't know where the glitch is but its a big one.

author: Zachary M Eldridge
title: Best headphones to own in 2019
content:
I am in love with these headphones!  I purchased a pair for myself and my wife and we have nothing but positive things to say about them.

These are comfortable to wear, have excellent battery life (20 hrs) and exhibit nothing less than phenomenal sound.  The noise cancellation is perfect for flights/drives/blocking out the world around you.

You dont simply listen to music with these headphones, you experience it.  Must have if you want to hear the music the way it was intended to be heard.

author: bptlage
title: Not what I hoped for
content: Don't get me wrong, the sound is good for watching TV, you can hear things you would not normally hear, but the headphones lack in music. Many years ago, my older brother had quadraphonic headphones that I listened to from a reel to reel player, that was the best music ever sounded to me. I had hoped the Bose Quiet Comport 35 headphones would come close, but disappointed I am. So, I can only give them 3 stars, which means average. Maybe I am being unfair, but digital music just does not compare to analog, what can you expect from 1's and 0's.

author: andre surles
title: Excellent! Works with PSVR too!
content:
This review focuses on using them for gaming, specifically for the PS4. They work great for everything else too but I wanted to focus on the gaming aspect because I hadn’t seen it covered.

I also purchased as set of PlayStation Gold wireless headphones, unfortunately they suffered from Bluetooth drop outs in wireless mode and didn’t fit well. (Just FYI usb 3.0 in conjunction with external hard drives creates electronic noise in the 2.4ghz spectrum which effects the wireless connectivity, including your router)

Anyway back to the Bose, these fit extremely well and are very comfortable even for people with extra large heads like myself. The wireless does NOT work with the PS4, however I don’t know about you but if I’m playing the PS4 then I’ve got a controller in my hand or a VR headset on...both of which have a 3.5mm jack.
Speaking of PSVR, these fit perfectly over the headset and because the PSVR requires a wired headset the PS Gold’s have zero advantage compared to the Bose.
Sound wise they are awesome and deliver a very immersive experience. Are they 3 times as good as the PS Gold? No. But they are notably richer and more nuanced and the fit is significantly better for me personally.

Note: If you are trying to use these with a mic for gaming you will need to pick up the android wired cable with Mic for the QC25’s.
Also the 2.5mm input on the headphones themselves requires a FIRM push, if you see metal on the plug tip then it’s not full inserted.

author: John S
title: Can even noise-cancel-out a chatty Marketing Department!!!
content:
These are amazing and Bose is great!  I purchased these headphones for their noise-cancellation abilities.  I am an application developer and wear them at work because I am easily distracted.  I don't even listen to music with them... they just cancel just about all background noise, including random chatter from the annoying marketing department.  I also use them for WebEx and Skype calls with clients.  The built-in microphone is great and the noise-cancellation is helpful during those calls as well.  Battery life is extremely good.  I can go an entire week without having to charge the headset.  It comes with an 1/8" cable that will allow you to listen to music even when the batteries are dead.  An added feature is that the bluetooth feature will allow you to connect to and hear audio from two sources at the same time.  This is great if you want to connect to your iPhone and laptop at the same time.

After a month of use, the headphones button would no longer work to pair to a new device.  It would still power on and off, just the pairing didn't function.  Bose support was difficult to deal with.  At first the support technician didn't think there was anything wrong with the headset.  After a frustrating conversation, he relented and sent me instructions for sending them back to the manufacturer.  This would mean that I would be without my precious headphones for at least two weeks.  The next day prior to dropping the headphones at UPS I came across The Bose Store at Tysons Corner Mall.  I had the headphones with me so I decided to speak to one of the employees there.  After a very brief conversation, and even though I purchased these through Amazon, he walks over to a display, gets me a brand new set of headphones and proceeds to exchange my defective ones for the new set.  No other questions asked.  He just said "We like to take care of our customers".  I wish customer support would have been as easy to deal with... but, things worked out.

author: Vilius
title: I'm loving it
content:
It's my 1st ANC headphones. I'm huge fan of Bluetooth headsets, so I'm using it wirelessly.

Pros:
• Very good for work - I'm not distracted by colleagues' conversations any more.
