• Noice cancellation is perfect - all outside sounds are removed, but if I someone would talk loudly near by, I could hear it quietly. That's perfect for not being distracted by random conversations around, but still be able to hear if someone would want to talk to me.
• Battery life is great
• App is very nice (only just few little complaints)
• Holds on my head very conveniently
• Has automatic sleep mode, so it's convenient if I forget it on my table turned on
• Supports two devices. Works better than expected (no other headphones worked that well for me before)

Cons:
• I can hear some ultrasound
• Strange feeling during 1st days of usage, but I think, I got used to it already.
• App does not remember what noice cancellation level I had set before (wanted to use it in a Low mode during 1st days, but now I got used to High mode).
• I'm not yet used to keep it on my neck - too big for me, restricts my head movements
• Some small issues with switching between two devices. Got confused couple of times which device is being connected to, but overall it supports two devices best as from my experience with other devices.

author: John R. Troy
title: Good Acoustics, but software/firmware not working well.
content:
At first, I was really excited for these headphones, as I heard Bose is the best and it was getting better reviews than the Sony.

The headphones fit the ears nice and snug, and the noise cancelling works wonders--a lot better than those $79.99 on-ear models.

However, the electronics don't seem to work well.  I can't get this to work with my Samsung Galaxy S8 Phone (Android Oreo update).  I've tried pairing several times and downloading new firmware, but it still won't connect.  Worse, the on-off switch appears to not work--it doesn't stay shut off!  It will turn on at random times and the battery gets drained.  The instructions didn't come in a booklet, you have to download the app.  Using it in corded mode seems to confuse the software.

I love the feel and the effects of the noise cancelling when it's on, but this just won't work.  I'll have to try once more this weekend and contact customer support but if that doesn't work, I'm going to return it.

title: Not as comfortable as the original QC35 headset
content: I have used Bose headsets for years and like their simplify and performance.  That being said I find this set of headphones is not as comfortable and they tend to pinch the top of my ears after wearing for more than 2 hours.  I have tried adjusting the head strap but have not yet found the sweet spot.  Sound quality is good and I like the flexibility of the bluetooth versus wired.  The wire cable they provide is kind of wimpy and can easily be broken so I replaced with a better quality.  The ability to share music with another set of headset is great.  My wife and I can watch a move together

author: Amy
title: Great sound quality and amazing noise cancellation
content:
I purchased these and the Sony WH1000XM2 to compare the two. Cnet says they both have a "9" for sound quality. I would agree, they both sound excellent. The Bose won the test for its noise cancellation, performance talking to people on the phone, comfort on my head, and sound processing.

Phone performance:
I compared how the Bose and the Sony sounded when recording and playing back my voice with a fan running in the background. The Bose sounded like I was holding an old fashioned handset and talking in a quiet room - intimate and zero background noise. The Sony sounded like I was on speaker phone, and I could hear some background noise. (As a control I also recorded using neither and it sounded like I was on speaker but also I could hear more background noise.) This feature is important to me since I spend a lot of time on the phone and prefer my clients to not hear any background noise.

Sound quality
The Bose and Sony both have excellent sound quality for playing music. I personally prefer the sound the Sony produces. The Sony iphone app lets you choose your levels on an equalizer, and I like that. However, the Bose hears what type of music you're playing and automatically optimizes the sound, and it does a really good job. While I would prefer to be able to set the levels if I so choose, I also appreciate that Bose is making it all easy for me, so I can truly listen to my music on random and not have to fuss with levels. The Bose iphone app doesn't do very much at all. It does let you "find your headset" similar to the "find my phone" app, and it will apply firmware. (I'm hoping Bose will add an equalizer into its app in the future.)

Noise cancellation
The Sony occasionally made me aware that noise cancellation was going on (with a whitenoise effect). The Bose on the other hand just stops the noise. There is no delay, no white noise, just quiet and your music.

Controls
The Bose controls are intuitive to find and to use. I like that the on-off control is a switch to flip on and off (rather than a button to find). Also, you can use this button to switch between devices, for example between your phone and ipad and your TV amplifier. The right earcup has three small buttons in a row together, and they control a lot of things. Volume, pause, and skip, rewind, answer/decline calls, etc. The left earcup only has the google assistant button, which I programmed to instead control the amount of noise cancellation (high, low, off). Song playback sounds much better with noise cancellation on high, and I don't think that has to do with noise (I was in a quiet environment); the bass sounds enhanced with noise cancellation on for some reason. (In comparison, the Sony lets you swipe the earcup itself to control volume, pause, play, skip, etc. This seems great in theory, but in practice if I bumped  the earcup adjusting my glasses or whatever, the music would pause. I found the Sony to be somewhat buggy in that regard. It would stop playing at times and I had to pick up my phone to get the music re-started, which is annoying.) I found the Bose controls to be more intuitive and consistent. Also, when you switch them on a voice tells you how much battery you have left, which is handy.

Comfort
The Bose QuietComfort truly is comfortable. The earcups are soft, there is not a lot of clamping, and the top band is padded so it's less annoying on the top of the head.  (In comparison, the Sony do have more clamping which was uncomfortable over glasses.) I am a pilot and wear a similar headset, so I'm familiar with how headphones feel after a few hours. On-ear are not going to be as comfortable for long term wear as earbuds would be, but I was wiling to make that trade-off to get superior sound quality.

Style
The Bose are more streamlined to my head. the Sony are bulky and look geeky.

Conclusion
Even though the Sony produces superior sound, the litany of other features (superior noise cancellation, intuitive controls, comfort, style, & phone performance) won me over to the Bose.

author: daVid
title: Not thrilled
content: I purchased these to replace my aging but functional Bose AE2 headphones. In comparison, I absolutely hate the controls. It is very difficult to press the SMALL pause/play button that is nested between the volume up down buttons. They are a little heavier and less comfortable especially since I wear them for long stints at work. They do sound great and the noise canceling is nice. They appear to be well made. The case is stupid. Bottom line- I regret having made this purchase.

author: mfg
title: Noise cancelling???
content: Felling quite perplexed here with the reviews, the reason I bough these is to cancel out moderate noise while Im working, however as soon as I set these up I could still hear all the noise around me.  Check and double checked. Did a test with my laptop 1 foot away from me and an audio book on, can still hear every word!  So the tiniest bit of noise cancelling but no more than you'd get from a cheap throwaway pair from a flight.  Massively disappointed.  Have looked online and it appears from april 2019 there was a software update that hasn't rendered headphones that worked great before useless with noise cancelling.  So Ill be sending back and getting the sony, apparently they aren't as comfy but Ill put up with that over this piece of cheap rubbish.

author: vee99
title: Bose does not disappoint.
content:
I have always used Bose, been over two years so needed another headset for all around listening. I would give the
shipping six stars if they were available, it came, open my door, and right where I wanted it. This item was by itself
more expensive than $260 HH jacket I bought which took almost a week to get after paying extra $20 for shipping.
If you do not have honest neighbors, not recommended to have Amazon drop it off on your doorstep. Now, as far
as the headphone goes, it is wireless, plus has the mono cable for wired use, when you turn on the noise cancellation,
it greatly reduces the ambient noise, plus, it is so comfortable, the around the ear feel is natural, you can wear it all
day possibly.  I have never been a fan of Beats, just by looking at the two, Bose is the better choice, it is like that car
commercial where they are trying to sell a red pick up truck, it looks cool, the girls dig it but not practical and red pick
up trucks get pulled over more than any vehicle. Do not fall for the cheese!!!

author: Margaret Saunders
title: After 1 Year - Left Ear not working
content: When I originally bought this I would have given it 5 stars but just a little over a year the left headphone has stopped working...ugh ...answer by Bose Support buy another one...hmm not sure if I got a lemon or not but for the price this is crazy.

author: Jordan T
title: Google Assistant integration takes these over the top
content:
OVERALL OPINION:
These headphones are amazing!  I might have been perfectly satisfied with the first version of the QC35s, but I luckily stumbled on the second generation which includes the Google Assistant integration.  I initially thought it would be a small bonus, but I totally underestimated how powerful and convenient this could be.  It's more than just a trigger for voice commands.  It's a surprisingly flawless implementation that allows Google Assistant to turn you into much more productive multi-tasker.

GOOGLE ASSISTANT VOICE COMMANDS:
You start by connecting the headphones to your phone via the 'Bose Connect' app.  Now, all you have to do is press and hold the button on the left side and speak your voice command.  This is a lot easier and less tedious than having to precede every command with "OK Google", but this isn't even the best part of this integration.

GOOGLE ASSISTANT NOTIFICATIONS:
The best feature of the Google Assistant integration is the ability to receive voice notifications!  Whenever you receive a notification on your phone, it is automatically spoken to you on your headphones.  When text messages are received, not only can you have the message read to you with a single click of the left button, but you're also presented with an immediate opportunity to send a voice-to-text response by holding the left button while speaking.  This allows you to multitask like no other.  The Bose Connect app allows you to choose between temporarily pausing your audio during the notification (so you don't miss a second of that podcast you were listening to) or just reducing its volume while the notification is played.  You can double press the left button to shut Google Assistant up mid-notification if you ever wish to as well.  It's an excellent experience.

I tried smartwatches in the past, but they never seemed to deliver a convenience above and beyond what a phone could do on its own.  The hands-free and vision-free experience these headphones enable fills the void we all hoped smartwatches would.

CONNECTING TO TWO DEVICES:
Speaking of multitasking, these headphones can be connected to two devices at a time without the fumbling and confusion that comes along with other Bluetooth headphones offering similar functionality.  I’ve got mine connected to my Android phone and my Windows PC.  Start playing media from either device and it’s streamed right to your headphones.  To play from the opposite device, just pause the current media on the first device and then play the new media on the second device.  It’s that simple.  But to receive the notifications I mentioned, your current connection must be with your phone.

FIT, FORM, & FUNCTION:
Lastly, you might be wondering how these headphones perform as headphones.  The answer is great!  Check out all the reviews of the first generation for the details as I don’t think much has changed there.  They’re very comfortable, lightweight, and they don’t make your ears sweat or hurt over long periods of continual usage.  I explained the left button for interacting with Google Assistant in depth, but the media controls on the right are just as useful and intuitive.  Double-click the play/pause button to skip to the next track and triple-click it to go back a track.  The wireless range, the sound quality, and the battery life (20 hours) is all top notch for such a portable package.  I haven’t tested the mic quality during a call yet, but even if it’s not the greatest, this headset has already exceeded my expectations in so many ways - I couldn’t be happier with the design.

author: Mike
title: Great noise canceling, best noisy open office solution, not great for audio enthusiasts
content: I bought these for my open office, which is rather noisy. It blocks most white noise entirely (HVAC, high pitch noise from lighting, etc). It probably cuts voices down by 60%. Bluetooth and dual pairing with my laptop and phone work seamlessly. Unfortunately, the audio quality is lacking - both highs and lows ("must be Bose?") are disappointing... but with music on at a low volume, these pretty much block out all voices entirely. The headphones themselves are lightweight and feel very sturdy and luxurious with the suede and leather; they certainly don't feel like cheap plastic. I tried wearing these outside on a windy day, and they just couldn't understand how to handle the "sound" of air blowing on them.

author: Alex
title: Incredible sound and ANC. Terrible mic. Questionable Bluetooth.
content:
Sound and noise cancellation is fantastic. I use my headphones primarily at the office and on planes.

Unfortunately the microphone is terrible unless you’re in a very quiet environment. Ambient noise is picked up and amplified to the point of extreme distraction for whoever is on the other line. I use these for business calls so have to be very careful where I am when I do. Others appear to have this issue but not everyone. It’s frustrating and not acceptable at this price point.

The other major issue is Bluetooth. I regularly have my phone and computer connected. They consistently disconnect and reconnect throughout the day. More rarely, my voice is garbled to people on the other line and I end up have to shut them off and finish the call with another headset. Again, not good at this price point.

Despite the flaws, I still use these everyday. The sound, noise cancellation, and lost calls in quieter environments are very good. But for the cost, the mic and Bluetooth issues really need to be fixed. So I can’t wholeheartedly recommend them.

author: MT
title: Worth the money
content:
So right before I bought these headphones, I had bought another much cheaper wireless headset (boltune 2019 upgrade version).
The cheaper headset actually surprised me in terms of sound quality and ear comfort. However you do begin to feel the pressure of the headband after a while which leads to headaches.
I’m on my pc a lot and wanted headphones that wouldn’t hurt my head during long sessions so after comparing the countless Bose and Sony reviews I decided to go with Bose since every review said they were more comfortable.
 I haven’t had it long but I can already tell it’s the best set I’ve had.  The comfort is at a level which I didn’t think was possible for headphones.  Really just enjoyable to have on.
The sound quality is something I also really like.  The reason I like it is that it doesn’t try to over exaggerate everything that’s played through it with bass or effects.
It has a very balanced clear sound when it needs to and it has great sounding bass when the song calls for it.

author: Kristen King
title: They don’t really cancel noise....
content:
I’m not sure if I was expecting too much from these. For the price though I thought they would be better. The sound quality is great... the color is really nice. But I don’t understand why they are called noise cancellation. In fact some noises are amplified. For example, on the plane, the noise of the plane engine was slightly reduced while the noise of the kid next to me talking nonstop to her mom was enhanced. I was hoping I could turn on noise cancellation without any music so I could take a nap but to do that I still had to use foam ear plugs as well or I had to use my white noise app which kind of defeats the purpose.
That complaint aside, the sound is really nice for watching movies or zoning out while listening to music. The battery lasts forever. I went on a three week trip and only charged them once before hopping on the plane back home.

author: David Jacobson
title: Amazing noise cancellation, high quality sound
content:
Absolutely amazing noise cancelling.  I can listen to delicate harpsichord music while sitting in a jet airplane, and music is totally enjoyable.

The sound is very good.  Good bass.  Clean highs.  They sound a tad better than my Audio Technica ATH-M50s.  Bear in mind that I'm 72 years old, so I probably can't hear much above 10 or 12 KHz.  It can Bluetooth pair with with multiple device, an you can switch from one to another.  (Very very nice.)  You can have the noise cancellation high (normal), low, or off.  This is good if you are, say, using them at home where the isn't much noise, but need to hear the doorbell or phone.  There is a built-in rechargeable battery.  It last a long time.

There is one button that you press it once to stop/start the music twice for something else, 3 times to go back to the beginning of the track.  This is difficult:  there are too many things to remember, and worse yet, there is no nice little cheat sheet, and no manual; you have to install an app and then read through the FAQ and look for the question like "How do I advance to the next track".  This could have been much better.

author: Joao Poneis
title: Unpleasant glitches and early wear off
content:
I have a very unpleasant experience with this equipment. There are constant small glitches when playing from a laptop. While it works fine when playing from a smartphone, the limitation is annoying. There is a thread with more than 26 pages in Bose's support community discussing the issue.
Removing from the laptop and reinstalling worked for a while. Now it doesn't. I updated the firmware and followed all recommendations, but the problem persists.
For the very high price it charges you, Bose should provide a better support.
I do not recommend the purchase, with so many other similar options in the market.

Update:
I could make the headphones to work without glitches by disabling a couple of Bluetooth Services, namely ARfcomm, AudioWear, AudioWear Voice and Handsfree Telephony. It still presents glitches, but now it is less frequent.
However, now I have another issue. The earpads began to wear off. It is way too early for this to happen (I bought about 10 months ago). I again asked for support, but Bose is very inattentive.

author: M. Thomas
title: Noise cancelling is PHENOMENAL
content: I bought these for traveling and the noise cancelling is amazing. Now remember - these are not audiophile headphones. These are more for the function of noise cancelling. The sound quality is good but not as much bass as some people would like. Pairing is easy and calls are great too. I will note that I had to pair with my Samsung TV first before all my other devices. Battery life is superb and the headphones are so comfy! They cover your whole ear. Comes with a sturdy carrying case as well with pockets. Absolutely worth the money.

author: V. Scott
title: Nice but not Fabulous
content: I purchased these for the rave reviews of sound cancellation mostly.  I work at home and my mother has dementia and yells frequently.  And yes, I certainly can hear her, even in a separate room with the door closed, so it is much better, but not what I expected.  Of course, I'm apparently underestimating the lung and sound making capacity of my Mom also.  Sound listening quality is great - I love hearing my audible books on it while I work out and I am sure I will enjoy it when I travel overseas, but I doubt it will really block the plane noise like I hoped it would.  Buttons on the headset are ok, but I find myself feeling around a lot or taking them off to figure out where the button is.  This was a splurge for me, and I don't plan to return them, but I don't think I really needed them either.

author: Stephane C.
title: What an upgrade from my QC15!
content:
I have been using a Bose QC15 headphone for so many years for my travels, but ultimately felt I needed to get an upgrade. And then I bought the QC35 II.
And what an upgrade!
First the overall sound quality improved, especially when the noise reduction is on (strangely, music sounds better with NR on than without NR).
And then I made a side by side comparison, and wow, what an improvement in the noise reduction field!!
This week end, my neighbourg decided to throw a party with live music.  I started to feel in despair until I remembered I had the QC35, so I put them on, and boom, the noise disappearely nearly completely. I just played some relaxing music to a very low level, and I felt completely in peace.
This thing is magical!
I like that through the Bose application, I could reprogram the asssistant button to select the NR level (3 levels, High, medium, or off).  I guess I am old school, I do not like the assistants like Alexa, Google, and so on. I am not using these things.
I did not have the opportunity to use them for phone calls. But reviews are not so enthusiast about this feature, so I guess I will not use these headphones for calls. I still have "regular" wired earbuds with a good quality microphone to run with my Samsung S10 when I am on the move and need to attend some calls.
FInally, as far as design is concerned, clearly the Bose headphones are not the slickest headphones around.  They look pretty dull to me, but well, at least for me, I prefer having the best noice reduction around, with a decent sound quality, rather than the best looking headphones.

author: Ed Everhart
title: Great Product That's Worth the Price
content: I've wanted a pair of these headphones for a long, long time, but I couldn't convince myself to spend $350 on a pair of headphones, but now that I've experienced the bliss that is Bose Noise Cancelling I can't imagine traveling anywhere without them. I travel to Europe and Asia several times a year and take domestic, cross country flights regularly. I decided to purchase my Bose headphones before my latest trip in Week 37, 2018. I put on my new headphones, settled into my seat, hit play on my travel playlist, and everything else disappeared.  I didn't realize just how good the noise cancelling function worked until I took the headphones off for a minute. The noise of the plane seemed almost deafening.  I quickly put the headphones back on and enjoyed the rest of my 10 hour flight with everything around me silenced.  I've bought several pairs of headphones prior to purchasing the Bose headphones because I wasn't willing to pay the price.  I can tell you that they don't even come close to the noise cancelling abilities of the Bose headphones.  In addition to the noise cancelling feature, the look and feel (especially the feel) of the materials are of the highest quality. The way the headphones feel when I put them on is like nothing I've ever experienced.  Again, all the other headphones I've bought and tried don't even come close.  The sound quality is also exceptional. I would definitely recommend these to someone who wants their own little oasis, especially people who travel a lot. The other headphones I've tried aren't even worth considering. If I could do it all over I would have saved myself the $200 I spent on lower quality headphones and gone straight to the Bose headphones from the beginning. I will use these headphones for a long, long time.

author: Far
title: Awesome headphones....thank you Dr. Bose!
content:
To be completely open, I did NOT purchase the Bose QuietComfort 35 II Wireless Bluetooth Headphones from AMZ. one of the rare things. I originally received the Bose QC 35II  and later Sony 1000XM3 through a vine program to test and review. I tested both headphones and have used many other types of headphones, over the ear and inner ear.

I purchased another Bose QuietComfort QC 35II Wireless Bluetooth Headphone a couple of years later (long story). I am not an Audiophiles by any means but I like Music.! Recently, I read a "highly rated" review of the Sony 1000XM3, therefore I felt compelled to write a review of the Bose QuietComfort QC 35II Wireless Bluetooth Headphones.

I LOVE the overall comfort of the Bose QC 35II, literally all day comfort. I have worn these when using an elliptical, watching a movie while connected to a laptop, and listening to all kinds of music. Comfort is where the Sony 1000XM3 fell off for me, as did other over the ear headphones. The Sony headphones do sound good, ANC is subjective!

The build quality on the Bose is excellent, they don't feel cheap! The bass is not overbearing and heavy, however it does sound clean! Listening to the song "Purple Rain", I became immersed in the music...I could hear everything as it was meant. That has not happened with any other headphone or IEM. Sony ear-cups do not feel as solid and I don't think overall quality is the same.

I have tried the Sony 1000XM3, Plantronics FIT, Grado Labs SR-80, JBL, Apple OEM inner ear, Klipsch IEM, and a few other generic brands. The Bose QC 35II  remain my favorite for sound! The Plantronics are good for working out. The IEMs, such as Klipsch get full of ear-wax.

I have the headphones connected to the Echo, so I can push the speech button the headphone and ask Alexa to play a song. That is sweet!! There is also a multi-function button for Siri, which Bose does not advertise. Pairing to phone and laptop was a piece of cake, the headphones tell you which device it is connected to. The Bose App is basic but provides information on the headphones, firmware updates, and connection to Echo.

Sound is a personal thing, everyone experiences this differently. Therefore, headphones that work for me, may not work for you. I have used the following types of headphones:

Sony Sports Wired (going back to the 80's)
Panasonic (going back to the 80's)
Grado Labs - SR-80 Wired
Klipsch IEM Wired
Apple OEM wired
Plantronics FIT Bluetooth
Sony 1000XM3 BT
Bose QC2 BT

Sony is a conglomerate, multiple business units making different products. We all know that Sony is a legendary company!I Sony products are hit or miss. I  have been a little obsessed with Bose, not only the products but as a company. The Bose QC 35II are something that the company's founder - Dr. Amar Bose would have been proud of.  Bose as a company is an amazing story and the products that they produce are incredible. I am now thinking about their portable speaker offerings.

The only drawback that I can is the lack of an EQ in the app. However, many other manufacturers do not offer this.

author: Laurentiff
title: The absolute best
content:
Let me start by saying I was insanely reluctant to purchase these headphones for a few reasons: A)  I travel 80% for my job. I basically live on Delta. Throughout the year I have made some really stupid headphone purchases on a whim, being a complete newbie to the headphone game. Right before purchasing these I had purchased Beats Solo 3, again on a whim, during Amazon prime day.  After wearing them several times, painfully so, I realized that I had wasted $150 on headphones and I had to buckle down and do some research B) these are expensive… &*^%ing expensive.  This was a big decision.

All that said - holy crap these things are amazing!  I can literally wear them, and have worn them, all day with zero discomfort. To put that into perspective, after about 30 minutes - to an hour with my other headphones, my ears would start to hurt due to the pressure and poor product  ergonomics.  Not these - they are amazeballs.

The noise canceling is also by far superior to anything I’ve tried.  I recently took a last-minute flight and got stuck in the middle seat in between two men that were well over 6’2 and chatting each other throughout the flight.  FML.  BUT - I seriously could not hear a word coming from them.  One guy even had to tap my shoulder to get my attention when the flight attendant came around. These things seriously rock.

The price point sucks but it’s worth it in the end.

author: Timothy Owen Koneval
title: Insistent voice stating that headphones needed to be connected. ...
content: Insistent voice stating that headphones needed to be connected. They were not effective at noise cancelling. Supposed to be effective even when not listening to music.

author: Andrew Kunkel
title: Sounds fine when it is not stuttering which is almost always
content: They sound good and do a fine job of giving me a quiet place to work but do not try to connect them to Windows 10 and an Android phone at the same time.  When this is connected to both devices at the same time audio starts to stutter uncontrollably after a few minutes.  With each firmware update I hope it will be fixed but so far it has not.  I have several other Bluetooth headphones that work flawlessly connected to both devices.  You can see support questions about this all over the place and Bose has no solution except to blame one or both of the devices or just a canned response about how to delete and re-pair you devices.

author: Andrey
title: NC is very annoying and can't be disabled permanently
content:
Regret buying these, because NC by default is always set to Maximum.
It's not comfortable to have enabled for more than 30 minutes.

There's a way to turn it off - via mobile app, which is pain. You need to do it EVERY TIME you turn the headphones on.
You can also assign the function button to control the level of NC, but 1. you still need to do it EVERY TIME you turn them on. 2. It kills the main function - Google (or Alexa) assistant functionality because you cannot use it now.

author: yamichi
title: Dang near life changing
content:
I took a new job that is going to require some international travel.  It was recommended that I get some good quality ANC (active noise canceling) headphones for the long flights and I decided to get them a bit early.

HOLY CRAP!  I spend ~2.5 hours a day on busses 4 days a week and my comfort, my alertness, and my overall attitude when I get to work is so much better.  The bus engine and vibration becomes a dull hum in the background. You can't even hear the air handlers. Most conversations are damped down to a level you don't care.  You can HEAR your music (or podcasts) without turning them up loud.

I wish I'd bought these years ago.

author: Ray-Ray Z.
title: Awesome Sound and Comfort.
content:
First of all, I am a HUGE fan of all things Bose!!!
I still own, and use, my original pair of QC2s (now just for piano practice) as well as my QC15s (@ home office), and QC25s (@ work office).
I originally thought I'd try the QC35 (Series II) Wireless because my Pixel 2 phone is missing the all-important headphone jack (grrrr).

Glad I did!.

The QC35 is lighter, more comfortable, and has better noise cancelling than any of its older siblings. And, when paired with my smart TV, I can hear the faintest whisper of dialogue or really crank up the explosions without waking up the family - even when the Air Conditioner is blowing its hardest!

My QC25s go thru at least 1 AAA battery per week with daily use (6-10hrs per day) so I was very skeptical of the QC35s non-replaceable internal battery, but it really hasn't been a problem thus far. Even after multiple hours of catching up on all things MCU, I have yet to get it below 60% and it charges fairly quickly with a decent wall adapter.

So, why didn't I give it 5 stars???
1.  The new carrying case is way too small and no longer has the expandable outer pocket or shoulder strap that my QC2 case has (been an issue since the QC15s). That could be a plus for some people, but the QC2 case (which I still use!) has enough room for me to carry a couple of airline travel necessities (like a blow up pillow and eye mask).
2.  The included audio cable (for non blue tooth use) and USB charging cord are way too short.
3.  Bose non longer includes an audio extension cable (which would make point 2 irrelevant) or the funky little 2x1 "airline adapter" (who cares, right?).  You can still buy these accessories but, for $350 you shouldn't have to.

All that said... I still highly recommend these headphones!

author: Matt
title: I own two of these... ran one ...
content: I own two of these... ran one of them over with a skid steer and when I told bose about it, they said no problem... ship them back and we'll send you a new pair completely free.  Sure enough, that's exactly what they did!

author: Robert L.
title: Expensive but worth it
content:
I used these headphones to block out background noise at work.  The noise cancelling feature works so well it is disappointing to take them off.  I had not considered how nice it would be to use these to make phone calls until I just made a call.  Not only could I hear the other person on the line, they could also hear me very well.
* You should note that Alexa integration is available after you update the firmware on the headphones, so don't be surprised when, during the setup process, you are only presented with Google Assistant as your voice control choice.
* The headphones came with 60% battery and this lasted me a long time, about a week.
* I like the Bose-supplied case, I don't see what another third-party case would do for me.
* I ordered this with standard free shipping at 10:00am and they were delivered before 8:00am the next day.  This was a pleasant surprise.

I hope these last because they were expensive, but things seem good so far.

author: ray
title: Bluetooth is awful. I want my money back
content:
I love the sound of Bose.  I have two pairs of the sport Bluetooth earphones. I have had two Quiet Comfirt wired headphones. Sadly, this more expensive headset isn’t worth it. I’d love to have my money back.

 About every 30-45 min, the headphones remain on but lose the signal. I’m within arms reach of my laptop, yet this has happened repeatedly. If two devices are on, they get confused and drop signal, or I’m stuck on the wrong device. I’m forced to turn off all other Bluetooth devices. Keep in mind, my earphones don’t have this problem.  For the first time on Bose and on Amazon, I DON’T recommend this product.

author: BlueKnight1600
title: Performs as advertised....AWESOME headphones
content: You put these these headphones on, and, like on the commercial, you seal the rest of the world out. The sound quality is like a concert hall, and the cushion seals, that close around your ears to seal out the sound, and the cranial pad that rests the unit on top of your head, are butter soft to the touch, and extremely comfortable around the ears, and the top of your head. I used them on a flight I took from Newark airport, to Dallas/Fort Worth, and once I sealed them around my ears, I couldn't even hear the jet engines. I felt their vibration, but heard nothing. And you can use them either wired, or blue tooth connected, AND you can answer, and talk on your cell through them. THE BEST headphones I have ever owned. They are pricey, and that would be the ONLY negative I could find about them, that's why I gave them 4 stars, instead of 5. But the BOSE brand can't be beat. I would just like them a little bit cheaper. EXCELLENT gift for the gadget weenie in your life......They will not be disappointed

author: Mark
title: Buyer beware: fake headphones being shipped
content:
I had the QC25 and decided to upgrade to the 35s. The product that was shipped to me was labeled as QC35 but the box it was shipped in had signs it had been tampered with. The headphones inside were not QC35s but a Chinese knockoff that didn't function. The biggest giveaway was that the charging cable was physically attached to one side of the headphones. It also didn't come with an owners manual or travel case. The Bluetooth didn't work either. I called Bose directly and they confirmed none of their headphones have a permanently mounted charging cable.

Figured I would let people know considering the item just went on sale and this happened to me last week 5/30/19

author: Dan Olson
title: No mic mute and can't walk more than a few feet from laptop before losing signal
content: I wanted an "upscale" set of headphones for use at work, mostly conference calls but some music listening as well. While these sound okay, the lack of a microphone mute makes them unusable. I checked forums and some people said they could push the volume up and down buttons briefly for mic mute but that didn't work on these even after firmware updates. I also can't walk more than about 10 feet from my laptop without the sound breaking up. I have a $30 set of MPOW's that I can walk all the way across my house with crystal clear audio. Returning and would not buy again.

author: Shane
title: Fantastic.
content: When I first turned them on I was shocked at how well they wash out all background noises. It was almost like turning an off switch for everything near by. They won't cancel out high pitch noises like an intercom or a loud pitch dog yelp but it does muffle it well. The battery life is another huge plus when it comes to travelling. I have gone for 8 hours of flying plus a 2 hour layover while watching movies non stop and the battery only went to 60% after being fully charged. The sound quality is very clear and has some bass, no award winning bass here. I also use them in my car which can top out at 120 decibels and they do a very very good job at keeping that noise down while listening to music. They may crackle a tiny bit at wide open throttle and 120 decibels but I have never experienced a better pair of headphones.

author: Aris
title: Best active noise-cancelling on-ear headphones money can buy
content:
I am a headphones and Hi-Fi enthusiast or audiophile if you will. This review is for casual and audiophile users.

Sound:
Very good sound 4/5 stars. Extended tight bass (that can be dialled down via the app at will), good definition, good musicality. Voices and single instruments don't sound "real" but music comes out with great enjoyment and overall rhythm and warm pleasant tones. You can listen to music for hours in these. They never sound like "you're really there at a live venue" - like better and more expensive headphones do - but 99% of people don't care and won't notice. You buy these headphones because they do everything rather well, and have active noise cancelling. Tip: If you really want the best sounding headphones around this price and you MUST have noise cancelling check-out the Shure 535 in-ear headphones which have far superior sound in every way and better (alas passive) noise-cancelling. Bottom line: these headphones are best value, just before diminishing returns where more money buys you fine improvements, whereas less money buys you significantly worst headphones.

My experience: Music and Hi-Fi fanatic for 20 years. Own multiple DAC's all the way up to $2000 devices, multiple $500+ headphones which I used to compare these headphones against streaming both Spotify as well as lossless Tidal.

Comfort:
These truly are the most comfortable over-ear headphones you can buy. They are light, fit beautifully with materials that feel soft and welcome to your head. Hours of easy listening await you. If comfort and noise cancelling is a priority for you look no further.

Noise Cancelling:
Myth buster first: You don't need active noise-cancelling. Passive in-ear headphones have better passive noise cancelling. The reason why you buy active noise-cancelling is either because you prefer to have on-ear rather than in-ear headphones, OR because you like to turn the noise-cancelling off some times. If you don't mind smaller and more travel-friendly in-ear headphones and don't mind having passive noise-cancelling on at all times. Do try a pair of Shure 535's before committing to on-ear headphones. All that said, Noise-cancelling on the bose is Very good 8/10.

Other:
Battery, connectivity, features, functionality are all top notch. You will not find better.

Overall I give these 5/5 stars not because they are the best headphones in the world - they are not. But they are the best on-ear noise-cancelling headphones in the world, and if you don't care for "astoundingly clear audiophile grade sound" - these are best value for the price.

Should you buy them? Yes. You will not regret it. You either know what professional and audiophile headphones and DACs sound like, in which case you wouldn't be looking at these headphones OR you don't know that you need better headphones yet, so these are the best headphones you can currently appreciate, and a great way to step into the world of great sound.

author: pp
title: Phenomenal Sound Quality & Comfort
content:
After trying out a few other headphone purchases that left me unhappy, I finally decided to try Bose after glowing recommendations from friends. I had resisted due to the lackluster physical appeal of Bose compared to other brands, but I can't express how much better the sound quality, comfort and noise cancellation were with Bose. These headphones are outstanding!

I actually couldn't believe how much more comfortable the earpads were than any other pair of headphones I've tried at this price point (e.g. Sennheiser HD1). Wearing the Bose for 2+ hours left me forgetting I was even wearing them and I completely tuned out my surroundings.

Accessorywise, the travel case is a good size for travel with interior pockets for cables - I was hoping an AC USB adapter would be included but I ended up using a spare one.

The physical UI on the exterior of the headphones makes pairing and powering on/off incredibly intuitive with a slider button and the voice instructions always let you know the battery life and to which device it's paired.

All in all, Bose really exceeded my expectations and lives up to all the hype. Seriously, worth every penny!

author: KimVT
title: Alexa is NOT built in!
content:
I ordered the Bose QuietComfort 35 Series II with Alexa Control. It says it is built in... I thought that would mean that when I turn it on it would have Alexa on the headphones automatically. Alexa is not on the headphones.
  What I had to do...Download the Bose Connect App. on my phone. Then, Install the apps firmware. Sync my headphones to it. Then download the Alexa app onto my phone. Update it. Then sync my address book to Alexa app so I can make calls. It seems I need to have my phone with me and on every time I want to use Alexa....so it's not built in....You must download 2 separate apps on your phone in order to get this feature.
FYI- My first shipment of headphones I opened the Bose Connect App and all that appeared was the Google Assistant. So I called Amazon tech support who wanted to say it was defective. Well the second shipment arrived last night and so when I opened it up to find all the same issues I was greatly disappointed.
I also called Bose who gave me instructions that weren't quite right either. I believe, this issue is Amazon not Bose. There are no instructions on how to do all of this...we found a website- digitaltrends.com that gave a more complete set of instructions.
I want to be clear. My issue with the headphones is the Alexa feature. The noise cancellation is superb. I've used it today to listen to music and books- it is a wonderful listening experience. My 3 stars are more for the sound quality & lack of sound quality. And if Alexa was "built in" I'd give it 4 or maybe 5 stars.
  So Amazon you did not live up to my expectations for this purchase.

author: Virginia Booklover
title: Don't use if you're worried about someone sneaking up on you!!
content:
I purchased this to use at home as well as while commuting and travelling. At home, I've had to learn to leave one earcup off the ear - otherwise a family member can walk into the room behind me and prepare an entire meal without my even noticing. That's how well the noise reduction works in a quiet-ish environment.

I used an upcoming plane trip as the excuse to buy this, though I really wanted it for my daily commute on the subway.  It did the job nicely on the plane - the noise of the engines was reduced to a fairly dull roar, and I was able to enjoy my audiobook.

It makes a HUGE difference on the subway - before, I couldn't listen to a book or music without having to crank the volume of my earbuds to dangerous levels, and even then I missed words in almost every sentence. The noise reduction is sufficient that I can hear my audiobooks quite well without deafening myself.  I've played with the noise reduction levels to see how much it cuts out and it is substantial. I never want to commute again without these.

Why is it only 4 stars then? Well, I had hopes of using it with my Windows 7 computer, but it refused to pair. Googling it suggests this is a nearly-universal problem. I never did succeed in getting the two to talk. I now have a Windows 10 machine and it  is working much better. I did have one day where I had to reset the headset to get it to talk to both the laptop and my phone - not sure what the issue was, but basically it kept behaving as if I'd powered it off and on, then connecting VERY briefly to the phone.... then a minute later, repeating the cycle. The total reset seemed to solve that.

The sound quality seems fine. I don't listen to much music, and the times I do, I haven't noticed any issues with, say, the bass quality, so I didn't rate it for that  The battery life seems decent. It's heaver than an old-style headset, of course, but it's quite comfortable to wear for hours.

author: Andrew S.
title: Bluetooth Nightmare
content:
Updated: Increased from 2 stars to 3 stars. The quality is magnificent and when paired with 1 device, seems to work well without any problems. The multi-pairing is still a huge issue and should never be advertised by Bose as a premium feature. I use these routinely for travel and for listening to music, but simply cannot recommend them for professional use.

I loved my Bose QC2's from way back when, and was really excited to order this pair since I have been saving up to go wireless for some time down.

I am disappointed. Not in the sound quality or noise cancellation at all, as of course Bose is the top of the line.

It is the bluetooth software. These things cannot stay connected to my devices (2016 13" Macbook Pro and iPhone X). I bought these to use in a business setting as I work from home and have video conferences with my colleagues everyday. I have had nothing but issues so far. I want SO desperately to like these, as when they are paired to a single device and not being used for phone calls, they are magnificent. But that is not the function as advertised, and its not what I expect from the top of the line headphones that cost $350.

I have been in meetings with clients where my audio completely stops working and I need to exit the Google Meet window and completely restart Chrome. Not to mention, when connected to two devices, if one of the other devices makes a sound of any type (notification sounds, music playing) the audio lags and drops out, then comes back sped up and then drops out again, rinse repeat. There are even times when I have my phone in my hand, and the headphones will just randomly unpair with them. At this point, I have owned them for 2 weeks and I am bitterly disappointed.

If I got a lemon pair, I'd love to hear from Bose to explain the situation, but from what I can see from forums online, this is not an isolated incident. If I cannot figure out how to make these work more consistently, I will be returning them and looking for an alternate brand. For shame, Bose. I am a huge fan and these are a disgrace.

author: Scott Simpson
title: Tight fitting earbuds (with inserts to match your ear size) produce the same net result without the bulk and does a better job of killing high-frequency noise from a child crying
content:
I had the previous generation Bose headphones and was looking forward to strong improvements in the sound reduction on flights... well it's the exact same when comparing them side by side, which is to say it's only okay.  Tight fitting earbuds (with inserts to match your ear size) produce the same net result without the bulk and does a better job of killing high-frequency noise from a child crying.

Bose needs to do something to reduce the bulk on their headphones. The headphone case is nice, but the old style was better -- this new version requires the ear pieces to be folded so they rub each other on the exterior plastic part (in no time I am sure these will have rub/scratch marks from storing them in their case).

Also, it may be obvious, but avoid wearing these headphones in hot environments (think florida or hawaii in the summer) -- your ears and head will sweat considerably.

author: Giraldus
title: As a cubicle dweller,  this is a sanity saver...
content:
As a cubicle dweller,  this is a sanity saver:  I was looking for something that I could use all day long (i.e.,  long battery life, confort - even while wearing spectacles - which is not a given for most over the hear headsets),  wireless to avoid the mess of yet another set of wires that gets in the way,  something that would cut off ambiant noise effectively (including next cubicle loud conversations,  off key singing colleagues,  noisy lab,  etc.) and with good excellent audio capabilities - and this is it.

There are a couple of competing products with similar specs and similar price range (e.g., Sennheiser,  Sony,  etc.) but the Bose came highly recommended by friends (and online reviewers).

Ah one handy feature is the ability to pair the headset with multiple devices,  it keeps track of two active ones,  e.g.,  the laptop and smartphone,  and will switch source seamlessly as needed.

author: ACB3344
title: Disappointed, Old Version Alexa Not pre-loaded. Not wind-tight.
content:
I intentionally ordered these, even though they were pricey, so that I would have Alexa built in. I have come to find out Amazon sent me an old version without Alexa preloaded and without the Alexa logo. I'm a big Alexa user so this was important to me. I selected these after watching the commercial for them lauding the Alexa connectivity and intentionally held off buying these until I was sure they were being issued with Alexa from Amazon.

I've struggled with Amazon for over a week with chat and emails trying to get them returned and new version issued without success. Very frustrating and disappointing.  When I tried to get the newer version from Amazon they said it wasn't possible and that I would just receive the exact same item. I'm not sure why I got a stuck with the older version and others got a new box for the same amount of money. Disappointed for sure.

I can tell from the answers of other users that they received the newer version because they talk about Alexa being pre-loaded and pressing the button being all it takes to get Alexa to work. For me it was much, much more difficult, frustrating and disappointing. It's been a pain in the backside trying to get them setup because there are no instructions in the box addressing the fact that these are the older version without Alexa pre-loaded. I finally found an article on Engadget that at least got me started in the right direction. It took me multiple attempts to get the firmware update applied because, 1. without instructions I didn't know to load the firmware update; and 2. they kept disconnecting from the source .... Ugh. After 3-4 attempts I finally got it loaded. But the frustrating experience tainted my satisfaction with this purchase.

Also, I wore them on a walk on a slightly windy day. I had to cover the headset with a hood to keep the wind noise from entering the ear covers and disrupting what I was listening to.

author: Matt Krass
title: They were fantastic when I got them, then the update broke them
content: When I first received these yesterday I was very impressed. They're very comfortable, and they sound excellent, and the noise cancelling was so good it was frankly unnerving. Then my phone prompted me to update them, and now I have the infamous 4.5.2 firmware (search the internet for QuietComfort 35 II firmware 4.5.2). Well, the noise cancelling is basically useless now, it's stuck on low, and now TV, cars, people talking all come through barely affected. I owned these for less than 24 hours and now they're useless, so I'll be sending them back. Bose is aware of this, there are several long threads on their forums, and they just insist there's no problem, they removed the ability to downgrade the firmware and they parrot the same repetitive generic "turn them off and back on" instructions that do nothing. Would not recommend these to anyone.

author: Roge213
title: So nice, I bought them twice 😄
content:
Wow! This thing AMAZING!! For years I have been resisting the urge to buy noise cancelling headphones because I thought they were just a fad. The latest gizmo. Also, Bose was pretty much the only game in town, and the price was outrageously high.
  Because my wife and I do our fair share of traveling, I felt it was about time to seriously reconsider my thoughts about anc headphones. After watching countless YouTube videos and reading a few reviews online about the different models of anc headphones available today, I decided to take a chance and go with the Bose Quietcomfort 35 II.
  I bought 2 pairs. One black (mine), and one silver (wife's). I was instantly impressed with the sound quality and the effectiveness of the noise cancelling feature. Sounds are full and balanced; nothing really overwhelming (no over the top bass). And oh so comfortable. Just make sure you adjust the headband to fit your head properly. I've worn them for 8-10 hours continually for the past few days, and they never hurt my head or ears. My wife loves her Bose headphones too, and she's very picky about everything I give her. I can vacuum the house, use power tools, make as much noise as I want, and she's no longer bothered.
  The pressure other reviewers feel in their ears are true for me as well. But I just yawn or do any of the usual things a person does to relieve that airline cabin pressure in the ears. Eventually my ears become acclimated and I don't feel the pressure anymore. I set the smart button on the left ear cup to control the noise cancellation level because I can call up my Google Assistant by holding down the play/pause button on the right ear cup. So I don't need two buttons for that feature.
  All in all, we love our new anc headphones. We use them almost everyday to listen to music, watch TV, or just to block out any annoying ambient noises. We have an upcoming trip in a couple of weeks and I can hardly wait to try them on the flight. Glad I finally got these.
  Almost forgot to mention this. The shipping was super fast. Ordered it on a Tuesday, and it arrived on my doorstep the very next day. That's another reason for me to love these things. Thanks Amazon!

author: Nate Wilson
title: Make Sure to Mute ALL Notifications
content:
I used to love these headphones, but since about June of 2018, any time that my phone receives a notification I get a FULL VOLUME BLAST of static/white noise in my ears in place of an actual notification sound. I honestly think it has damaged my hearing and I simply cannot use these headphones any longer. I have researched the issue thoroughly on Bose forums and the company provides no work arounds or desire to improve the issue. Some users have worked around the issue by manually turning off the notification sounds on each app so that they don't get their eardrums blown out. However, as these are $350.00 headphones, Bose should fix this issue via firmware, not by expecting their own customer's to provide other customer's with workarounds.

I always thought Bose was the cream of the crop when it comes to Headphones, but from here on out I will just by the Tao Tronics Chinese Knockoffs just because Bose is such a shitty company when it comes to supporting their customers who pay way too much for their products.

End rant.

author: Martin Quevedo
title: overall top quality headphones
content:
The noice canceling feature is really nice. Although, since it is considered the best of all, I expected more. I set the noice canceling to high and I can still hear the music around. But I have to say, music is very loud (in the gym).
Another thing I notice is that when I am not playing music but noice canceling is on, i feel some discomfort in my ears, as if there was extra pressure. But noice is cancel effectively (almost)

The material used for this headphone is really great. Just all of it.

What I am not happy with is that it does not fit very well. I had another pair of headphones before (cheap ones) and they wont move during gym activities. But these move. I have to re-position them all the time.

Some thing else particularly annoying is that when i am walking or running I can hear my foot hitting the ground (very loud). This didnt happen with my previous cheap pair of headphones.

author: Will Berninger Whitewater Aviation Inc.
title: Give credit when credit is due
content:
I resisted purchasing these Bose headsets for a while since almost all of the noise reduction is from electronics and not much from passive design.
Well I finally bit the bullet and gave them a try and I have to say, Bose got it right.  Yes, not a lot of passive noise canceling but the electronic canceling is wonderful.  Even wearing a ball cap and sun glasses they cut out all of the offensive noises I expose them to.  I even tried them on my Cub Cadet Tank which is a noisy beast.  I normally use the best (passive) Peltor headsets and the Bose are better yet.
One word of caution, they are so good that you could easily forget that a piece of equipment is operating which could lead to injury.

They pair up with my phone and MP3 player immediately which is another good thing.  Sound quality is very good. I got these for the combination of sound reduction, adding music to my day and comfort.

author: Edmonds
title: Bought Two.  Both have keep disconnecting Bluetooth after 2 weeks' use
content:
For $384 each, you would think this is top-of-the-line.  I saw the many 1 star ratings and think that they guys are just overly critical.  But I was shocked that after 2 weeks of perfect use, my headsets start to disconnect by itself from my phone.  It would re-boot the connect, the headset audio would say "Bluetooth Disconnected.  Bluetooth Connected."  I cannot carry on a phone call, not a song, not anything without this continual interruptions and disconnects.  A cheap bluetooth $20 headset will lock in a connection solidly for an eternity.  But this expensive Bose is horrible on this essential feature.

Comfort, material, design, construction, performance, ... all fine.  Other than the fact that it connect connect to my device for more than a few minutes long before auto-disconnecting the bluetooth.  I search everyone on the web, but there's no solutions to be found.  There are thousands of instances of this occurring everywhere on this product.  Check out the 1-star ratings on Amazon and you'll see what I am describing here.  After 2 headsets with 100% failure, I know this is not a fluke.  This flaw is built-in and designed into the headset hardware/firmware/software.

I called Bose Tech support.  They took me through a process to turn off the headset for 30 seconds, plug it in to the charger for 5 seconds, then unplug from USB charger and turn on again. This is very rudimentary.  I have unpair, rebooted device, drained the headset battery, reloaded the Bose App, resynch to my phone many times, airplane mode, turned off bluetooth, tried on different phones, computers tablets, ... in the end, it all fails.

Bose Tech support was good, though.  They offered to replace, but I don't think that's the problem.  I just want their engineer to get all-hands-on-deck and fix this serious problem on such an expensive product.

author: ObiJuan
title: Stay away from the Bose Black Headphones QC35 II.
content: Stay away from the black set. I work from home and I am on 4 hours of conference calls a day and dont want to be tethered to phone or pc for that long so I need a comfortable, reliable and long lasting blue tooth headset for work and play. So I purchased the Black QC35 II set first to replace my Samsung Level headphones that just snapped with normal use.  Within the first week I noticed the BT connection dropping intermittently for 3-4 seconds at a time, didnt matter if the phone was in my hand or several feet away sitting on my desk. So I went thru the normal troubleshooting steps of reinstalling and updating software and no luck. I went to Bose website and checked their support forum and found that's its a known issue with no apparent fix that i have found. A customer mentioned he purchased both the black and silver set for himself and his wife and the Silver ones worked fine with no issues.  So I wasted no time and sent back the black set for a refund and purchased the silver Q35 II.  I have found that to be accurate, no issues with the Silver headphones. Now that thats out of the way.  Easy pairing with my Galaxy S8 using the Bose app.  The battery life was significantly longer with Silver Heaphones than the Black Headphones which makes no sense since the were both new. For music, the sound is fantastic, my music tastes ranges from techno Daft Punk to Metalica and everything in between except country. The reliable Blue tooth distance at least my house is acceptable but thats not a big requirement for me. The Silver Bose QC35 Series II headphones are what I expected from Bose and for the price.

author: K. westcott
title: These headphones stopped working almost immediately
content: After listening to music on these headphones for four days while at work they stopped functioning correctly.  They would restart themselves repeatedly for no reason (roughly 5 times per minute).  When they restart they're not just turning off and on again.  The  process is that a voice says "connecting to <your device name>, connected to <your device name>, battery level; <your battery level>" and then I have to go into my phone and restart the music.  Having to do this a few times per minute makes listening to music not worth the trouble.  I contacted Bose, they sent me a return label and I'm waiting for a replacement.  Hopefully my next pair will actually be usable.

author: Public Name
title: Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series II) vs Sony WH1000XM2
content:
I purchased both this Sony WH1000XM2 and the Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series II).  I am happy that I tried both because there are some big differences. The touch pad on the Sony was really nice for skipping a song on a playlist. The cups over the ear on the Sony are SMALL and the band puts a pretty tight pinch on your head. After using them for an hour it was uncomfortable. I couldn't see using these all day. The sound was excellent, bright and scintillating. For certain types of music this might be preferable. The base was not impressive. If you crank it  up, the base falls apart.
The QuietComfort 35 (Series II) as soon and I put on... I knew the Sony had go back. The larger cup on the Bose don't cramp your ear and the pads were like putting a soft pillow on your head.. so comfortable. You could wear this ALL DAY or on a long flight... in blissful comfort. The Bose have a more natural and undistored sounds compared to the Sony. The base is solid and tight all they way to the maximum volume on my phone. There is no question in my mind, or for what I need them for, that the Bose are hands down the better choice.

author: Jeffrey Wang
title: Top of the line for comfort
content:
I didn't buy these headphones through Amazon but I thought I would leave a review for these anyway.

When I was shopping for a quality pair of noise-cancelling headphones, it really came down to a few choices. Watching a lot of youtube reviews and reading a lot of online reviews, it narrowed down to choosing the Bose QC35 IIs and the Sony WH1000XM2. When it comes down to the best noise-cancelling and the best comfort, there were a lot of debates between the two. And, when choosing headphones, I think it's important to consider what you want in a pair of really expensive headphones.

For me, comfort was an absolute priority. A lot of headphones can give users wearer's fatigue and can become hot and uncomfortable after some time. When I'm using them to study or through plane rides, I wanted to make sure that whichever pair I bought would be the most comfortable.

In the end, I decided on Bose because of how light-weight they were. The Bose QC35 IIs are about 8.1oz (~230g) in weight and the Sony headphones are about 9.7oz (~275g). They might not seem like a huge difference, but that comparison is for you as a future consumer to make.

So far, wearing the QC35 IIs have given me the best wearing experience out of any of the headphones I've tried previously. I can go hours with them on without feeling much discomfort and because they are so light-weight, sometimes I forget that they're even on.

What's also great about these in particular is that these cover your entire ear. The plush for the L/R ears actually sits around your ears instead of sitting partly on your ears. When I tested the Sony headphones at Best Buy, the headphones sat partly on my ears and after ten minutes of testing them, I had the sense that they might become uncomfortable after some time. This was also one of the big reasons I chose to go with Bose instead Sony.

The active noise cancelling is one of the best on the market today and personal experience tells me that the ANC is amazing, but plenty of reviews have said that Sony either matches or beats Bose in the ANC department. Because I don't own a pair of the WH1000XM2, I can't really comment on which is better. The QC35 IIs, however, blocks out nearly all ambient noises and is a pleasure to use in noisy environments. Some have said that the ANC can give them headaches due to a cabin-like pressure attributed to the ANC. It took a day or so to adjust to the ANC and that "cabin-like pressure" and it doesn't bother me personally anymore, but so I would head to your local Best Buy or electronics store to test this for yourself. These headphones are a huge expenditure, so it's important to test whether or not this might apply to you.

Pros:
Incredibly lightweight and comfortable
Completely surrounds your ear instead of sitting partly on top of your ears
ANC is amazing that blocks out all ambient noises
20-hour battery life

Cons:
"Cabin-like pressure" that may cause headaches for some users
Sound quality may not be up to far for some audiophiles (some reviewers have noted that Sony has better sound quality)

TLDR:
If comfort is your top priority and you're not the biggest audiophile, I would absolutely recommend Bose.

author: GPN Fan
title: The sounds of Bose
content:
I purchased these headphones to replace an older Bose set. The others worked fine, but I wanted the updated features.  I have Bose in the car, in the den, the bedroom, in the office. Everywhere is Bose in my house.
I fly weekly for a total of 4 flights a week. A sturdy and good sounding set of head phones is essential. The case is great protection.
The sound is balanced with the clear sound I expected. They are not heavy and stay on my ears without being weighted down. I also use them in the office when the team gets too loud. You can still know when someone speaks to you if music is not playing. But I don’t have to have music blaring in my ears to drown them out either.
I have the silver grey ones and they look great.
Yes a little expensive. But you definitely get what you pay for.  I have zero regrets in this purchase!

author: Marco Forcone
title: A lifesaver for frequent flyers
content:
It took me a long time to pull the trigger on these given the cost... but I'm glad I did.  I've used them on several flights already and am kicking myself for not having bought them long ago.

Noise Cancellation:
They do an excellent job of cancelling the most of drone of the engine noise and most loud conversations/babies.  Operative word is "most".

Comfort
Very light and comfortable.  I wear glasses and find that the temple of the glasses is uncomfortable with the headset on, so I simply remove my glasses when wearing the headphones.

Build Quality
I don't get the sense these are rugged by any means.  That said, it's a trade off between the weight.  Personally, I would have preferred an extra ounce or two and more solid feel.  That said,  if you take good care of your toys, I don't see any issue.  The hard case that they came in protects them well when not wearing them.

Battery life seems fine.  I don't foresee any concerns on long-haul flights.  I keep the charging cable and plug in my case with them.

Headphone Jack
They come with a cable so they can be plugged into typical airline jacks for entertainment.  They do work on the proprietary airline two prong jacks (typically in premium economy or business) by plugging them in the single larger jack.

Bluetooth Pairing
Work great with my iPhones and laptop.  Which is perfect for taking work calls while at home.

author: HiDeeBug
title: Great pair of work headphones!
content:
The pair I ordered on Amazon I returned because the box was opened and they had already been paired by someone else. I ended up going to Best Buy to purchase the same model bec I didn’t want to wait for a new pair or risk getting another opened box when I paid full price for a new pair.

I wear these headphones at work as I work in an open office cube farm. These headphones are comfortable fitting over my ears, which is important because I have a lot of ear piercings (industrial, daith, tragus, helix, lobe, and upper lobe) in each of my ears. My coworkers can be loud and these help me focus on my work. Sometimes I can still hear them if I don’t have my music up very high, but I’m actually ok with the amount of noise canceling.

They last for almost 2 weeks on a single charge and I use them at least 4-6 hours each day. I know they have a mic and could use them for conf calls, but I’ve never tried them as I worry that the mic would pic up all the background noise since it isn’t a direct mic in front of my mouth.

Overall, very satisfied with my purchase (from Best Buy). I love them!

author: Mike Ransom
title: Works Great
content:
I absolutely love these. With no music playing I can barley hear things outside the headsets.  With music playing I can not hear anything other than the music.
Pros:
 - Comfortable
 - Long Battery Life, I have used them for several hours over several days without needing to recharge them
 - Great sound.  It is like having a stereo on my head.
 - Have not had any issues with them staying connected to my iPhone.

Cons:
 - I can not really thinking of any for this item.

I would recommend and would buy again.

author: Kindle Customer
title: For comfort it's Bose, for sound it's Sony.
content: I purchased the Sony headphones and the Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series II) set because the reviews were so close and I wasn't sure which ones I would like better.  While the Bose were definitely more comfortable and the case was large enough to fit the charging cord and headphone jack, the sound did not quite measure up.  I did like the on/off switch of the Bose headphones better and the Bose app, but I love the Sony headphones for the following reasons.  The sound is phenomenal...it's transforming.  I took them on a recent flight and it was like being in another world...no noisy discussions or engine noise, just a beautiful series of sounds that volleyed from one ear to the next.  It's easy to change tracks, adjust volume, or stop play by simply swiping or tapping the outside of the right earpiece.  The Sony app is fairly easy to use, too, including a way to adjust if your connection cuts in and out.  I didn't experience that with the Sony, but did with the Bose.  If I could have chosen the comfort of the Bose with the sound of the Sony (and the convenient swipe feature) I would never take them off!

author: Jim Botsford
title: Poor Bluetooth Implementation
content:
Sound and noise canceling seemed very good. However these were a nightmare to get bluetooth connected properly. My wife wanted them for the computer when working and TV in the evening. Could not get them to seamlessly switch between devices with out having to clear the bluetooth connections and starting over.

Then once connected the bluetooth kept breaking up, dropping and stuttering if she moves even 12 feet from the TV or computer. 19 dollar cheap headphones with poor sound quality work much better than this.

For this kind of money, no thank you.  Sent them back.

author: Amazon Customer
title: It keeps disconnecting on it's own even when it's fully charged. I just got this on Sunday
content: Dislike

author: Victor Hache
title: The level of comfort these provide compensates every other possible flaw
content:
I was not sure on which noise cancelling headphones to get between these and the new Sony WH-1000XM3 for me and my wife and all reviews were very vague (e.g. "which ones should you get?, well, it depends, if you like this or that buy Bose, but if you like other thinks like Sony. Useless!!). So I bought one of each and have had the chance to use them both and compare for more than a month already on a daily basis.

I must say  I was intending to like the Sony's more for their marketing gimmicks like "4x better noise cancelling and all day comfort", but I found Bose's noise cancelling still good enough vs the Sony and the level of comfort on the Bose has not real point of comparison. They are just very enjoyable to wear for long hours, while the Sony tend to warm up the ears and feel heavy after a few hours.

If you are still undecided between Sony and Bose like I was, I really recommend going for the Bose QC35ii.

author: S. Howard
title: I bought these solely for noise cancellation
content: I bought these Bose headphones solely for the purpose of noise cancellation.  I work at a desk in a room that has a very large overhead fan that goes on and off all day.  The noise is so bad that I found myself getting stressed and literally putting my hands over my ears.  The headphones are absolutely awesome at canceling out that noise.  I wear them virtually all day at work, and I can barely tell when the fan is on versus when it's off.  They are very comfortable, and my ears don't get hot as some other people mentioned.  The part that goes over my ears is actually big enough that my earlobes don't get crushed, which was a problem with the last headphones I tried.  I also have a big head, and these aren't too tight.  Overall extremely comfortable.  My only complaint is that they require being connected to a cell phone in order to work.  So if I forget to bring my cell phone to work -- no headphones.  If my cell phones dies -- no headphones.  I can't understand whey they couldn't make these so that the noise cancellation would work regardless of whether I had my cell phone with me.  In fact you should be able to use the wire to connect them to the computer and listen to something there without a cell phone as well.  The only feature that should require a phone is talking on the phone.  It doesn't make sense that they are useless without one.  These would be five stars -- ten stars!! -- if I could just use them without the phone.  Still very happy with these headphones though, would definitely buy again.

author: John A
title: Stop working just after limited warranty expires.
content: So here is a classic case of wait until the warranty runs out to see if the product has any quality. Bought the QC35 II December 2017 and have loved them - I've had some minor issues with glitchy sound every now and then but would usually be fixed by repairing. However, yesterday, turned on the headphones as normal - connected to my Macbook Pro - no sound. I thought - hmm thats weird - followed the troubleshooting guide, reset the headphones, repaired the bluetooth etc. Still no dice. I went through this process 3 times, tried another device and eventually gave up - I plugged them in to my computer. Worked fine though the cable was a touch sensitive. This morning - won't even produce sound with the cable connected. For a $350 product Bose is marketing a scam - and when you go to try and get support they have the audacity to try and sell you a 'discounted' new pair for $250. Shameful marketing practices and poor customer service. Very disappointed. In all honesty I cannot recommend these headphones.

author: Richard Myers
title: Don't Update the Firmware (don't install the Bose app)
content:
I really wanted to like these headphones.  I've had other 'cheaper' ANC headphones, and while the ANC worked OK, I kept hearing how Bose ANC was the best of the best.  So I upgraded.  Or so I thought.  To be fair, the ANC is superior to my Cowin or Nakamichi headphones.

I installed the Bose app right away, as instructed by the Docs that came with the Bose QC 35 II headphones.  That was a mistake, apparently.  The app immediately installs version 4.5.2 firmware without user consent.  There are many complaints about this firmware on the Bose community forums, and elsewhere (Reddit) and Bose claims they cannot find any issues with the firmware (since June '19).  Most of the posts complain of ANC problems created by the update.  Since my headphones were updated right at the get go, I couldn't compare before and after effects.

I had 3 (+1) issues with the headphone (I don't know whether they were caused by the update or not):
1. There was a very annoying 'distorted clipping' when listening to certain meditation music.  I didn't do an exhaustive study of whether the noise was added to other music.  But it was very apparent, and easily discernible by my old ears, and did not exist in other headphones (I went back and forth). I'm not the only one complainting about this issue...
2. The sound was tinny compared to my Cowin E7 Pro headphones.  The Cowin's produce a much richer sound, especially at the low end.
3. The Bluetooth call operation didn't work well.  If I dialed a number while connected, the call didn't automatically attach to the headphones.  I'd have to mess with poking the speaker icon and the BT icon on the phone dialer to eventually get it to connect (Samsung Note 9).  Same with receiving calls.  My other BT headsets just work.  Every time.
4.  Build quality seemed cheap.  Though I don't know how well they would hold up over the long haul.
