I will say that they were a bit smaller and lighter than my Cowin, which could be good as long as they hold up.  The control placement and operation were the best of any BT headphone I've owned.

So why pay $300 for headphones that added distortion, tinny sound, and problematic BT integration?  I didn't.  I sent them back and will continue searching for a company that gets the ANC right, along with the other important bits.

author: @youcantseeme
title: I wanted to try this as I heard it was more comfortable than the Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2 The sony ...
content:
Ehhhhh
Its over $300 and doesn't do Apt X Codec for bluetooth audio or Apt X HD
It only does AAC I think?

If you want to use a standard 3.5 inch to 3.5-inch stereo cable to listen to an audio source, you can't--for some reason, this has a 2.5-inch input....in 2018.  Huh?

I wanted to try this as I heard it was more comfortable than the Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2
The sony has a bunch of Bluetooth codecs Aptx Aptx HD AAC LDAC and includes a good 3.5 inch stereo cable if you want to use a wired input--plus it has better noise canceling and battery life than the bose QC 35

I checked a lot of reviews on youtube and online, nobody mentioned the lack of Apt X codecs.  For $350 it should do a better job.

author: Ken in Boston
title: Love these quiet, beautiful sounding headphones.
content: I love the bluetooth function, and that they can pair simultaneously with 2 devices (have had no problem with this). They really do have beautiful sound, and NC function is great. The cable for use with airplane screens is essential, and easily replaced if lost (no need to buy the expensive cable from Bose, they are readily available online). They are large, and if I'm wearing them around my neck (ie, not using them while walking thru airport or taking a break on plane) they can feel a bit annoying or cumbersome. But that same size covers the ears beautifully. Battery is great. No complaints.

author: Joseph Murphy
title: Failure out of box. Audio cuts out
content:
Received item on 10JAN2019

I've had nothing but positive experiences with Bose products over the past ten years or so. Unfortunately although the QC35 II has great noise canceling and cool features, the one thing it needed to do, which is play uninterrupted music, it failed at. Could not get through one song without 2-3 split second "cutouts". I reset the device, firmware was up-to-date, reconnected the device and found again that music playback was cutting out for a split second again. Tried a colleague's pair of QC32 II wireless headphones with my iPhone and did not experience the same issue.

Sounds like Bose has a batch of lemons. Might want to do more research than I did to see if Bose has resolved the issue. Returned the item same day I got it. Hopefully they'll get their act together and sort this issue out. I just don't have the patience for it.

author: Wayne W.
title: Easy to use and comfortable
content:
These headphones sound great, are extremely comfortable, and easily pair with my iPhone and laptop.  I typically use them on flights in lieu of earbuds that provide no background noise cancelation.  I liked the headphones so much I bought a second pair for my wife.  Highly recommend.

This is a 5-star product but gave it 4-stars on noise reduction because I could hear some background sounds.  All that said, it effectively cancelled out most of the background noise and i’ll Freely admit that I don’t really know what the criteria is that would make any headset a 5-star product so it’s possible that this one is as good as anything out there.

author: Greatjon Umber
title: Quality and comfort are extraordinary, but bluetooth connectivity, app, and firmware issues abound
content:
The sound quality, build quality, and features of this set of headphones are pretty much unmatched even considering its relatively steep price. While it might be a bit awkward putting these on if you've never used a pair of noise-cancelling cans before (it feels a little like your ears have to pop), you quickly get used to it. The sound quality is phenomenal; I use these mostly for playing video games in addition to music, and they're simply unmatched by any other set of headphones I have, including my pair of Audio Technica studio monitors, and a pair of Sennheiser "beater" phones that I use while traveling and such. Though this is to be expected considering the price of the Bose is far more than those other pairs. The bass rings low, highs are crisp, and midrange is full. Zero complaints, but I'm no audiophile, so if you're looking for an in-depth review you'll have to look elsewhere.

Being a gamer, I spend quite a few hours-long sessions with these on. My Audio Technicas had a nasty habit of really hurting my left ear, leaving soreness and a red mark if I tried to use them for more than just a couple of hours at a time. The Bose comfort, by comparison, is astronomically better. I've used these for a number of 8-9 hour sessions (don't judge me, I pay my taxes) and I've NEVER felt any discomfort -- Not once. They are supremely crafted for comfort.

I do have a few complaints, though. The added cost to ship this product with Google Assistant/Alexa functionality is completely lost on me because I don't use either service. In addition to this, having the headphones remain unusable while charging from the USB cable really hurts utility for me. They're usable with the power on and the auxiliary cable attached to your phone or PC and drawing power from there, but the battery still slowly drains in this mode. Having an nondetachable battery cell built into the body of the phones bodes unwell for future-proofing; this is basically the same shady built-in obsolescence that cell phone manufacturers are using to force people to upgrade sooner, and it stinks. At the moment, the battery lasts for quite a while (I can go for nearly 2 full days before requiring recharge), but if this battery loses its robustness over the next couple of years, then I'll never buy another because it's just not worth it at a $300-350 price range for the headphones to die every couple of years due to a battery that isn't built with the same longevity as the headphones themselves are. My cabled Audio Technicas come close to this sound quality, cost $200 cheaper, and have been kicking for 10 years. So if the Bose doesn't give me as long of a lifespan I'll happily go back to a set of cabled cans, sore left ear and all.

Jan 16 2019 Edit: In the previous few months of use I've experienced significant Bluetooth connectivity issues that have caused me to knock a star off my prior rating. I haven't been all that happy with the Bose Connect software which, while a stylish app to look at, feels like it sacrifices easy functionality in order to appear more stylish.

The headphones regularly have issues connecting to my work laptop, which is only a couple of years old, and also to my brand new phone, to which they regularly lose connection for no apparent reason (pictured). Another problem is that sometimes, in the middle of use, they will revert to an odd mode in which I can hear myself, as if I were recording from the microphone, with all other sound distorted. The only fix for this is a complete restart, after which they will no longer receive sound from my laptop without my restarting Windows. Since the headphones lack USB connectivity, and aux cable connection has noticeably poorer sound quality than Bluetooth connection does, this has become a significant issue, as you can imagine.

I can't help but feeling Bose pushed Bluetooth first and foremost, to the neglect of everything else. Maintaining the same sound quality of USB connection, or aux connection, should have been trivial, however the headphones lack it. And I warrant that a severe enough issue to knock a star off my initial rating.

At the risk of sounding like an old man yelling at a cloud: If you're going to force me to use Bluetooth connectivity to get the best sound quality, you better make Bluetooth damned reliable (and it hasn't been). Otherwise just give me a wired connection any day of the week. Bluetooth wireless is just a nice utility; I want good sound quality and comfort first and foremost. If you're similar to me in this aspect, then maybe these headphones are not for you.

Feb 6 2019 Edit: After several weeks of experiencing severe headaches, I finally narrowed it down to Bose's Active Noise Cancellation as the cause after some extensive googling and realizing that many others experience the same headaches as I do when using the ANC included in these headphones. I have no idea why it gives me such a terrible headache, but I was getting it almost every day until I began turning off noise cancellation each time I used the headphones. Normally I wouldn't hold such a subjective complaint against the product, but a significant problem is that these headphones don't save your setting when you turn them off. This means that each and every single time I turn on the headphones to use them, I have to log in to the app, wait for it to load and connect, then navigate the menu to turn off Active Noise Cancellation. This may not seem like a major issue, but trust me, when you're doing it several times every day, it becomes an annoyance extremely quickly. It's something that should be so simple to fix, too.

In addition to this, whenever you use the headphones with the cable, all of the buttons become non-functional. Since the headphones start up with noise cancellation active every single time and the buttons don't respond in cabled mode, you can never turn off noise cancellation. This basically means that I will never be able to use cabled mode without getting a severe headache. Thanks, Bose.

I have added photos, too, so you can see these headphones have held up very well with daily use. Build quality is indeed impressive.

3-Months Conclusion: These are still great headphones with supreme build and sound quality, but there are significant issues involved that I would not have expected when paying $350 for a pair of headphones. I would expect a higher level of polish when spending so much money. Buying these did in fact turn out to be a mistake, despite their positive aspects, and I do regret my purchase after a few months of use.

author: Rostam
title: 1-year review of Bose QC35ii
content:
Frustrated. After having these headphones for an entire year I'm just feel like I was completely ripped off.
The headphones have great audio quality and all the fantastic features that is mentioned above. However, these headphones have serious issues when it comes to the audio skipping when using the bluetooth wireless mode. It's not a fluke issue with my headphones, this is a consistent issue with these headphones. If you google "Bose QC35 skipping" you will see a multitude of message boards of people spanning for the past 4 years with these same issues. There is a rabbit hole of forums dedicated to shoddy bluetooth quality of these headphones. I was unaware of this before purchasing these headphones. These headphones are VERY expensive and for the price they should at the very least play CONSISTENT AUDIO! They worked fine for a 8 months. Then a I noticed many major audio issues. Sometimes the audio wouldn't sync with the video I was watching on youtube, phone call would have in and out connection, music would begin to skip. I was so busy at the time unfortunately I did not have time to remedy the issue. Now there is nothing I can do about it as my warranty is up. I really wanted to like these headphones. Please take this a warning, if you buy these headphones they may work great for the first 6 months- 1 year, maybe slightly longer. However, they take a huge turn for the worst after the warranty is up. If I had the money I would buy the Sony WH1000XM3. Many customers on the Bose message board got fed up with the customer service representatives giving them the run-around and bought the WH1000XM3, and came back months and years later saying how they still work just as great as the day they bought them. I just wish I would have known that prior to purchasing these headphones. Please take heed of this review.

author: Phil
title: Has 2.5mm audio port, not 3.5mm, audio cable has no microphone. Not worth it
content:
- This is contradicts to official spec on the web site. The cable included does not have microphone, so essentially wired use is just for listening not for talking.
- Can only connect to 2 devices max!
- The noise cancellation is average, not much better than others on the market.
- Phone call quality was very poor - my $35 ear buds do much better job with calls.
- Battery indication is inconsistent - first it says 100%, literally five minutes later it says 80%.
- Also when charging cable is plugged in Bluetooth turns off.

150 would be fair price for this. Not worth $350 at all. Planning to return it and try something else.

author: noknots
title: My first ones disappeared and I only used them at hospital
content: This is a replacement and we haven't got them out to charge nor my new iPod (they are being discontinued).  I spend 12 hours in the hospital getting an immune infusion, they put Benadryl in me so I'm groggy and with the QE head set it blocks out most of the noise so I rest a lot but it still lets to hear the nurses come in and I have the sound low.  I made special bags to carry my stuff and can't believe they disappeared.  I always leave in the pocket in the bag until next infusion and we searched the house inside and out and couldn't find them, called the hospital and I didn't leave them behind, suspicious house cleaner I think

author: Ryan
title: BEST TECH PURCHASE EVER!!
content:
Just for reference, I have already purchased a pair of Beats Solo and Studio. I experienced lots of discomfort with both of those pairs of headphones. I decided to splurge a little after reading review of these being best in class. Very very expensive, but definitely worth it. I could wear these for hours and hours and still be comfortable besides it getting a little hot, which comes with all over the ear headphones. Very good connectivity and keep multiple connections with different devices. The app allows you to do change the sensitivity of the noise cancelling as well. Perfect pair of headphones for any type of travel. My only gripe about these are that the cushions, although very comfortable do wear quite quickly. You can purchase a replacement set for $30 which can be user installed. Overall, I would highly recommend this product.

Update: After exactly 1 yr 2 months and 1 week, this happened to the cushions. Be conscious that if you are buying this for heavy use, multiple hours a day everyday, be aware its cushions tend to tear up. You can get new cushions for $30-$40, but this shouldn't be expected when paying $350+ on headphones.

author: Ruby
title: Awesome listening experience
content: Great pair of noise canceling headphones by Bose. The Quiet comfort 35 (series II) are the best and no other can compare. Sure,a bit pricey but if you’re looking to have a non interrupted quiet time while listening to your favorite music or enjoying a good movie from your favorite device this headphones are worth it. Downloading the Bose Connect app adds to the listening experience like never before with more options to choose from to optimize and personalize your Q35 headphones. So,for on the go or just listening at home at your own leisure this noise cancellation headphones will deliver a unique experience second to none.

author: Gary Tasky
title: Quiet and comfortable
content: I've only had the Bose qc35 for 2 days.  It was very easy to sync with my iphone x. The controls are simple and easy to learn.  Charged up in no time (came at 50% powered).  COMFORTABLE.  Lightweight. I don't see a purpose for an iphone owner to use the Google Assist app - the middle button on the right gets you to Siri - meets my needs.  Phone calls - CLEAR.  Person on the other end had no complaint.  I saw some reviews that were negative on the phone calls. Not for me.  The noise cancellation is perfect - IF a truck was screeching down the street to hit me, I'd hear enough to get out of the way. I work in a very noisy part of town and walking around with the Bose on full noise cancellation was terrific.  Sound quality - Good, not the greatest ever but I think playing with the equalizer on my phone should help that along. All in all - 5 star.

author: Jordan
title: Great Headphones... Save For One Glaring Issue
content:
I just started using the Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series II) wireless headphones, and generally speaking, they are pretty great. My intended use is to try to drown out the background noise in my open-plan workspace. They do an okay with human voices- certainly better than my old earbuds. They are relatively comfortable, and the sound quality is very clear.

That said, my main issue is with the port for the audio cable. It is EXTREMELY particular, and I have to wiggle it around to actually get it to get both ears to work. This is rather disappointing for a brand new pair of $350 headphones. My PC does not have Bluetooth, so I am sort of stuck using the cable. My ultimate concern is that the jack will wear out fast. I will give the headphones a few more days of trial, but there is a real chance that I will end up returning them if things get worse.

author: Anonymous Identity
title: Good Headphones
content:
They're great. It comes down to these or the Sony WH-1000xM3 (watch videos to compare the two)

Here is my analysis

Bose QC 35 II:

Pro's:

Good Sound quality
Good Noise canceling
Good aesthetical appeal
Decent Battery life
Comfortable****
Multi Point Bluetooth Pairing**

Cons:

-Sound Quality while amazing doesn't beat Sony's WH x1000M3
-Noise Cancellation is much better in Sony - first time ever but Sony did it
-Aesthetics better on Sony
-Battery life better on Sony
-Newer Bluetooth on Sony
-USB C Rapid charging technology for Sony
-Sony also gives you a much better carrying case with pockets for all the wires (this is a small thing but when you're paying close to $300 small things matter too)

With this review some may say why not buy the Sony's but the Sony's have their own set of issues: 1) You can not multi point connect with bluetooth. This is not the same thing as pairing. The Sony's can be paired with 8 devices and it will remember them so you do not have to configure it every time. However, if you're using your headphones with your laptop and you have a phone call coming in, you can't simply answer the phone call and expect to hear them and talk to them on your headphones. You will have to disconnect the bluetooth from the laptop and then activate the bluetooth on the phone - this may sound like a trivial thing but when you're working and you use your headphones all day this gets a bit annoying. 2) The Sony's get uncomfortable around your ears after a couple of hours and your ears feel sweaty and that doesn't happen with the Bose. 3) The Sony's have a touchpad on the right ear cup instead of buttons but when it's cold outside, the condensation creates a "phantom touch" therefore skipping your songs at time - so if you use your headphones outside and it gets cold in your area this is something to consider. 4) The voice quality via microphone (if you do a lot of phone calls) isn't the best for the Sony's.

Both are great but you need to evaluate your needs and wants and see what works for you - the price is similar for both. The Sony WH x1000M4 were supposed to come out at IFA this year in September but they did not and the new Bose Headphones do not really live up to their $400 cost or its predecessor the Bose QC 35 II. I hope this helped. There is unfortunately no real winner but you decide based off of this and watch videos and read other reviews as well

author: C. brown
title: best ever
content:
this is best head phone I have ever owned.....  Light and very user friendly
you will love them.  it works flawlessly

I searched the internet and have seen various prices My only disappointment with the 35ii is that the audio jack is not the standard 3.5 mm (1/8 inch) style that we have known and loved for about 50 years. Instead, the phones have a 2.5 mm jack. I did not see this noted in any of the many reviews that I read---they all mention a standard audio connection. The phones come with a cable that plugs into the 2.5 mm jack and provides a standard 3.5 mm plug on the other end. But for the life of me I cannot even guess why a 3.5 mm wasn't used on the phones themselves so that any standard cable could be used. So if wired connection is important to you be advised that you may wantto buy an additional (more robust and longer) adapter cable, and I do see some on Amazon. Apparently the smaller jack is used on other headphones as well. But why? Makes no sense to me.

author: Fabian
title: Do Not buy! Firmware issues.
content: These were great when I first bought them in 2018. But unfortunately they are trash after the latest update. I started to have a problem with the headphones and that problem was that the headphones would not shut off after switching them to off. The headphones would automatically turn back on after 10 seconds without the button being toggled. I researched online about the issue and it turns out it’s a very common problem after the new update. It seems there hasn’t been a fix for a long time now. Save your money! I’m never buying Bose products again.

author: gmolony
title: Inferior Bluetooth
content: I've been using noise cancelling Bose headsets since the 90's and they are excellent.  This is my first pair of Bluetooth and I am having the opposite experience with these. They are  difficult  to pair and have an extremely short range. With a direct line of sight a max range of 15' if there is a wall or door blocking line of sight the bluetooth fails. I have two other inexpensive $49 & $79 bluetooth headsets that out perform these. Very disappointed in these especially considering the price.

author: Stephen Crewdson
title: Very comfortable until you hear music from them
content:
I was very disappointed in the sound quality from these. I have had many pairs of headphones and ear buds from Bose and these are simply not up to par. The best way I can describe it is they sound “hollow.”  The sound is what I would expect from a pair I pick up from the drug store for $19.99, in a pinch.

The reviews from practically every trusted site said they are very close to the Sony competitors for sound quality whilst being more comfortable. I can’t say for sure because I haven’t heard the Sony WH1000m3 cans but I hope they sound far better than these or else wireless cans are still just garbage. I find that the Bose SoundSport earbuds have far superior sound to these at a much lower price.

Comfort was excellent and noise canceling was very good. Bluetooth worked flawlessly as well. However, I cannot countenance paying $350 for headphones, the sound from which makes me frown.

author: AllThatJazz
title: How much is peace worth?
content:
Other than being grossly overpriced, they are decent headphones. Highs are bla, midrange lifeless, bass not tight, that’s what you want for extended use or you will get fatigue.  I fall asleep wearing these no problem.

The electronics and app work without issue using iOS.

If the great noise cancelling is worth an extra $175, get these.

author: Brandie
title: SO GOOD I ALMOST LOST A COOKIE
content:
These were great!  My only complaint is that they might be TOO good at canceling noise.  I recently wore them the plane ride to Italy.  I put them on to take a nap and woke up an hour later with drool down my face and a cold cookie on my tray.  I somehow slept through the warm cookie distribution, but luckily the lady beside me was looking out for my best interest and grabbed me a cookie. THANKS A LOT, BOSE.

.... would recommend 10/10.

author: mdo_01
title: Solid excellence I have come to expect from Bose
content: I have used a set of QC 25's for years.  I love the comfort.  I love the audio quality.  I love the noise cancelation function as compared to some others I have checked out.  (Not extensive research by any means....)  Would be 5 stars but for one thing.  The cable that came with it is flimsy compared to the QC25's cable.  I know it's less important since we have bluetooth functionality.  I play a digital piano using headphones.  The delay with the bluetooth is enough to force me to use the cable.  (As it happens, I have a spare good one.)  It's just not up to the quality that I expect (and PAY FOR) with Bose.

author: Will Dunn
title: Best sounding headphones!
content: WOW WOW WOW!!! I never realized how much I have been compromising my listening experience until I purchased these Bose headphones. Very rich and clean sounds! The Bose connect app makes a great companion in operating the controls and adding the Google Assistant adds to the enjoyment and convenience of accessing information. The noise canceling feature actually works very well for me. The noise canceling feature doesn’t noticeably detract or diminish the sound quality in anyway in my experience with these headphones.

author: mathew
title: Not the same Bose quality of old
content: I've had them for six weeks. They started having random crazy loud static which can't be safe. They also start pulsing, even if you aren't listening to anything. It is a second of audio and a second of silence continuously. This is the 2nd Bose product I've bought in two years that have left me disappointed.  The brand means nothing these days. Buy a $40 pair and get the same results.

author: DayumWright
title: Amazing headphones!
content:
I previously had the corded headphones and I really loved the sound quality but the cord just gets really annoying.  I fly once a month, so it’s sooo nice to have that freedom when walking through the airport.  I really enjoy the fact that these headphones are rechargeable, I didn’t have a problem with the battery on my previous, but seeing that I can just plug in at the end of the night makes it very convenient.  The sound quality is obviously phenomenal, that’s why we pay the $$ for Bose products.  Noise cancellation I’d say is not as great as my previous corded ones, but still better than anything else i’ve tried.  When I found out there was an app, I was like WTF? But the app is pretty useful.  Being able to connect to two devices at once is really cool. I can connect to my phone and my computer while I work so I don’t miss any notifications.

Cons:
With all that good, there are a few things that would make these headphones perfect.  1. It would be nice to have play/pause, skip, and restart capabilities directly on the headphone.  2. When I take a call, I lose the noise cancellation capability and I can hear what’s going on in the background which gets a little distracting.  Even with this said, I’d highly recommend these for anyone looking.  Spend the extra $ and get the best quality, it's definitely worth it!

author: S. Pemble
title: worth every penny
content: My son recommended these headphones but they were *far* more expensive than I was willing to spend, but when I got an unexpected bonus at work the first thing I thought of was rewarding myself with these; the moment I used them I was absolutely stunned. I told my husband "It's like I've never heard music before!", and when he tried them he understood. Beyond that I don't know what to say; the battery life is fantastic. They're easy to use because the switches are positioned so well and easy to identify with my fingertips. They are profoundly comfortable. If you can afford them, don't hesitate!!

author: D. Cap
title: LOVED them until they made me sick
content: If you’re looking for the BEST noise canceling headphones with all the comfort you’d expect from $350, then this is where you stop and buy. However, if you’ve ever been prone to car sickness, Disneyland rides or any type of motion illness, I would pause before buying these. Basically there is a thing where the noise canceling feature sends a frequency  that messes with your inner ear/balance, the same thing that is triggered when you get motion sickness. I enjoyed these bad boys for 3 days, and then experienced severe dizziness and nausea for hours after wearing them. I thought it was from the travel (I bought them for flying) but then I wore them for day 2 and 3 while sitting at a desk and still got severely dizzy. Unfortunately I have to return them, but if I didn’t get the spins, they would be my favorite set of headphones.

author: LGFitness
title: ATTENTION SMULE SINGERS! REALLY, BOSE???
content:
The Bose QC35 II is by far the best pair of headphones I’ve owned...and I have used quite a few...

I haven’t owned this long enough to give feedback on battery and interaction w/my Echo Show (Alexa) but I’m hoping those will be good experience.

I’m here mostly for those who are considering investing in these great headphones for the purpose of singing in Smule (the Sing app).

First of all, I think it’s pretty ridiculous that Bose would include an audio cable/wire without including a MIC audio wire!  But since it’s not a big deal and no big investment, this is resolved by purchasing a 3.5mm wire w/mic, right? WRONG!
To make matters a bit more frustrating for consumers such as myself, not only Bose made the female input jack in these headphones smaller than 3.5mm but they also make no mention of it in the owner’s manual.  To say such thing is super lame on Bose’s part is gross understatement!

So...if you are indeed thinking of buying these to use with Smule app, you’ll need to invest in good audio wire with microphone (I invested in Beats mic wire...can be found at Walmart for $20) and had to purchase a 3.5mm female converter with a 2.5mm male plug in order to connect the Beats mic wire to my new QC35 II.  Now, what was BOSE thinking?  After all, they know about Smule and how the worldwide popular singing app has and is creating plenty market for the audio equipment industry...and Bose didn’t impress me when it comes to making it rather inconvenient to use these Bluetooth headphones work w/wired mics.

And no, I haven’t found any headphones with wired mics that supersede the sound quality that my Bose QC35 II headphones render.  So it’s something for Bose to improve...and their marketing folks ought to know better than omit important info from consumers.  While Bluetooth option is an awesome thing, there remains certain online activities that require wired mics...Smule being one...and trust me, I’ve tried using “state of the art” expensive audio equipment to sing in Smule and even the most advanced of audio equipments (such hand held microphones; stand mics (Yeti), mic filters, digital headphones, etc, etc) render poor audio result compared to using wired mics with a good set of headphones.  As far as Smule sing app goes, even cheap earbuds do far better (because it has wired mics!) than expensive audio equipment without wired mic!

So either Bose “forgot” that some of us need wired mics w/a 3.5mm male plug, and by the way, that’s SUPER USEFUL for when battery time is shorter than the consumer intends to use these headphones for, or Bose purposely made these nice headphones w/a 2.5mm female input to make us go out and spend more money just to plug into their nice Bluetooth headphones??

Whatever the reason, I expected a LOT BETTER from BOSE, especially while paying almost $400 (that price includes extra service protection warranty) for A PAIR OF HEADPHONES that don’t even come with a wired mic and HAVE NO input to connect a 3.5mm audio cable to the headphones! I feel that there’s always some type of sound quality loss when we have to use adaptor connectors so I truly don’t understand why Bose chose to make the QC35 II with a 2.5mm female input in the headset while providing a cable that has no mic in it!  Yes, some use these just to listen to music, videos, news, etc.  But what if I’m listening to something in my device while wearing these and using the audio wire and my mother or a friend calls me via FaceTime or Facebook messenger or whatever else?  I can easily accept the video call but must unplug the headphones, which usually causes an audio problem in the video conference app, because it doesn’t transfer audio, once the audio device first used is disconnected. Something Bose seems to have completely disregarded.  Obviously, the focus in these is the Bluetooth capabilities.  But I ask Bose this question: why would I buy a wired pair of Bose headphones that cost not a lot less than these while getting less quality sound?  So if these work with audio cable, which it does, why not include an audio cable with a mic???  Charge the extra $20 or so dollars for goodness sake but it’s pretty sad to make such great quality headphones without sending it with a wired mic while knowing that the microphones in our devices don’t handle all recordings and are not designed to work well with singing apps!  Headphones aren’t just for listening!  What do professional singers wear when recording their songs inside a studio?? HEADPHONES!  Is it important for them to hear their own voices through the headphones they wear? You bet!  This is why those headphones are well connected with whatever microphones professional singers and studios use.  The same is true for ordinary, amateur singers such as myself.  But unlike pro singers, all we ordinary singers need is a wired mic that connects directly to the fancy expensive Bose headphones we invest on!

It’s a BOSE so yes, they are awesome headphones.  But needless to say I’m rather disappointed.  I can’t use these until the extra pieces arrive and worse than that, I had to find out the hard way!  Nothing in the specs here or even in the Bose website or in the owner’s manual shows that these headphones have a 2.5mm female input to the audio cable.  I feel a wired mic w/the appropriate size plug should be something to expect in a pair of headphones that cost $350!!!! Most of all, I feel that any type of electronic should come with pictures of it indicating the physical parts inside and outside of it.

Bose mentions that they include the 3.5mm audio cable.  Unfortunately, they make NO mention that the end of the audio cable which plugs into the headphones is actually size 2.5mm!

REALLY, BOSE??  A $20 mic wire with the correct size male plug to fit into the headset unconventional female input size would’ve saved a lot of frustration here...not to count given you a perfect “5 stars” score...

author: Jerome
title: BOSE vs SONY
content:
I Bought these noise cancelling headphones first before purchasing the Sony WH-1000X M3.  By the time the Sony head phones arrive I had used the Bose a few times but didn't use them heavily just in case I needed to return them.  So after reading reviews  about the Bose and Sony and Beats I decided to purchase the Sony head phones.  As I said by the time the Sony head phones arrive I was coming close to the 30 day return policy  for returning the Bose.  But I wanted to compare the two for myself.  Here are my findings.  The Bose by reputation know how produce a device the reproduces clear natural sound.  Sony, for the longest time has been making.... no, inventing products for us that in some cases are second to none.  So after using them for a week I have to say for myself the Sony Head phones came in #1.  Like the Bose I heard the clear sound,  but with the Sony's  I got a bit more bass.  I'm not concerned yet with all the buttons, whistles, and bells that the two give.  Rather the best sound possible using some not so good compressed music sources (Mp3).  I can only imagine up grading to uncompressed  recorded music will sound using the Sony's.
My only problem is I'm stuck with both units because due to a stay in the hospital I went over the 30 day return limit to sent back the BOSE Head phones.  PS. Look for review on the Sony head phones

author: dgd
title: Got these as a gift for my husband
content:
He absolutely loves them!!! He uses them for everything. They can connect to the fire stick on our TV so he can watch TV while I read, he uses them for meetings at work, he will take calls with them, listen to music, utilize the Alexa functionality, etc. the list goes on and on. The noise cancellation is ridiculously good, at least externally - if he is watching something on TV through the headphones and I am sitting directly next to him, I can't hear anything. The sound is crystal clear.
They are pricey but he uses them every single day so I would definitely say it is worth the investment. I would recommend to anyone thinking of springing for these!

author: Izak Hickcox
title: Very Good Headphones, but materials could be sturdier
content:
I bought these mostly for gaming (FPSes like Rainbow Six Siege, etc.) They sound great and the noise cancelling makes a major difference for determining where a sound is coming from, though after a while it might be uncomfortable from the counter signal (hardly notable if your volume isn't too high).

The major, and really only, complaint I have about them is that the ear cushions deteriorate after a while. It does take a bit... for me it was about a week ago from when I bought them... which was probably around a year ago. You can buy replacement cushions which are not nearly as expensive as the headphones in their entirety, but it is an unfortunate "maintenance" cost you'll have to look forward to with most Bose Headphones.

A my rating suggests, I would recommend these to someone looking for good noise-cancelling headphones, but I think it's important that people know that theirs a 35-45 dollar ear cushion renewal fee for their long-term use.

author: Gypsywoman
title: Great product and so as they advertise. Wonderful for plane travel !
content:
Have taken these now on 4 plane trips and used them on the plane, what a difference it makes in comfort level when flying.  Also in the room at night if others are sleeping I can watch a movie or listen to music knowing I’m not bothering anyone.  Great quality and very sturdy.  I’m rough on things when I travel and they show no wear and tear at all.
The quality of the music is so much better than just listening to music on my iPad or phone.  They are an investment but if you travel a good bit they are well worth the investment or if you just enjoy a great sound of your music enjoyment, buy them ! Yes

author: Was Fast
title: No Surprise Here
content: Read reviews here on Amazon, that made me nervous on counterfeit headphones, but nothing to keep me from doing some research to find reliable seller. The headphones arrived and performed as expected out of the box-  I am a huge Bose fan. Anyone denying the physical or sound quality of Bose is fooling themselves, or has a weird shape to their head. The headphones have seen noise canceling time and no noise canceling time, and have performed as a top shelf pick. The headphones have been more than 25ft away from a music source and did not lose the signal, until I went upstairs and the opposite side of the house-  30’ish feet I would guess. Love not having to leash myself to an audio source.

author: Squirley
title: Calls are interrupted - stops working
content:
I have been using the original Bose Noise suppressing headphones for years and absolutely loved them.  I thought that by now the wireless version would be excellent too.  I was wrong.  I installed the apps for my laptop and my iPhone 6 and paired the headphones to both.  I think I'll be returning them.
Good:
 • Comfortable
 • Light weight
 • Announces battery strength and paired devices when you turn them on
 • Microphone works very well for calls in both my home office and a very busy client site.
 • Extremely easy to pair to a device
Bad:
 • Garbled music!  Music from Laptop is very often garbled and the overall sound quality is bad.
 • They seem cheaper.  Not that they are, they are very well built, but I think in their striving for light weight they made them feel a bit cheaper.
 • While on a call on the laptop (Skype usually) other desktop alerts or any iPhone activity interrupts the call for at least 10 seconds or more.  I've had to ask people to repeat the couple minutes of a discussion because of this.  It should just mute the call by 20% and overlay the alert message so I don't miss anything.
 • Continuously announces that the iPhone is paired when it has a message like a text  that you have not dismissed yet.
 • The blue tooth connection just stops working.  While listening to music from YouTube on the laptop, it will just stop working.  I have to turn them off and wait several minutes for the paired devices to time out before they will reconnect.
 • The Google Assist isn't very useful.  Hopefully it will get better over time.

author: Lee D
title: Almost broke my own neck
content:
The sound detail with these is phenomenal. It picks up the smallest details...which I wasn't used to, which is how I almost snapped my own neck. I was listening to music and a subtle noise that directionally sounded like it came from behind me, scared the bejesus out of me to the point I snapped my head around so fast I nearly incapacitated myself.

The battery life is great on these, even when you don't use them for awhile they still retain their charge. They charge relatively fast too. You can use them with the aux cable without turning them on also which uses extremely minimal amounts of the battery.

They are very comfortable, coming from a guy that wears glasses and has big ears, I have worn these for hours without discomfort.

I don't have a lot of experience with noise cancellation but it seems to work good to me, I've actually put the headphones on and used the noise cancellation to take a nap.

I watch a lot of TV and movies with them and have them hooked to my amazon fire stick, the only down side is if you want to use them with bluetooth on another device while near the fire stick you either have to go onto the fire stick and disconnect the headphones or unplug it.

My only MILD gripe is having to install a Bose app on my phone to update the firmware and change what the left side button does (I use mine to adjust the noise cancellation but it can be used for Alexa or Google assistant too)

I can't 100% say it is or isn't worth the money because I have never had an equally expensive headset but I would recommend these to anyone as I have been very happy with the sound and build quality. They even come with a high quality case to store them in.

author: myamana
title: So far so good!
content: Recently got these headphones because I have noisy neighbors and I'm honestly tired of hearing their annoying songs. Unfortunately I thought that the ANC would work with pretty much everything, but that's my own fault for not making proper research. The ANC does block out lower pitched noises very well, but it won't block voices/music from outside since it can't really convert the waves so fast and cancel them. Still, when there's music on, I can't hear anything at all. I was hoping I could use this for pure silence, without music, but I guess that's still impossible! Nonetheless, amazing fit, it's super comfortable. All earphones/headphones I had prior to this would start hurting my ear about 1 hour in. This one I could spend hours and hours wearing and it would still be comfortable. Very light as well. I'm hoping it keeps this way. It's very expensive not to last long lol!

author: tt92618
title: Setup software and Bluetooth stability SUCKS.
content:
If I could give these a negative number I would.

First the backstory:  bought them, set them up, and enabled the Alexa helper.  All worked fine.  Charged them overnight.  Disabled Bluetooth on the phone,  then re-enabled.

And then:

- Alexa stopped working.
- Alexa app wouldn’t pair
- So after an hour of reading and trying everything online, still no Alexa.
- So I try to clear the Bluetooth list as Bose suggests.
- Headphones pair again, but still no Alexa.
- Clear Bluetooth devices again, and restart everything (phone etc).
- Alexa still won’t work.
- Clear everything again, delete Bose Connect, restart everything, reinstall Bose Connect, and re-pair.  Still no Alexa.
- Reoeat all previous steps but add in another device restart.
- Now the headphones won’t re-pair at all; all pairing attempts fail.

Total time wasted on something that should be dead simple: multiple hours.  Outcome: headphones won’t pair at all and are totally useless.

So where to begin?

- First, the Bluetooth pairing is terrible and unreliable.  It is utterly baffling how a user simply toggling Bluetooth on or off, nor doing ANYTHING with software settings, could break some core functionality of the device.  That’s just terrible engineering.  Bose needs to do better.

- No hardware reset.  So, if things go seriously sideways as they did here, there is no way to totally clear settings and set up from scratch.  Honestly, who does that?  Who builds a hardware device that can be set up only one time and can NEVER be reset to factory settings again?  That’s just crazy.  What if something goes wrong?  What if the settings get jacked up somehow and and nothing works to fix them?  Just replace the hardware?  Just seriously deficient.

None of this stuff should have happened.  It should not be possible for settings to get this munged.  So the fact that they can is a serious mark against these headphones.  A product this bad shouldn’t be sold.  I bought these for my son, but I have a pair of Sony MX1000/M3.  They are leaps and bounds better in every respect, starting with the fact that they just work without requiring a person to be a software engineer to figure them out or fix them when their software and firmware setting get jacked up,

Bose: if your product is this fragile, for crying out loud at least include a factory reset.  I’ve not been this disappointed in a product in a long, long time.

TL; DR: Do not buy these unless you are a masochist who enjoys pain.

author: Ampersand
title: Life changing productivity tool.
content:
I never thought I would buy these. They always felt like a luxury item...but little did I know they would become the most important productivity tool in my work bag.

The Bluetooth connectivity is great—better than any Bluetooth headphones I’ve ever owned (which ranged from cheapies to B&O). Sound quality is crystal clear, the microphone is great. People tell me they’ve never heard me so clearly.  And on top of all that, they’re incredibly comfortable.

I spend a lot of my time on conference calls, on planes, or writing in noisy environments. These have been life changing in all three circumstances. The only negatives: the Bose app can be a little wonky, and for some reason, the Google Assistant app seems to add a second instance of the headphones to my phone, which interferes with answering the phone, using Siri, etc., but that doesn’t happen often.

author: B. Loomis
title: Sound is just ok, but comfort and noise cancelling are excellent
content:
The sound quality on these are just not very good.  I compared them to several other headphones, including an 8 year old pair of cord-only bose triports, and the Plantronics backbeat 2 wireless noise cancelling headset, and these are the worst sounding headphones I own.  Almost no bass and they simply cannot handle some types of music.  But, the comfort and noise cancelling feature almost make up for the lack of sound quality.

Pros:
1. Comfort!  These are ultra-comfortable, pillow soft, around-the-ear bliss
2. Noise cancelling - best in the business.  2 levels of NC... much better than my Plantronics backbeat 2.
3. Phone voice call quality - these are excellent to use as a phone headset, even better than my Plantronics.

CONS:
1.  The bluetooth 4.1  distance is only 100 feet, 3x less distance than the Plantronics backbeat 2 which is 4.2
2.  Cannot control volume while cord is connected.  With the Plantronics backbeat 2, you can.
3.  2.5mm cord port vs standard 3.5 port... now I need to busy a special adapter to connect to long 3.5mm cord
3.  Price... these are very expensive for relatively bad sound quality

author: lwojdyla
title: Incredible for commuters!
content: These headphones are amazing at eliminating background noise. If you commute on the train/bus or if you fly a lot then these are a must have, if you value silence and your ears. Expect around 80% of noise reduction on your commutes. They are especially effective against background noise (such as aircraft engine/train/bus/or city noise). Sound quality is incredible too. Build quality is great. They are expensive but for sure worth the price tag. Save your hearing and get one of these for your noisy commutes! They also have a built-in in microphone and are pretty good for having Bluetooth calls too!

author: MBH
title: Bose QuietComfort - Still The King
content:
I come at this review after owning/trying a long line of good headphones. I own Grados, Sennheisers, other Bose, Sonys, and Beats. I just tried and returned the Sony WH1000XM3 due to their dismal call audio quality. These Bose, while not perfect, are pretty darned close.

Audio Quality: I've tried about everything I can throw at them; NPR streaming, Pandora HD, FLAC from Vox, MP3, Amazon Unlimited, Apple Music. They all sound really good. I think the app could use an EQ like Sony has to tweak them for personal preferences. Soundstage feels broad and realistic. I'm not an audiophile, but like music to sound like I'm there. Spatial information, shuffles by performers, resonant buzzes, string squeaks, little breathy inhales, those all add to the experience for me and I can hear them with these cans.

Comfort: They are light and the cups are big enough to clear the ears. The clamping force might be just a bit too tight, but I wore them for 8 hours yesterday without listening fatigue.

Connectivity: They paired with my iPhone and my work Dell laptop with no issues. They switch back and forth seamlessly. The only thing I've found amiss is that sometimes incoming calls don't default to the headphones and I have to switch the audio manually.

Call Quality: This is where they excel against the Sonys. Audio quality on both ands is crisp, clear and natural sounding. My client who complained about the Sonys didn't even know I was using headphones with the Bose. Total win here.

ANC: Really excellent. Maybe doesn't give the shocking "whoomp" of no noise like the Sonys, but my chatty office environment just disappears when I have these on. All I hear is my audio.

Personal Assistant: I have it set for Siri and she is no smarter unfortunately. Response is good though. Too bad she's such a dingbat.

Other little things: great packaging, really nice case, robust feel, good volume, long battery life.

I have not used the music sharing so can't comment on that.

author: seri
title: Can I give these more stars?
content:
I am in love with these headphones. I originally hesitated because of the cost but because I travel so much, and use 2 cell phones (one for business and one for personal), I decided to bite the bullet and hope for the best. These do not disappoint!

I have worn them on various flights and they have done a great job of canceling out the crying kids while I listen to music.

I work from home and these are also great for canceling out construction work going on outside.

I have successfully paired both my work phone and my personal phone at the same time to these headphones and it works perfectly. I can listen to music on my personal phone but still be connected for calls on my work phone.

And of course the sounds is incredible. BOSE really is the best for that.

I don't know why I waited so long to buy these. They're wonderful.

author: Cat dad
title: Lightweight, and beautiful.
content:
Bought these headphones to replace my last pair of noise-canceling headphones (TurtleBeach i30).  They come with a sturdy carry case which is a bonus in my opinion since I do travel a bit.

Build - Lightweight, and sturdy.  Felt good on the ears with an extended music listening session.  I also like the simplicity of the design as well.

I’m no audiophile, but the sound quality is wonderful.  Bass is solid without being overwhelming too.

Noise cancellation - I know these aren’t supposed to be used for canceling out a battery powered lawn mower hum, but they out preformed the i30 on that feat.  As for what they’re supposed to cancel out, ambient noise and people talking?  They’re far superior too, don’t expect them to mute the whole world though.

Bluetooth pairing with my phone was extremely simple too, and it’s app is streamlined too.

Haven’t set up the headphones with Alexa yet, and will update this section when I do.

author: Tawnya Dozier
title: Wife got these for me and ruined me forever
content:
My wife bought these for me as a gift. I'd never spend this kind of money on myself for headphones. I usually buy $10 ones and am pretty happy. Not any more. Once I used these for a few days, it's a pain going back to anything else. The kids didn't believe me when I said I couldn't hear what they were saying when I had the noise cancelling feature enabled. Heck, I didn't even know they were talking!

I bought another pair of noise canceling headphones for 1/7th the price during a Cyber Monday sale I found on slickdeals. But I returned that other pair after 2 days. What a piece of junk. My old $10 headphones are better than the wireless noise canceling headphones in the $50-$70 range. Now I want another pair of the Bose for home (I took them to work). Ugh, I guess I'll just have to shell out the cash or wait for my birthday. I'm tired of cords catching on things anyway, or forgetting I'm wearing headphones and stepping away from the desk with them on. With the wireless ones, that's not a problem.

Sound quality is excellent. Music and videos sound great. Even with nothing playing, you can use the noise canceling feature, combined with having something over your ears, to block out a good percentage of sound. I often put them on and forget to play music because I can focus really well without music when I wear these.

author: Don C.  ( Daytona Beach, Fl )
title: Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series II) Wireless Headphones, Noise Cancelling - Black
content:
These are the best wireless headphones i have ever owned. I use these for listening to music. (I prefer Classic Rock) The comfort and sound quality of these headphones is just fantastic! I like to sit outside in the breezeway, and listen to my tunes. A city park is nearby, and is sometimes noisy when football games or other events are going on.
When i set the Noise Cancellation on high, all the outside noise is gone, and i can hear the music the way it is MEANT to be heard! I am building up a great Classic Rock Playlist of music videos and some of my favorite Classic Rock albums. The Noise Cancelling feature blew me away the first time i heard it. I could not believe what a difference it made! In my humble opinion, this feature alone makes them worth the higher price than some of the cheaper wireless models available. I am very pleased with these headphones, and i recommend these to anyone who cares about quality sound and well fitting headphones. Try a pair! I think you'll like what you hear! I sure did!

author: Corey W.
title: Multiple Bluetooth connections doesn't work
content:
The specs says it can handle 2 Bluetooth connections at the same time. However, anytime I have both a computer and my phone connected at the same time, the audio really suffers if i try to just do anything with my phone. If Im watching something or listening to something on my computer and all I do is unlock my phone, the headphone audio degrades pretty much the entire time im messing with my phone. Even when Im not doing anything with audio on my phone, as in playing music or watching videos, and all im doing is surfing the news etc, the audio for the computer just becomes intolerable.

If only using 1 device at a time, these seem to do really well. But the multi-connection audio suffers quite badly.

author: Jan Smrcina
title: Awful quality issues for a premium product... twice!
content:
I have now had two of these sets of headphones and am in the process of returning the second. I'm writing this review in comparison to a set of Plantronics BB Pro 2 headphones that were separately connected to the same devices as this Bose headset, so the issue is definitely the headset and not the device.

First device:
- Noise cancelling worked sometimes in one ear, sometimes in both, and sometimes in neither.
- The headset would randomly emit a death screech at maximum volume in one ear.

After returning the first device, I thought that there was no chance I'd get a defective product twice in a row. I was wrong.

Second device:
- In a 15 minute period, I experienced 4 random power flickers which resulted in the device power cycling, announcing battery level, and reconnecting to the device it lost connection to.

I'm really disappointed with the quality level of these considering they are a ~300$ premium device. Hitting 1 quality issue happens, but two devices in a row is absurd. In contrast, I've had my other noise cancelling set for years and it has no issues. It's unfortunate as this device has a lot of positives (good battery, great sound, easy to use, nice carrying case and compact fold pattern) but none of them matter if the device doesn't work. 1 star.

author: Adude
title: Has critical flaw that Bluetooth mic drops during calls
content:
Product has a critical flaw that the mic drops during calls (phone, video conference, facetime, ...) making it useless for this function.

Another flaw is that if you just want the noise cancelling and no audio (say you are sleeping on a plane), there is no way to prevent the bluetooth from trying to connect to one of your devices. Solution is to attach the headphone wire and not connect it to anything, or turn off bluetooth on all your devices.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Broken noise cancelling while using bluetooth(possibly fixed)
content:
If you want good noise cancelling while on bluetooth you're out of luck. For some reason it plays back the sounds around you into your ears. Type on your keyboard and it plays back the sounds it hears into your ears. And to top it off when you go to the bose support webpage to download the updater it 404s. I used to think bose was a high quality company when I had the qc25.

Update: The playback issue seems to be gone for now. I don't know if that'd just because I haven't used Discord with it for a while or not.
Still not pleased with how difficult they make it to revert the version of firmware. They're as comfortable as the qc25s but like others have mentioned the noise cancelling on the qc25 seems like it was better.

author: Gary Murphy
title: Defective Firmware
content:
I am a fan of Bose headphones. They are expensive, but up until this purchase, I felt there was still a value there.  The pair I got has a noisy left ear.  I downloaded the firmware update.  That software is junk, but I finally got it to start up.  It states that I am at the current level of software.

This is a huge disappointment.

Update:  I called Bose Customer Support.  They asked if I had tried it on two devices.  I had.  That was the end of the diagnostics.  They were going to send me a replacement product.  There wasn't even a mention of trying a firmware update.  A person on the Bose Community board had this problem over a year ago and she received a second defective product.  Apparently Bose isn't the company they used to be, if they can't fix a manufacturing or QA issue in over a year.

author: Rob HNL
title: Stellar product if the support is still there.
content:
I have used virtually every model of Bose NC headphones since Dr. Bose first invented the NC technology- everything from the original $1000 pilot headset with battery pack, to the in-ear version. Most of the time, like many others, I use the NC headphones inflight (“never board an air[liane without them”). Along with the other promising features, the QC35 SII promises 40 hours run time in wired mode. While I would not look forward to testing that claim on a marathon series of flights, that’s impressive. Bose technology is still the uncompromising best, unless you prefer distorted sound and superfluous controls.
The bells and whistles have been well covered by other reviewers and should prove useful over time for those who make the effort to master them.
After millions of miles of inflight use, I can vouch for the “comfort” aspect of the over the ear models. My only disappointment is that Bose no longer supports its very reasonable replacement program for QC ear cups on older or discontinued models. They do deteriorate over time and the otherwise functioning unit cannot be salvaged.
I also noticed that the permanently affixed line wires for the in-ear models are flimsy and eventually fail from wear, and cannot be replaced. When I took advantage of the “discount” Bose offered to upgrade to a new in-ear set, it shipped without case or accessories and appeared to be refurbished. Why not use a double-ended line plug as supplied with the new QC35, at least that can be replaced, and an extra set should be included on the site or offered as an accessory. They will get lost or worn over time. Let’s just hope that Boise policy and service will live up to the high standards of their technology and their past commitment to support. I’m giving them 5 stars on performance, in anticipation that at today’s prices, the service will still be there.

author: Josh
title: Hands down my favorite headphones yet, base and manule eq lacking
content: So I don’t like first looks right after getting a product, so this is just at 14 months of owning these. My only reason these don’t get an all around 5 is due to a lack of base and no Manule eq settings. Besides that battery life is boasts 20hrs a year later stands true with noise cancelling the whole time I flew 15 and 1/2 flight with a 2 he flight preceding. And to include airports. Probably ran total of 24hrs and still had 20% left. Construction is not my favorite lots of plastic and aluminum don’t hold up great if you aren’t careful. Sound cancelling is amazing unless there is a medium wind. For some reason messes with it and it’s a little loud. Ease of use. Parr’s every time I’m with little blue tooth games. Unlike some headphones you have to forget turn off turn on. All that. They auto connect in seconds. I purchased a case with a battery to charge them and honestly hardly ever use it. Is nice for cause can it can charge you phone too. Or any usb so I still carry them in that. Besides the eq and base and construction. They have held up well under my falling asleep with them in and ending up going Through who knows what. I annoy a little more weight for matirials that feel sturdy. But as far as them holding up they have done well for me

author: Samantha TBD
title: Best headphones EVER
content: I had taken possession of my husbands Bose Quiet Comfort II headphones for about a year before he finally told me he needed them back. I was delighted to find the same ones in rose gold!! These headphones are so comfortable you can wear them all day. They don't squeeze your head and give you a headache. They don't hurt your ears.  The noise cancellation is adjustable too!! There are 3 levels: off, low and high. Its brilliant! On a walk and want to hear a car coming-turn it off! Trying to listen to a book while your husband snores-high it is and you will listen in peace! These are expensive headphones, but it is an investment I found worth every penny!

author: EW
title: great if you are totally dead inside
content:
I’m a 35 year old woman. I’ve got good ears but I’m not a hardcore audiophile. I got these to listen to music in the house and work out with. They fit comfortably and I thought, how bad could the audio be? They sell a lot of these right? Big mistake. If you want comfort + the audio experience of thin background music with no bass and muffled highs, look no further. But if you want to feel alive and experience a range of joy and feeling with your music and aren’t completely dead inside, run the hell away. I don’t know what BOSE stands for, but it may as well be Bass Obliterated Sound Eviscerated.

Even if you aren’t middle aged, these headphones are enough to give you a midlife crisis. If this was all I had to listen to, no amount of sex or fast cars could make up for the deadening, soul numbing mediocrity of these headphones. Bring me some Ativan and a Coldplay Spotify playlist and let me end it all now. This hollow, consensual hallucination I call a life has nothing left in it for me.

That got dark quickly. I’d better return these. Getting the Sennheiser HD1 instead.

author: C. DeGhoul
title: Less-than-impressive noise cancelling and sound drops out.
content:
Update: 12/8/18 - I had a conversation with Amazon and we determined the headset was likely defective, so they kindly and quickly replaced them.  The replacement pair is MUCH better about the sound-dropping issue, but it still has happened a couple of times.  Noise-cancelling is still, in reality, merely noise-muffling.  For the price, they’re disappointing.  It’s nice not having a wire but I’m afraid that’s the best thing I can say about them.  My much less expensive - but wired - Street headset works as well for sound quality, if not better.  I guess sound quality is the sacrifice you have to make if you want to lose the wire.

Original review:  After having just picked up a Bose Soundwear, and being impressed with it, I splurged on the QC 35 II.  That was a mistake.  They are in no way noise-cancelling.  Noise dampening, yes.  Cancelling?  Not even close.  From the commercials, they make you think you'll be insulated from the outside world.  Nope.  The other issue I have is the moment I stepped out of my house, the music I was playing started to cut out.  This did this on all settings, including when the 'noise cancelling' was turned off.  It became so bad that when I was returning home I literally shut them off, which made them absurdly expensive ear muffs.  I turned them back on before entering the house and, while in the house, they worked fine.  So, apparently I can only use them while in a building.  That's not going to work for me.  Heck, my much less expensive, corded Star Wars Street headset muffles nearly as much extraneous sound and they're not even noise cancelling!  And they don't constantly drop the sound when I'm walking outside (because, of course, they're corded.)  At lunchtime, I turned them and music on and stepped outside.  About 5' outside the door, sure enough, the music started glitching again.  I'm torn between wanting to see if a replacement will have the same issues or just getting my money back after reading all the problems people have been having with them.  For the amount of money they're getting for these, they should be flawless.  So far, I'm 50/50 on satisfaction with the Bose products I've purchased, with this particular purchase being firmly in the "substandard" category.

author: fiveminutesmoreo
title: Very good sound
content: Very good sound quality and I am pleased with the comfort, but only four stars for three reasons: no charging adapter included - seriously at this price point? The "customizable" button can only be assigned to a few things. The last reason is the charging seems slow and then the power drops down to 70 percent very soon after you start using it. It is too soon to tell if it has a defective battery.

author: Orangeman
title: Tough Choice Between The Bose QC 35 and the Sony 1000XM2
content:
After doing a lot of research, it ultimately came down to the Bose QC 35 and Sony 1000XM2.  I tried them both for several days but in the end, the Bose QC 35 was my choice, which wasn't an easy one to make.  You can't go wrong with either pair as they are both very nice headphones.  The final decision for me was whether I wanted a little better quality (Sony) or better fit/comfort (Bose).  I chose comfort and the Bose 1000XM2.  Here are some other things I noticed...

SOUND QUALITY:
No question at all, the Sony 1000Xm2 are better sounding headphones.  Don't get me wrong, the Bose are still very good.  However, I really liked and preferred the bass response of the Sony over the Bose.  Bose are the brighter sounding headphones but the biggest difference was how they sound with bass, which Sony does better.

FIT / COMFORT:
The Bose gets the edge on fit/comfort.  They are VERY comfortable and light!  The Sony 1000xm2 are fine but they fit a bit more snug than Bose.  At first, I actually preferred the Sony fit.  However, after having them on for an hour or longer, that's where I noticed the biggest difference... ear fatigue.  Much less ear fatigue with the Bose.  That all being said, what is more comfortable to me might be less comfortable to you.  You just have to try them on, ideally for extended periods of time.  I bought these particularly when I fly where I plan to wear them for hours at a time.  Even though I prefer the sound quality of the Sony, I just couldn't get over the incredibly comfortable fit of the Bose.

BLUETOOTH CONNECTIVITY:
Both do a fine job here but the Bose were the more reliable in establishing a connection without having to fiddle around with settings.  When comparing the Sony and the Bose, I often went back and forth trying when trying out the headphones.  Every time that I went back to the Bose, it was fast and easy.  With the Sony pair, I had to go into my Bluetooth settings a few times in order to get a connection.  It really wasn't a big deal but the Bose gets the edge here because it is painless and works more reliably.

DURABILITY:
I won't give either pair the edge here because I only had them for a week BUT do keep in mind that the Sony 1000xm1 had issues with the headband cracking.  Because Sony hasn't clearly stated whether they resolved the issue with the xm2's, it's anyone's guess.  This alone probably wouldn't keep me from going with the XM2's but it is something to consider.

CONTROLS:
I like them both and consider this a toss up.  With the Sony pair, you just swipe the headphones to control the music and volume while the Bose has hard buttons.  At first, I definitely preferred the hard buttons that are on the Bose.  However, after getting used to swiping on the Sony's, I found it easy enough to do.  Which do I prefer?  Probably the hard buttons because they are a bit more reliable than the swiping.  This is very subjective though and I could see some preferring the swiping while others preferring the hard buttons.  It just depends on what you like.  For me, I found both to work fine.  The Sony does have a feature where you can put you hand over the right headphone and it will allow you to hear outside noise without having to take them off.  Cool feature?  Maybe for some but for me, I didn't see any use for it.  If someone approaches me while wearing big headphones like these, I'm going to take them off my head rather than keeping them on with my hand cupping the right headphone.  It just seems a bit rude not to do so.

FEATURES:
They both have their pluses and minuses here.  It really depends on what is most important to you.  I really like how the Sony 1000XM2 allows you to customize the sound (including equalizer).  It also has the ability to modify you settings depending on where you are listening to them by simply pressing a button.  I don't really no what impact that has though because I only tried this a couple of times.  The fact of the matter is that Sony provides a bit more customization which I like!  The Bose has google assistant which I found to be a cool feature.  I could live without this but it is a nice feature.  The feature that I found VERY useful on the Bose is the ability to play text messages through the headphones.  I was on a flight recently where we were waiting for our turn to take off.  While listening to my music, I was notified that I had a text message.  Instead of having to reach for my phone (Sony) the Bose pair allowed me to just push the action button to hear the text.  I found this awesome.  Sony does not have this feature.  What headphones gets the edge?  For me, it's another toss up.  I really like the customization of the Sony but the Bose are very cool with being able to read my text messages (and google assistant).

LOOKS:
They both look great!  I had the gold/beige Sony's and the silver Bose.  I might give a slight edge to Bose as I like the silver look and the Bose logo on each headphone.  However, this is very subjective.

SUMMARY:
This is one of those times where you just can't go wrong with either pair.  They both have their pros and cons but in the end, for me, I prefer the Bose QC 35 by a very small margin.

author: caconym
title: meh sound, great everything else
content:
The sound is about on par with what I'd expect from a good pair of headphones a third of the price (driven by an in-device DAC/amp, nothing fancy). Totally usable but the detail and presence just aren't present (heh).

Everything else is great, though. The noise canceling works very well, and even when it's turned off there is a fair amount of passive isolation. They are *very* comfortable and quite light. Build quality seems quite good; there's a thoughtful use of different materials throughout and there's no creaky plastic. Battery life also seems very good, and they charge relatively quickly.

The software side also seems to be in decent shape. I've had occasional weird connection issues but overall things work better than I generally expect.

I"m only dinging one star for the audio quality because it's fine and I'm sure the other constraints on closed-back wireless noise-canceling headphones with great battery life make it difficult to achieve sound like other headphones at the same price point but with none of those constraints. Overall I'm very glad I made this purchase.

author: VCDG
title: Sound reduction, not noise cancelling.
content:
Bought these to help me concentrate at work and NOT hear any of the noise around me. However, I have tried them on with the TV on, with fairly low volume, and I can still hear it over the music. Only way NOT to hear the tv is to turn the volume up high on the headphones. I have hoped to replace my old Bose headphones (wired) which still work, but have lost most of the covering over the ear cups. Plus the limit mobility from them being wired. I'll have to try them out some more, before I decide to return them or not.
Sound quality thus far is best from my phone. My pc may need a better bluetooth transmitter. Looking to also get a transmitter for my tv.

author: Daniel Covell
title: Great Sound, Amazing Noise Canceling, Extremely Comfortable, Stupid Wired Audio Cable
content:
On an airplane just put these on and close your eyes and put on your favorite music. Then just disappear into your own world. The sound is very wide and pleasing. A little bass heavy if you are used to monitor quality headphones but for most the bass is very nice. I wish the headphones had different EQ modes. The Noise cancelation is amazing and even after having it on high for a long time it does not wear you out. They are very light and you almost don't notice they are on your head.

The only real complaint is the audio cable is proprietary 3.5mm to 2.5mm. I have no idea why they did this and if you lose the cable you have to buy it online. Unlikely to find in most stores. Also annoying since half the time I have the wrong end and have to flip it around. This is just stupid to me.

author: FREROW
title: Falling Apart - foam showing in both ear pieces
content: Purchased in April and already the foam is coming out of both of the ear cuffs.  This is totally unacceptable for the price paid for this item.  I hang the headphones up each time, ie they are not thrown around or abused in any way.

author: Henry Beuving
title: Amazing sound and noise cancellation, slight headband problem
content:
Pros:
Strong and detailed bass, clear mids and crystalline highs. Great sound.

Active noise cancellation is very effective amazing for public transportation and school.

Very comfortable on the ears.

Long battery life, I've never had a problem with it running out before I get to a charger.

Bluetooth connects fast and stays paired reliably.

Cons:
Since, the clamping force is pretty light, there is a slightly annoying pressure on the top of your head. I wish the top headband was a little thicker.

ANC gave me a giant headache on the first two days, but it feels completely fine now that I'm used to it so I don't care.

The pros of these headphones dwarf the cons, so I'm giving them 5 stars. They were worth $299.

author: Nick6684
title: These Bose are the best headphones on the market
content: These Bose are the best headphones on the market!  After having a Beats Studio Pro headphones for 5 years, they served me well but needed a new set that was noise cancelling.  The Beats sound was very base heavy, not balanced amd no noise cancellation at all.  These Bose are literally in a different league above Beats.  Only thing I wouls improve is if Bose gave a charging plug with them.  I only use Apple products and had to buy a generic Andriod plug to charge the headset, very surpised that Bose did not include a plug in the box!

author: Brandon
title: Don’t waste your time....
content: I have had these for 2 weeks now. I have given them as many tries as I can. The sound quality is okay, the volume level is poor. The noise canceling is almost nonexistent and don’t get me started on the Bluetooth connectivity or syncing issues. The amount of money these cost is not worth the product you received. I am returning them ASAP

author: Barry Allen
title: Great product but too pricey for products worth
content: Well like always Bose made good headphones. They are versatile and lightweight, easily controlled and comfortable. But with that said, I have owned the Beats Studio and Skullcandy Crushers before. Both are very adequate and cheaper replacements. You are in fact paying for the Bose name with this product. Nothing wrong with them, but honestly I've heard other brands be barely different for a lot less money. The battery life is less than impressive, overall I'm not even a little impressed with this product. I've been a fan of Bose for well over two decades now. But this product kind of let me down. The noise cancellation is actually very well done though. Overall not a bad product, but it needs to be 120 bucks or less for it to be worth it

author: Michael
title: Major Bluetooth problems
content: Really bad bluetooth on two different items. The sound is great, noise canceling is great, but the bluetooth drops, gets full of static, and has a very hard time connecting. Other devices in the same room, including $30 headphones, have no problems. Get with it Bose, Bluetooth is not some new thing you shouldn't be having such trouble with it.

author: Wayne C Burkan
title: Super comfortable, great noise cancellation, no issue pairing and a great mike for making phone calls.
content:
I am a long-time Bose QC 25 user, so I'm used to good noise cancelling. Because I wear them while doing chores, however, the wire invariably catches and yanks. So after years' of my beloved QC 25, I took the plunge. The QC 35 II Wireless has topped even those high expectations!
