I wear headphones to help me concentrate at work and to listen to music, so have been wearing this pair an average 6-8 hours a day, and they are by far the most comfortable pair I've ever owned. The noise cancelling is awesome, and being wireless is especially liberating. I was concerned, however, after reading reviews of pairing issues. Out of the box I paired my phones with my iPhone 8, my iPad Air 2 and my Lenova laptop, all without a hitch. I have not had ANY issues with connectivity.

I have not found any reviews on the phone's performance while making calls, so I wanted to highlight that I can receive, and to my relief, everyone reports they can hear me loud and clear: on a bus, in the wind, it makes no difference. I love my QC 25 II.

author: Scarlett O'Hara
title: noise cancellation caused ear pain
content: I missed the return window by one day.  The bluetooth is fantastic, sound quality good, and these fit well on my ears.  I bought them for the sound cancellation, to replace a wired pair whose earpiece fell off.  The noise cancellation on these works to muffle the sound (not as well as on the wired ones), but it has left me with pain deep in my ears. The first time I used them I wasn't sure they were the cause, but this past weekend I knew.  The earpain does not go away.  I may have to see a doctor.  The solution, I guess, is to turn off the noise cancellation, which was the reason I bought them.  I also think it is ridiculous to have to download apps to get instructions, but I know there is a way to turn it off and still use the bluetooth feature.  I am not interested in Alexa.

author: no problem
title: very good
content:
sound quality is very good. i am not an audiophile though. i love the sound. the sony XM3 has better bass. the XM2 has maybe slightly better audio. i do like the bass so i will give XM3 the edge here.
noise cancelling is comparable to the XM2 but inferior to the XM3 whose noise cancelling is noticeably better.
comfort of wearing the headphones: i feel these are more comfortable than both the XM2,XM3.  the sonys are comfortable, just less so.
comfort of use: the bose have physical buttons, which i prefer over sony's touch interface.
another advantage the bose has over the sonys is that i managed to connect it simultaneously to two devices. i did not manage this with the sonys. you can pair them with more than one, but i could not connect them simultaneously. this basically means i use the bose when i am at home because i like being connected to my laptop and my phone. the switch between laptop and phone is automatic and usually good. some bugs, but overall, worth it.

to sum it up, i will use the bose when i wanna connect to two devices, and the XM3 when i want superior noise cancellation and bass for music, which usually means when i go to the gym, or on flights.

author: Amanda
title: Absolutely amazing and worth the $$$$
content:
Ok, these are amazing! I can't hear a single thing when I turn these on. I was looking for headphones that canceled out noise in the background even when I wasn't listening to music (I'm a med student and need constant quiet while studying), and these work really well. Here are some details about the features:

Features: On the right headphone, there are 3 buttons aligned vertically, the volume-up button, the pause button, and the volume-down button. This is also where the On button is. On the left headphone, there is a button for Google Assistant, which I highly recommend. Just get the Bose app for headphones and the Google Assistant app and it'll help you through the set-up. You can even use them on multiple devices at the same time. I use it on my Mac, iPad, and iPhone. Just turn on Bluetooth for all your devices and turn on the headphones and it should connect automatically. Google Assistant is like Siri. These also allow you to speak into them as it has a mic, so if someone calls you are able to talk through these without picking up your phone.

Noice-Canceling Feature Only (No music): If someone in the background is cooking or cleaning I can't hear a thing with these turned on. With just the noise cancelation and no music, I can't hear the dishwasher or even certain levels of music playing in the background. I can hear conversation but really low which doesn't bother all that much. The noise canceling is really good.

Noice-Canceling Feature WITH Music/Video/Sound On: I can't hear a thing! People have to scream if they need to talk to me. Not only does it cancel out all noice in the background, you don't need to turn the volume up all the way and kill your ears in order to hear the sound playing. It's like being in a movie theater. The sound is outstanding and clear!

Overall great headphones that do the job right! I feel like I'm in my own world when studying, and even watching shows/movies.

author: Wayne Ngo
title: Perfect Headphones Ruined By Firmware Updates
content:
I received these with firmware 2.0.1 which worked phenomenally with my Mac and iPhone. ANC was nice and bluetooth stable. Unfortunately, the google assistant app decided to update my firmware to 2.5.1 by it self!! Seriously Google? Ask me for permission first.

Afterwards, ANC got noticeably worse. I played various background noise on my speakers and there was no difference between low and high ANC. Bluetooth skipped every 2 seconds if both Mac and iPhone were connected whereas it worked seamlessly before. Symptoms didn't go away after updating to the 3.1.8 firmware via Bose's website. These are getting returned.

If you get these headphones, DO NOT update them - please. If it ain't broke don't fix it.

Notes:
-I did the Bose reset and re-paired multiple times. No dice.
-This ANC issue happened on the original QC 35 too
-google assistant initiated update WITHOUT prompting "yes or no". This happened when opening the app.

author: jswest
title: My comparison: Bose vs Sony
content:
OK, my personal comparison of the Sony WH-1000Xm2 and the Bose is complete. After reading all the reviews, the Sony seemed to win out, but with Amazon's generous return policy, I purchased both and did a several hour comparison yesterday. Both are great, but here's what pushed me over the edge for Bose.

1. Sound. I am not an audiophile so the terms I use in this section to describe what I experienced may be technically incorrect terms, so bear with me. The Bose sound is amazing. It is crisp and clean and full. I can hear so much more in the same music I have been listening to for years. It's hard to explain but the Sony seemed compressed while the Bose feels full. The highs are better on the Bose and the there is separation in the music. The bass on the Sony seems louder, but not crisp and clean like it does on the Bose. The Sony sound is very good but compressed and almost muddy compared to the Bose. I know reviews say the Sony sounds better, but I just don't hear it that way. I found myself cutting my Sony tests short so I could go back to the Bose.

2. Comfort. The Bose is lighter and more comfortable for me. The Sony felt heavy in comparison.

Every other feature became unimportant to me after hearing the sound and feeling the comfort. Both eliminated noise and did everything else fine.

Nothing against the Sony WH-1000Xm2 - it is an excellent product, but for me I'm keeping the Bose and sending back the Sony's.

author: Fnord
title: Excellent wired sound and ANC, but nearly useless Bluetooth audio
content:
POSITIVES: Extremely comfortable to wear, sound when connected by a cable is is top notch, noise cancellation is excellent, and it comes with a tough case.

NEGATIVES:
- The sound over the Bluetooth connection is simply awful. At best, it's like listening to AM radio, with a muffled high end, muddy mids and dead bass. At worst, it drops out, distorts, skips, makes bizarre low-frequency digital beeps and loses most of the frequency band. This is what I would expect from a $9.95 pair of cans, not one that costs over 30x more than that.

- The Bluetooth connection has an effective, reliable range of only 3-6 feet (and even then, the sound quality is as described above!) At just 10 feet, it often starts dropping out and skipping. Going around a corner inside a house, even if it's only 10 feet away, normally kills the connection. Going 15 causes it to disconnect. This was the same on two different laptops and a mobile phone, so it's definitely a headphone issue.

- You cannot use the headphones while charging. Seriously?

- The included audio and USB cables are a joke -- the former is maybe 2 ft long and so thin it seems bound to wear out in weeks; the latter is maybe 3 inches long.

- The built-in volume controls only work over Bluetooth, which is unlistenable.

- The synthesized voice that tells you about various headphone statuses cuts out to the point of unintelligibility.

I would gladly pay $29.95 for these headphones knowing that the Bluetooth is essentially unusable. At the price they're sold at, however, these headphones are a massive disappointment.

author: Silent Jay
title: Life Changer For Coping With Big City Noise
content:
I've had these for a few days and they are a lifesaver.  I live in New York City and work from home near a busy road.  There is noise all around me - heating, refrigerator fan, light fixtures, traffic, incessant honking and sirens, neighbors playing music loudly.  After the first time I tried them and turned them off, I thought, wow why is my room so loud all of a sudden, what is that?  It turns out it was just the everyday noise I've been surrounded by.  That's how incredibly silent my world becomes when I put these on.

Granted, like other reviewers have mentioned, the world won't actually become completely silent, but it'll get as close as you can to it.  For me, as someone who has a case of misophonia, these do such a great job that I can focus on my work so much better.  They make a world of difference.  Sometimes I just leave them on without music.

Bonus points for the Bluetooth connectivity and the mic.  I now take all my work phone calls on this.  I have connections to my work laptop, my work cell phone, and my personal cell phone.  I can stream music to it, pause, take a call, and resume my music.  I've been told the receiving end hears me very clearly.

Yes, $350 is a lot of money.  I originally had no intention to get these; i wasn't considering them at all.  I was looking at the QC 25s (wired).  But after spending time reading reviews and making the decision that this was something necessary because the noise was impacting my concentration on work, I pulled the trigger.  Going wireless is sooo much better than being chained down to my phone or computer.

Definitely a worthy investment if you experience similar conditions as me or simply enjoy silence!

author: Songhai
title: So far so good. I bought it because I often forget taking ...
content:
So far so good.I bought it because I often forget taking earbuds on flights and have to buy them on flights which I quickly loose before my return trip! So I thought maybe carrying a sizeable wireless headphone will solve the problem considering the significant size.Additionally, it helps to watch and listen to TV program at home when others are doing their own thing without me distracting them.

Pros:
1.Sound quality is good.I like that the equalizer self adjusts to the sound continuously and you do not have to make any manual adjustment. The sound it delivers is undiluted. It is as rich as the sound coming out from our old Phillips surround speakers connected to an OPPO audio/video system.
2.The cancellation effect is excellent.At a high level, it effectively cancels out all external "noises".  For safety reason, I use it on the low level so I can still be aware of my surrounding.
3.It is very comfortable on my ears.I do not just place the ear piece over my ears .I deliberately make sure I place it over my ears coming from a back approach.That way the ear lobe sits into the recess and no pressure is applied on my ears.Then I push the piece up but not pull it down as one would normally do.Compared to prior headphones I had worn many years back for listening to music, my ears do not get uncomfortably warm after a prolong use, by prolong use, I mean wearing it for 20 minutes or more.I have worn this headphones for 5 hours continuously without feeling any discomfort of warmth or pressure to my ears.
4.Have not tested the limit  of the battery life.But as noted above, it has  served me for 5 hours of continuous use.Also,I make sure I charge it after each use. I believe that the battery life will even be longer than it is today.
5.The unit is not heavy to carry but I think that as the technology improves that lighter materials will be used to make it lighter. I have not tried using it to make hand free calls with my phone.Other reviewers say that, that feature works well.
6.Reconnecting to any bluetooth devise automatically has always been smooth and seamless. Has excellent memory. Have not tried other brands to compare with, I doubt I can afford to do that.I am happy with this wireless headphone and will recommend it.

Cons:
1. Expensive.
2.The manual that came with it was not very helpful.

My wishes:
1.That the system automatically shut itself off after 20 seconds of being taken off from the ears, if it does not detect any pressure from the ear pieces.This will save the battery life.
2.That it has a storage compartment in it you can store the wired cable.
3.That it comes with an "instructive" instruction manual. I had to go online to download a manual that made more sense.
4.That I do not have to take it off my ears to listen to someone talking to me. Planatronics unit I have read has a feature to overcome this little incovenience. By placing your palm over the right ear piece makes you hear external sound and temporarily pauses the internal sound.Removing your palm, resumes the internal sound and cancels out the unwanted external source of sound.Boss could learn a thing from Planatronics here.

author: Judd
title: 1. Horrible app 2. Audio cuts out 3. Action button is a disaster
content: Absolutely horrible. Bose are good when they're not Bluetooth. I literally have had 3 pairs (I know... burn me once...) and they've all been really horrible. I currently own 2 pair. I just couldn't believe they could be this bad and kept giving them a second and third chance. I assumed I was having bad luck. Not true. Same results on all of them. In fact, one has an extra special annoying problem, unique to itself, which I'll get to in a minute. For one, the "Action" button is a total catastrophe and the Bose app sucks hard. Regardless of whether I set this button to Google Assistant, Alexa or nose cancellation intensity... the headphones continuously ask me to connect to the Bose app. This isn't only from time to time, but amazingly and annoyingly extremely often. It's not just an initial set-up thing. No. That would make too much sense. This is constant. Also, I with my 2  pairs (so I always have one around the house, etc.... again...I admit I'm a moron for doing this and not returning them) they both have the dreaded, sporadic Bluetooth signal cut out. I would think for this price, that wouldn't happen. The $20 MPOW Bluetooth headphones I bought for the gym don't ever cut out using the same phone I use with Bose. Lastly, Bose gave me an extra special treat with 1 of the 2 headphones. This beauty won't just simply play as a commoner would expect. I have to first press play, second, press the amazing Action button (sarcasm), third, hear "you have no new messages", then finally press play on my phone in order for it to play. This headset also won't play if I use Google Assistant. It just sits there. My advice is to buy any other brand. I'm never buying Bose again. There are other brands now which have caught up with the noise cancelling feature. Bose is stuck in the 90's. The owners clearly are lazy and don't want to make improvements.

author: Julia
title: Perfect sound, clear beautiful high and low, light and comfortable, secure fit for exercise, even great for calls
content:
I narrowed down my hunt reading various headphone review sites to upgrade my exercise music experience to three higher end headphones and couldn't narrow it further so decided to get all three to find out in side by side comparisons which would be the best for me.

[1] Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series II) Wireless Headphones, Noise Cancelling ($349.00)

[2] Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless Bluetooth ($348.00)

[3] Beats Studio3 Wireless Headphones ($298.99)

I put on the Beats and the heaviness and fit gave me the sense of an impending headache the instant I put them on. That, and the sound was empty and flat compared with either Sony or Bose. What was most surprising to me was they didn't have strong bass, which I had thought they were known for.

I put on the Sony and they were bigger but somewhat better fitting, not a lot lighter, but with more of a clear and full range from high to low.

I put on the Bose and it was surprisingly and significantly lighter and better fitting than either of the others and the sound was basically perfect. Good bass, full range of highs and lows.  I have to admit that I had to switch back and forth between the Sony and the Bose about 10 times to determine if I *really* preferred the Bose to the Sony, and they were actually pretty darn close. The final element that tilted the scales in favor of Bose was they were so much lighter and better fitting, which was paramount for me since I'd be using them for exercise, so I took a 1/10th of a point of the Sony. If I was the type of person who uses headphones for sitting around enjoying music, the weight and fit would be less important and the music quality would be almost everything, and then I'd probably have to switch between the Bose and Sony another 10-20 times to figure out what the difference is and what I prefer. It's subtle; equal but different. It may come down to a matter of individual preference and the type of music you listen to.

In addition to all of the above, as I've continued to use the Bose for 'everything' - I was most surprised when on a whim I decided to see if I could place a call with them; and my two initial callers both exclaimed that this was the BEST and clearest sound talking to me they had yet experienced (For years I've tried their patience through testing calls with 10-15 different best rated wired and wireless headpieces, ear buds et al).  The rave reviews of the recipients of my calls carried from inside to outside walking the streets of NYC with all the usual sirens and traffic noise.

But most important of all, I can listen to my music in full head-filling gorgeous energizing glory when I'm exercising.

Final score:
Bose 5 stars
Sony 4.9 stars
Beats 3 stars

author: dls74447
title: Can't say enough nice about these!
content:
DREAM headphones for me. Got the beautiful silver which I love.
I ordered at least 4 or 5 other brands. Either didn't fit my-I guess short female head. Or they quit working within a week. Came not working, or the sound was pitiful.
The ear pads feel great. Soft & just perfect around my ear.
Controls are very intuitive compared to the other brands. I love the on/off/pair on the upper side of the right ear piece. I have short arms & older fingers. Searching & searching for the up/down or on/off "under" the ear piece was awful for me. the volume is under the right ear piece but it''s all your fingers are looking for there. Once I set the sound on a movie for example I rarely need to change the volume with these headphones.
I like the the noise canceling button on the left is all you need to deal with too.
The noise canceling with Bose AR is the best I could have asked for. Battery lasts a long "binging" time.
Bluetooth is easy to set up & reconnects almost immediately. If needed to turn off push right side button to right & you are in business again.
Worth the money in every respect. I wasted time & money trying not to spend this much money. Retired-limited funds. Oh my Gosh how happy I am I just pushed order on these headphones & ignored the $299 this time.
I hate to have even one negative because it is only really my problem. That is the mute ability.
For me I can't do it. I really miss muting quickly. The option is there the directions say. I accomplished it one time. But maybe due to my awkward old fingers & position of the muting button in between the off & on volume I have just given up trying to mute all together. I just take the head phones off my head to not hear some things because I love all else about these headphones so much. I pray next model will have a completely separate, easy to do, mute button added away from the volume buttons. Something Quick. Such as right "under" the right on/off/pair button. Not beside to confuse my fingers. Or better on the left outside ear piece in same place the on/off/pair button is on the right earpiece. Away from NC button.
My son is particular with his headphones. Has several for different purposes & work. He liked these so much he decided one of his were not working right, ha, ha. He bought the next up $399 model immediately. He could not be happier. Both sound extremely clear. Oh my gosh!  I like the less bass & more inclined to treble of mine. Helps me hear better.
I can only connect to two devices at a time. We noticed he can connect to 3 or 4. (sorry not sure but at least 3).
If you can be in love with a pair of headphones I AM THERE! JUST DO IT.

author: thunderstorm
title: Wonderful headphones
content: I love these headphones. Sure they're pricey but I can say wholeheartedly you get what you pay for. I live in a city where trains and or buses can get pretty loud and sometimes regular headphones don't block the noise out completely. These do just that and more. When you turn them on you already can tell the difference in background noise and once your music starts playing that's all you hear. You don't hear people's conversations or whatever is going on around you. The headphones adjust accordingly to many sized heads and they're very comfortable. I have Google assistant with my headphones so the button that controlled noise cancelling now can control my notifications. For instance if i get an incoming text message i can press the button to have message read to me then I can hold to reply and press one more time to send. My only small gripe with these headphones is the microphone is a little sensitive and from my own experience when I talk to someone on the phone they can hear the background noise very loudly even if it's really not that loud. Maybe it's an over exaggeration since I can't really tell but overall well worth the money. Sound quality is phenomenal in every aspect

author: James M. Rhoades
title: Bose vs. Sony: use case matters
content:
Don’t write reviews often but I recently struggled with the decision between these headphones and the Sony wh1000mx3. I ended up purchasing both to test and landed on the Bose. First and foremost, these are both phenomenal noise cancelling headphones and most people would be happy with either. Just to name a few things I liked about each product and why I seemingly went against the grain and chose the Bose over the Sony’s:

Fit: both were extremely comfortable. I give a slight edge to the Bose as I received a little less clamping force. Mind you I have a larger sized head so most people likely wouldn’t perceive the difference.

Controls: I preferred the Sony’s controls only because I feel like everything is touch now and it felt natural. I know there is a cold weather issue but I’m mostly using these indoors in an office setting and occasional air travel.  I also preferred Sony’s inclusion of usb c.

Sound(music): simply put my ears preferred the Sony sound. The Bose sound very good (neutral) but I preferred the sound of the Sony’s.

Phone: and here is why I chose the Bose. And this is where for me, my use case meant the Sony’s were not an option. The Sony’s were unusable on work conference calls. Even in a quiet environment other participants couldn’t hear me. The Bose were exceptional in this regard. Also, the ability of the Bose to connect to two Bluetooth devices simultaneously is invaluable (for my use case).

In summation, both are great headphones and you should really determine your use case before deciding.  For me, the Bose voice quality and the seamless Bluetooth connectivity between multiple devices out weighed the Sony’s exceptional noise cancelling, controls, and audio sound.

author: J. Kapur
title: Excellent Product (from someone who has not been a fan of Bose "sound")
content:
This is a great product and perfect for what I was looking for.  Excellent noise cancellation (heaven sent on long flights; great for tuning out in the office; so on, and so on).  AND - GOOD SOUND - I listen to a wide variety of music (Classic Rock, Jazz, Bollywood, Classical, Indian Instrumental - you get the point) and the sound quality has been consistently excellent from these head phones.  Bose has a hit here as far as I'm concerned - getting these for the kids as b'day presents (both in college...).  It comes in a case that is perfectly designed to protect these and the Bose App connects quickly and without any bother.  Previously connected (via Bluetooth) devices are automatically connected (up to 2 at a time and you can toggle which two [if it has discovered more than two in the past] from the Bose App easily and quickly)
I am truly enjoying this product and I would highly recommend without any constraints.

author: PJB
title: They are ok
content:
Bought 1 pair and didn't care for them so I gave to my husband.  Bought a 2nd pair because of crying kids and loud excited old ladies on train at christmas and didn't want to listen to them on trip home on train. My head might be a tad too small. Wish they made them in a smaller size.
They do not block out sound at all, not even close to it. It just muffleds sound. Makes sound less sharp and shrill.

author: JA
title: Most comfortable wireless noise cancelling headphones.
content: I also own the Sennheiser MOMENTUM 2 wireless noise cancelling headphones, which I think look much nicer (especially white version) and sound amazing, but they're unfortunately just not as comfortable. The Bose are FAR more comfortable, so ultimately they're the ones I prefer just because they're so much more comfortable to wear for extended periods. Both have great sound and noise cancelling for my tastes, though I'd say the Sennheisers sound a bit better overall. The differences there are not nearly as dramatic in the differences in comfort, though. If the Sennheisers improved their comfort I would pick them over the Bose, but until then I'd rather have something that doesn't make my ears and head hurt.

author: naa134
title: Good, comfortable headphones for long wear
content: I bought these headphones for my very long flight to China. The best feature about them is comfort. They fit over my ears so they were not pressing on my ears at all. I also wear glasses and they were not pressing into the sides of my glasses. I was able to wear them for hours without any discomfort. I synced them with my tablet to watch shows and movies on the flight. The sound quality was really good and the bluetooth worked great. There is also a cord to plug in to devices if you don't want to use the bluetooth. I think the noise cancellation feature works good, but not great. It blocked out some of the loud plane engine noises and some surrounding noises, but not everything completely. There were crying children on the flight which I heard through the headphones. I guess I expected them to block out all surrounding noise completely instead of just muffling the sounds. Using a pair of earplugs in addition to these headphones would be good to block out all sounds. Overall, I really like the headphones for the comfort they provided.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Comfortable and great sound quality. Disappointing range.
content: I have a pair of QC25s too. The QC35IIs have the same great comfort and sound quality ... as long as you stay close to the source. Using either my iPhone 8+, iPad (2018) or Gigabyte GB-BKI5HA-7200 computer; if I get more than 10ft away from the source, the sound breaks up. This is very disappointing as I was hoping I could walk around the room while enjoying my music or having a phone conversation. The manual states a 30ft maximum distance, but it's more like 10-12ft in my experience.

author: JT Mon
title: Great Product / Failed Customer support options
content:
Love the product. One of the best on the market and it should be for the relative price.
Warning about Bose service/support policies.
Just 2 months after the 12 mo warrantee ran out I had the right side of the headset come apart from the headpiece.  The culprit was a small screw which could have easily been shipped to replace the lost one.  I called Bose and the only option they offered was to replace the Unit for about $300. They clearly stated their policy was to replace at a very small and unreasonable trade in. Absolutely ridiculous in this case for a small screw.
Bottom line: Bose repair policy is way out of reasonable and so ridged one cannot imagine.  If I could rate Bose customer support in this case it would be a whopping zero.  It certainly will effect my decision to purchase future Bose products

author: MrBungle
title: Great sound quality, comfortable, and good battery life
content: I am loving these noise-cancelling headphones.  This is the first pair of noise-cancelling I've ever had, and  it's really quite amazing how much noise it blocks out.  When I take them off, it becomes immediately clear what a good job they've been doing.  It seems like because of the rejection of all that outside noise, I can really hear the detail in the music I'm listening to all that much better, which leads to a really great listening experience.  Battery lasts a good long time too, and is easy to charge via mini USB.  No problems pairing with multiple devices via Bluetooth.  Can't wait to take my first flight with these and just cancel out the outside world.  :)

author: Wes N
title: TREAT YO SELF to the Best Noise Cancelling Headphones on the Market
content:
No other way to put it - these are extraordinary. I made the mistake of trying these on at some point in the past, being amazed, then attempting to duplicate the experience with a much cheaper substitute. The quality of the the noise cancellation, the quality of the sound, the comfort, and the physical construction are all far, far superior on the Bose device. If you are looking for the best noise cancelling experience around, you'll need to pay for it, and you will likely not be disappointed here.

Just a word about expectations: these cancel ambient, background noise: airplanes, airports, air conditioners, white noise, etc. They do not silence (or really even quiet) conversation, screaming babies, fireworks, shotgun blasts, pneumatic tools, bowling alleys, breaking glass, car alarms, fire alarms, carbon monoxide alarms, falling cookware, crash symbols, and the like.

Cheaper headphones also produce poor sound quality that seems to be affected by their own noise cancellation. With Bose, you're getting top quality noise cancellation without sacrificing in sound quality - and that's sound that's coming from Bose speakers! If you fancy yourself ANY flavor of audiophile, some headphones of this quality will be your baseline. Cheaper imitations warrant no discussion.

The battery life is excellent, and they charge quickly. These are not the cheapest headphones in town, but in this reviewer's opinion, they are the best.

author: Sue Fowler
title: Headphones Do Not Work With New Generation 9 Kindle Fire
content:
I have two other Bose headphones that worked seamlessly with my Kindle fire tablets in the past and I would have loved to keep this new set if I could... unfortunately Amazon's gen 9 kindle tablets no longer allow Apps from Unknown Sources, to allow the Bose connect app to be download to the tablet.  Without the app, Bose will not allow connection.  Of course, the app is not available on Amazon but on Google Play which is blocked by the new "Unknown Source" requirement.

If you buy any headphones, there should not be a requirement to down an app first before you can use it.  Or at least put in the ad that they will not work with the new Generation 9 Kindles.

As long as Bose requires this download, I'm done with the company.

author: Rae
title: Love them -- definitely worth the money!
content: Love these so much!  I really researched and read many, many reviews on different noise cancelling headphones and decided to go with these.  Even though they were more expensive, I didn't want to spend less and hate them.  I'm so glad I did.  They are everything I was looking for.  They are very comfortable (even with glasses/sunglasses), love that they sync to my phone, sound is great (even with wireless), battery charge lasts a long time (as long as you remember to turn them off if you have to take them off & set them down), and the biggie is that the noise cancellation works like a dream!  I use them mostly at work where I can concentrate.  If you don't have music on you can hear muffled voices, but other sounds are damped down.  With music on I don't hear much of anything around me.  Definitely worth the money!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Perfect for studying
content: I originally used a pair of headphones meant for the shooting range whenever I studied. However, there would be situations where I would still be disrupted or distracted by conversation if it was loud enough; these headphones have been essential for proper studying ever since then. They’re comfortable, last a long time, and will only allow outside noise to distract your music if it’s ridiculously loud. I love these headphones, definitely worth the money. (and the google assistant is pretty convenient whenever you get notifications, which is a plus.)

author: Arman Fazeli Chaghooshi
title: Was working fine until the update
content: The noise cancellation feature has been destroyed by the last update. I am really really disappointed. It's been a month with no official resolution from Bose. I strongly recommend you to stay away from Bose until they get their <thing> together and fix this. I am not into conspiracy theories and I am truly hopeful that this screw-up was not on purpose in order to sell the newer headphones.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good in overall but sound quality can be improved.
content: This pair of headset is comfort to wear and battery lasts long enough before the end of the day when you start to charge it. The only deficiency of this product is that it only supports AAC and SBC codec which render the transfer rate  to be 320 kbps in maximum; while for its competitor, SONY wh-1000xm3, the transfer rate of its specific design(LDAC codec) makes it able to transfer up to 990kbps of music. So no wonder people are arguing the impressive sound quality of SONY wh-1000xm3. Yet SONY wh-1000xm3 is king of "notorious" for its discomfort of long-time wearing. So in the end it's a trade off between comfort and sound quality. I choose more comfortable QuietComfort 35 ii as I will be wearing my blue-tooth for hours.

title: Ambivalent feelings...
content:
I’m not totally satisfied with this product.

Cons: For almost $400 I was expecting that you can actually pair it with devices. Yeah, whenever it feels like it, it would pair with devices. Other times you can just spend an hour, trying everything to make it work, and it still doesn’t work. “Pairing Unsuccessful”. No hints, either.

Pros: When it actually works, it works very well. Great noise canceling, good sound quality. My co-worker who speaks super loud sounds like a talking mouse on the TV in the next room. It’s quite comfortable, but sometimes I feel pressure at the top of my head when it touches it.

author: Robert M.
title: A little let down...
content:
I love the way they sound but was very let down to find out that they do not support aptX-Low Latency codec.

I had planned to use them for late nite TV and there is very noticeable lag on the audio.

I tried the BOSE website to look around for future updates or work arounds but found none (really surprising for top line headphones and the price).

author: Carl Haupt
title: I desired a better range but also needed something with supreme comfort as ...
content:
If you prize comfort these are the headphones for you but it will come at the (small) cost of sound quality.

I decided to pick up some ANC headphones after getting tired of the in ear buds I had been using for years. I desired a better range but also needed something with supreme comfort as I listen for hours on end while studying. A lot of people have been comparing these to a couple other sets so I will leave my thoughts around those as well.

QCII: Best comfort. Well-rounded sound. Great build quality (glass fiber reinforced nylon, or so I have read). User replaceable ear pads. One thing to note is the good but uninspiring sound. It is far from poor but it has sort of a muted feel. I suppose this allows them to have good marks across a wide range of genres. Can't blame them for that. I'm satisfied with the sound as they are definitely an improvement from the hf5 buds I had been using. Google assistant is cool but I don't care about it. I have that button set to adjust ANC (high, low or off). Where is the airplane adapter? Stupid to leave it out. Also to consider - there are massive issues with Bluetooth pairing in Windows 7. It can be argued that this is not their responsibility but it's still frustrating. For those having issues search up Toshiba Bluetooth drivers for Bose - this workaround solved the issue for me. Also note that this issue is not specific to Bose. The Win7 Bluetooth stack is just garbage so you may have issues pairing with any modern wireless device.

Sony WH-1000XM2: Definitely wins in the features category. Superior battery life, more lively sound, great equalizer customization in the app, touch controls and LDAC support. I kept finding myself wanting to listen to these more than the QCII. However, I could not overlook the build quality issues with reports of headband cracking. Unacceptable and not worth the risk for me. Also, I have larger ears and they were less comfortable with noticeable heating. The QCII have more space within the ear cups. The pads also got quite thin at the base of the ear during wear. This didn't compromise the seal but after removal it stayed flat and did not readily go back to a plush conformation. This may seem like a very particular critique but longevity is a concern for me and I could not help but think how long the cushioning would last. Add on top the fact that you cannot replace the ear pads and I had to rule them out.

B&W PX: Amazing sound and superb sound stage. Unfortunately, too many negatives. They are heavy and caused a hot spot at the top of my head after less than an hour of use. The build quality was amazing and they looked fantastic but it was just too much weight. Sound quality takes a big hit with ANC enabled. You also cannot use them passively without battery power. They also do not collapse for easy storage. It's a shame since they sounded so good but I could not live with these downsides. Maybe the next version will fix some of these issues. I've read the P7 is a good option for those not requiring ANC.

Ultimately it depends what you value. The combination of comfort and build quality with above average sound is what sold me. I hate to compromise but that's what you need to do at this price point. An ideal product would incorporate the Bose comfort, B&W sound and Sony features.

author: Mark  Customer
title: Do NOT buy for PC use!
content: Work ok with cell phone.....BUT WORTHLESS if you're running Windows 7 and many times Windows 10.  Nearly impossible to get sound from Windows 7.  I spent hours and hours researching and found SOMETIMES SOME fixes will work....MANY times just temporary.  I've done everything.  Bose says not their problem but they sell the damn things so it IS THEIR EFFING PROBLEM.  There are pages and pages and pages of people struggling for MONTHS trying to get these QC35's to work with windows 7 (both home and professional). I'm not going to devote my life to TRYING to make this work.  For $350 they should jump out of the box and connect themselves and then jump right onto my head.  SENDING THEM BACK AS MY MAIN USE IS PC.

author: Francisco Guerra
title: Bose Vs Sony
content:
I was tore between the Bose QuietComfort 35ii and the Sony WH1000XM2 so i ordered both to compared. I received the Sony first and used them for a couple of days off and on with one session being 2 hrs. The features of these are awesome! So easy to setup and use. The app was also easy and lots of features to adjust the headphones. The touch pad though sensitive, i got used to keeping my hand away from it except when needed and i really like the Pause feature and Vol. The noise cancellation is top notch and the best of the two. I could not hear anything outside the headphone and a muffle sound when my wife was talking to me. Sound is amazing though i thought it was a little bass heavy.  My initial feeling was it was definitely a keeper! But that changed after that 2 hr session. The headphone started to feel heavy and though i am not to sensitive to the use of head gear as i ride a motorcycle and spent many many years on a US Navy Flight Deck, the headphone were getting a bit warm and uncomfortable around the ears.
I received the Bose and was just as easy to set up. The app is not as feature rich as the Sony but has the basics required. Used the Bose for a 2 hr session also and though it was a bit warm also not as much as the Sony. It was not as heavy as the Sony. The sound on the Bose was not as detailed as the Sony but pretty close on all the genres of music i listen to.  I also noticed that the distance between the Bluetooth source and the headphones on the Bose is not as far as the Sony but plenty of distance. The Noise Cancellation is not as good as the Sony but it did muffle most sounds around though i was able to hear the floor fan and i could talk to my wife without taking the headphones off. The controls on the Bose seem primitive compared to the Sony but it works well and easy to use.
In the end, i ended up keeping the Bose as they were more comfortable to wear for extended times. If i was just looking for a headphone for short periods of use, I would definitely go with the Sony but I needed these headphones for use of extended times. The sound is solid and enjoyable and the Noise Cancellation feature is tolerable.
Once i get more use and utilize more of its features, i will update.

author: Ken Scott
title: Not worth 1/4 of the money
content: I fully charged then and brought them on an international flight. What a waste of money. On "full" noise cancellation level I could hear mostly the engine noise of the plane. These are far worse than the previous Bose ear bud noise cancelling earphones. I heard the loud sound of the engine, babies crying, people talking. I had the noise cancelling level on "high" and it seemed they were barely doing their job. And they are so bulky that you cannot lean your head in any direction to get some shut eye on the plane. Then, on top of all that, they heat up your ears too much. You can't wait to pull them off.  Don't buy these.

author: Joe E.
title: Poor performance. Loud and annoying crackling noise when airplane takes-off or lands.
content: First time I used my new headset on a flight this week.  I settled in my seat and set the headset's noise cancelling level to high, connected to my phone and began listing to music.  Everything was good.  However I about jumped out of my seat once the jet engines revved up for takeoff. There was a loud, pronounced, and annoying crackling noise in both sides of the headset that lasted until we were airborne.  The same thing happened after touchdown when the jet engine's reverse thrusters kicked-in.  It seems the noise cancelling capabilities were overwhelmed and couldn't handle level of noise produced by the jet engines during take-off and landing.  I never experienced this problem with my old Bose Quiet Comfort 25 headset.  Also, they performed very poorly cancelling out voice conversations around me, a baby crying behind me, and the flight attendant's intercom announcement.  My old Bose QuietComfort 25 were excellent at cancelling out all these sounds.  After the flight, I searched on Bose's web site and found that mine was not an isolated experience.  Others shared similar experiences with their headsets and were equally disappointed. Bose tech support posted replies to the complaints stating that is was normal.  Needless to say I'm very disappointment with the performance of the QuietComfort 35 (Series II) and will be returning them for a refund.  I've read good things about Sony's latest noise cancelling headset and will give them a try.  Bose needs to address these performance issues or risk losing more customers.

author: SBK
title: The Best of the Best
content: I needed a good hi-fidelity headset for the calls I make for work.  I have international meetings and didn't find any headsets with both great sound and excellent microphone until I purchased the Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series II) Wireless Headphones, Noise Cancelling.  Yes they are expensive, but sometimes you get what you pay for.  They are extremely comfortable to wear for long periods.  They last 8 hours on one charge and quickly recharge.  The only observation I have which is not a criticism, is that the Noise Cancelling is so effective that family and colleagues need to physically get my attention because I can't hear any outside noise.  The Bose are great for music and fantastic as a headset.  They connect to my iphone, ipad and PC.

author: Mr&MrsV
title: The best choice vs. the comparable Sony headphones
content:
(FYI, I also posted a similar review on the Amazon page of the Sony WH1000XM2.)

I'll keep it short. I read the reviews of the Sony WH1000XM2 and the Bose QuietComfort 35 II and could not decide which to choose, so I bought both. I returned the Sony and kept the Bose. Here are the pros and cons:

Sony:
+ Crisper highs and deeper bass (I can't see how anyone says the Bose model sounds better)
+ Better song navigation with the figure gestures on side of right headpiece
- When making phone calls, those on the other end hear more of your background noise than on the Bose (I tested by calling from a land line to a family member who used my Sonys)
- Heavy on the head and hurts to wear for long periods (this was a deal breaker for me)
- Finger navigation feature is too sensitive sometimes - easy to skip/rewind songs by accident.

Bose
+ Great noise cancellation, especially with no music (better than Sony's)
+ Light weight and definitely more comfortable for long periods
+ Best for phone calls (those on other end don't hear much background noise)
- Sound is missing crispness at high and low ends; overall sounds are a bit muffled (it would be great to get Sony's sound on these speakers). If music quality is your deal breaker, buy the Sonys for sure.

In the end, I couldn't get over the uncomfortable aspect of the Sonys. I really preferred the Sony sound, but didn't see myself wearing the Sonys for long periods of time. My primary reason for buying these was muffling office and plane engine noise for long periods of time, therefore comfort was a deal breaker. It also helps that I can take conference calls on the Bose headsets and not worry about those on the other end hearing lots of background noise.

Both lose one star due to their respective shortcomings, but for my use the Bose was the winner. After owning them for about 5 months, I'm very happy I chose them. Really great product.

author: Tina
title: A bit expensive for sound quality
content: It blocks out low frequency noise like a plane engine but I could still hear a baby crying in the background. The sound is good for music when listening via Bluetooth but the sound is only ok for movies and shows with the cable. With the rumble of the plane engine, it almost wasn't loud enough to hear the dialogue. I had to turn the volume on my tablet up all the way.

author: Sam B
title: Never knew what I was missing
content:
These are phenomenal headphones. I didn't realize the kinds of ambient noise I had around me until after I used this for a while. I bought other fancy headphones in the past, which usually had cables and ended up broken when I tripped across it. These are wireless, with a volume control built in. (You can still plug them in if you like, but I never do that.)

When I got them in the mail, they worked perfectly. Then, after an update, for a while, the software was a bit glitchy and would randomly beep. But at some point they must've fixed that in another update, after a year or so. Because they work perfectly again.

One downside is that the microphone isn't really worth having on it. In order to use the microphone, you have to put the headphones into "headset" "communications device" mode, which doesn't properly do sound cancelling. Worse, it sounds like someone is playing back the audio from outside the headphones. I never use that mode, because I can't stand it.

I also wish that I could stream (mix) two wireless sources at once. While speaking on the microphone. I often want to listen to a show on one device, and a video game on another, while possibly talking into a microphone. There isn't a solution for this. For my purpose, I connect to a small bluetooth adapter, and plug that into the line-in jack on my PC. Then I check the "listen to this" button for that line-in, so that I can hear the second audio source.

But despite any and all drawbacks, I am very happy with my headphones and would buy them again.

author: E
title: Rose gold very cute, definitely a novelty bose item
content:
i've loved bose for a long time and always dreamed of the day that i would finally purchase one of their products. i was pretty set on getting the silver QC35 II's and then they came out when the rose gold color and that one sold me. I would have liked more if the white portion was also rose gold. i try not to wear them when i'm wearing face make up or i was my face/hair before wearing them because i don't want to get those white portions dirty. very simple to use. nice rounded sound, could use more bass unfortunately. noise cancellation is great, i use it when sleeping at my gf's house because her family is very loud.
unfortunately, you can't pair this to anything, even if you download the bose connect+ app. it only pairs to my iphone via bluetooth. if i want to listen to music using this headphone on my laptop or old android phone, i need to use the wire. i'm going to see if it connects via bluetooth to modern samsung phones soon. really wish it could at least pair to my laptop.
it's a bit heavy on your head at first, but you get used to it. i'm still too scared to wear it in public because it's so pretty i feel like someone will just run by and steal it off my head if i'm not paying attention.
i really don't use the google assistant/alexa button ever. if you use siri or whatever a lot, it would be useful to you.
calls are crystal and people say i sound clear. people have said if i have the volume about halfway, they can hear what i'm listening to, which i don't like.
overall, these headphones are a gem. definitely very expensive, but i plan on using these for a very long time. battery life is good. i'm not a heavy headphone user. i've charged it once since getting it (couple months ago) and have just reached 60%.

author: Amanda
title: Great for studying
content:
I bought these to use in the library for studying and for working around the house. Works well with music and the spoken word.
In the library:  The noise cancellation is great. Oftentimes that alone is good enough to let me fall into the level of concentration necessary for my studies. Otherwise, a rainfall white noise track on youtube does the trick and I can't hear ANYTHING around me.
Around the house:  Keeps the bluetooth connection very well for several feet or if my phone's in my back pocket. My house is very long, and I normally have to walk around a wall before it will start to cut out.

author: Hadrien Dykiel
title: Nice headphones with too many quirks
content:
These headphones are certainly nice, but have too many quirky issues for their high price point:

Issue #1 - noice cancelling crackles during airplane takeoff. Given Bose sells aviation headsets, this is something they should have figured out how to do but for reason the roar of the airplane engines is too high for the headphones noise cancellation system to handle.

Issue #2 - audio will cut out out of the blue when connected to multiple devices. For example, if you are connected to your computer's bluetooth for a very important Zoom or Webex meeting and you forgot to turn off your phone's bluetooth, you will lose your computer audio at some point during the call, quite unexpectedly. You will then be left to fumble your phone to try and disconnect the phone bluetooth connection and get your computer audio working again, all while the other people on the line are wondering why you're no longer responding.

Issue #3 - After about 6 months of using these headphones, the right side no longer plays any sound while connected to computer audio. Thankfully, this is something Bose support offered to fix at no charge, however they seem to be unable to send me the return shipping label so I do not know if this will get resolved or not.

To recap, these headphones emit high quality Bose-like sound but I cannot recommend them because of various usability issues which appear to have been overlooked when designing these.

author: B. K.
title: Works great for focusing on audio/video at places with loud ambient noises
content:
I'm using these to do some transcription and video coding work, and I was surprised at how well they blocked out noises at cafes (the cafe music and espresso machine, any echoes from people's conversations), and construction work next door to my house (which will be going on for ALL summer). Before, I never would have considered doing this kind of work (where I have to pay attention to audio very carefully) at a cafe, but these headphones enable me to do so! If you're not listening to any audio while using the noise-canceling feature, you can still hear people's conversations, but a lot of the ambient noise is cancelled out.

They are very comfortable over the ears and don't squeeze my head (or earrings) like many other headphones do. The only uncomfortable bit I've found is the top of the headphone band that rests on my head, but because the headphones are fairly light, it's not so bad.

The headphones come with a cord to directly connect to a device (I use this when I don't need to use the noise-canceling feature and want to save on battery), and the case is nice and sturdy, so I'm not worried about my expensive headphones getting crushed or damaged when jammed into my bag full of books and other junk.

I also like that the buttons are easy to find while wearing the headphones, so I can pause and play video/audio without having to click out of any note-taking windows I have up on my computer.

I was lucky to have some research funds to buy this item. Otherwise, I'm not sure if I'd be willing to shell out $300+ for this. If cost is an issue, I'd probably recommend that you rely on cheaper headphones and find quieter places to work if that is an option for you.

author: Thomas Hackett
title: Great for music.... sucks for calls and bluetooth cuts out
content:
I don't know if NOW it is normal to have an echo while ON a call with these headphones.  Bought these for my wife so she can be free of wires and not have to constantly change out batteries.  Sound quality and noise cancellation is way beyond satisfactory.  Although, while making a call, it seems that you are using a web based platform, like Skype or Discord.  You can hear an echo if you have a tv in the background, or you can hear someone typing as if their phone was right at the keyboard.  Was told by a Bose agent via chat  "Karla at 14:18, Sep 18: The QC 35 has a side-tone feature. And it is perfectly normal for it to have an echo."  Wow.  Whatever this "side tone feature" is, its crap.

Another thing is that the bluetooth would cut out and disconnect at random times.  Just got these not too long ago and it worked fine until a few days ago.  The headset would say "disconnected from XXX" and then reconnect a few seconds later.. or having to reconnect manually.  Did an update to the Bose Connect app as well, which didn't fix the connection issue.  You can connect with the aux cord they provide, but what is the point of having it being hands free?  Anyway, if you like having your music drown out everything else around you, these are great.  Just don't use them for calls.  You're better off NOT using them.

author: Niko
title: Great headphones but hard to justify cost as a casual listener
content:
I got these headphones as a gift and in one word they are great. There are many detailed reviews from self-proclaimed audiophiles on here, so I won't waste time trying to write my own. I'll just make note that while these headphones are amazing, they didn't blow me away. Prior to owning these, I owned the Cowin E7 bluetooth noise canceling headphones for almost year. Make no mistake, these Bose headphones are a lot better than the budget friendly Cowin E7s, which cost roughly $70. But for me the QC 35 just didn't offer a big enough bump in my listening experience to justify the price difference.

That being said, I am a casual music listener. When I listen to music, I am usually doing something else and I don't often focus on the music itself. I just want my headphones to produce clear music that sound reasonably close to the original recording. I can live with minor distortions and I don't need feel as like I'm in a live studio.

Other things to note:
- I don't find these headphones to be super comfortable. I know I'm in the minority here, but the cups squeeze a bit too tight for my liking.
- As others have noted, the "noise canceling" aspect is more like "noise muffling" of certain frequencies. Not a bad thing per se, but just be aware that you'll still be able to hear a conversation happening next to you.
- While the bluetooth works well most of the time, I occasionally have connectivity issues. I sometimes have to disconnect/reconnect a few times to get things going.

Bottom line:
These headphones are amazing and are probably the best on the market. However, I think most people would be just as happy with cheaper alternatives. If you're a casual listener, who mostly plays music in the background, I would recommend saving your money and getting something cheaper.

author: Tyler W.
title: If you're a student, these are a great buy
content: These headphones have been a lifesaver. While studying in public or at the library, their noise-cancelling function has been pretty great. While most reviews online suggest the Sony WH-1000XM3 for the best noise cancelling, I decided to go with Bose because of the comfort benefit over its competitors. Boy, am I happy about that. I typically get headaches when I have any headphones on for more than 20 minutes, but with the QuietComfort headphones I can leave these on for hours and not have an issue. Sound quality is fantastic. I've heard complaints from friends that the base doesn't perform as well as other headphones on the market, but I personally haven't had this issue. highly recommend

author: Kindle Customer
title: BUY!!!!!!!!! BUY!!!!!!!!!!!! BUY!!!!!!!!!!!!!! These things will change you!! If anything can save a Marriage its these, LOL!!!
content: These Sound SO GOOD, work So well and Feel so good that you should be begging me to stop buying them so I can leave some for everyone else. I bought 2 pairs of this one for myself and one for my father. These things can save marriages and relationships by the droves. I combined these with a Lenovo Yoga Tab3 and a 27000mAh and I love it!!!! Sounds superb, the software works excellent and is easy to use. these things tune themselves in a sense and they sound Fantastic.  Anything sounds wonderful in the s they have excellent bass and clarity all mixed into one. If you are thinking about a set of Beats headphones, check these out first... I'm telling you they are worth every penny, durable as all get out and I have been using them nonstop since I got them. I am listening to music through them right now while writing this review.

author: Pat McDermott
title: These are not worth the price tag, I returned them.
content: I bought these to use to block out the noise in my office, to listen to music, and to make conference calls on the phone and computer.  They blocked noise while listening to music but when on calls they actually pick up noises from around me and transmit the noises into the headphones and to the people I was speaking with, the exact opposite of what they should be doing.  On calls everyone had problems understanding me and I had to switch to a landline headset every time.  People said they could hear people in my office about 15 feet away better than they could hear me.  I really expected more out of a $350 set of headphones.  I have owned free earbuds that came with my phone that did a better job at canceling out background noise through the microphone.  I looked up the issue on Bose support forums and they have known about the issue for a while and have just basically shrugged and told customers that they would have to live with it.  When asked if there would be a software fix they claim they never know what might be in the next release.  The headphones and the lack of service are not worth the price tag, I returned them.

author: J. Summers
title: Non-Bluetooth Was Better
content:
I've used Bose headphones for 7 years now, and they're lifesavers for someone who's noise-sensitive like me.  Previous models were great against roommates, neighbors, etc. and great for traveling.  I finally opted to upgrade to bluetooth "for convenience."  Sigh.  The promise is so rarely as good as the reality.

BLUETOOTH PROBLEMS
The bluetooth will only support two devices at once.  "No problem, who uses 3 devices at once?" I thought.  Well, what they don't tell you is that it won't auto-switch between devices, so you are constantly opening the app to adjust devices if you need to switch between MORE THAN ONE.  Why one?  Because one of them always has to be your phone to use the bloody app!  So, it really only supports your phone plus one.

Bluetooth randomly disconnects.  And randomly tries to connect, beeping and beeping in your ear or just failing completely.  Pain in the @$$.

App constantly forgets the device, tries to connect with other people's devices, creates delays while it figures things out, etc.  Pain in the @$$.

NOISE CANCELLING
Noise cancelling isn't as good as previous models.  You can't just turn on the noise cancelling either like you could with the others.  It has to be audio on.

APP
App is a stupid, pathetic piece of garbage.  It's slow to connect, it's a pain to manage connections that CONSTANTLY need to be managed (HIDDEN IN A SECONDARY MENU - ARE YOU F'ING KIDDING ME!?).  And even with the stupid app I shouldn't have to use, I still can't adjust sound quality.

BASS
Bass is too strong and un-smooth.  And there's no way to adjust it.  I can't listen to some of my favorite songs through these headphones.

All I can say is that Bose better get their act together or I'm finally following my friends to other brands.

author: Arthur Zatarain
title: Excellent product, but wired users may not like the 2.5 mm audio jack.
content: I selected the Bose 35ii after extensive research and am very pleased with comfort, audio quality, and performance. A key aspect of my selection was the wired connection that I often need, as with in-flight entertainment systems. (I would have bought the Bose 30 earbud design but, amazingly, it lacks a wired connection). My only disappointment with the 35ii is that the audio jack is not the standard 3.5 mm (1/8 inch) style that we have known and loved for about 50 years. Instead, the phones have a 2.5 mm jack. I did not see this noted in any of the many reviews that I read---they all mention a standard audio connection. The phones come with a cable that plugs into the 2.5 mm jack and provides a standard 3.5 mm plug on the other end. But for the life of me I cannot even guess why a 3.5 mm wasn't used on the phones themselves so that any standard cable could be used. So if wired connection is important to you be advised that you may wantto buy an additional (more robust and longer) adapter cable, and I do see some on Amazon. Apparently the smaller jack is used on other headphones as well.  But why? Makes no sense to me.

author: Bruce B
title: Great headphones with a not so good required app to control settings
content: The headset works great. The app required to control it not so well. I have used several models of noise cancelling headphones, primarily Koss, for many years. Koss no longer makes a comparable product and a friend recommended this product. For noise cancellation and sound quality it works great, probably the best I have ever used on a flight. But the app, which is required to change any settings on the headset, is clunky and hard to navigate.

author: sEhm
title: *SAFETY FIRST*  High Grade ear muffs #muffs
content: Welp!  These work brilliantly.  THey drown out loud phone lady with the best noise canceling I’ve ever heard.  Or not heard.  Either way I can’t hear the dumb stuff that comes out of her mouth.  I can also jam baby making music or holiday tunes as loud as I want without disturbing the judgey squares. It provides immediately on voice command meditation music so I don’t kill anyone.  That Alexa and Google Assistant that come with the headphones are my real beaches.  I’m over here telling them to make me coffee in the kitchen while I’m working in my office.  They do it.  They don’t fuss.  But really.  If you can afford them, buy them.  My sweet husband bought them for me for my birthday.  He knows I need safety ear muffs.

author: Flyboy
title: Bluetooth connection is a nightmare
content:
The sound on the unit is exceptional. One of the best I've heard -- when you can get it to work.  Bluetooth setup can be a nightmare, and differs from device to device.  Bose gives several excuses on their website as to why this might be - none of them valid (one of their suggestions was to make sure the unit is turned on).  The headphones stutter when played on PC, but work great through a smartphone -- until a firmware update happens.  Then you've got to drop all of the connections, clear out Bluetooth and try again...and again....and again....  I love the sound, but hate the headphones. For the cost, I should love both. You failed on this one, Bose.

Update: I'm standing behind this being a bluetooth nightmare, but I figured out what the problem was (with no help from Bose). I've got a metal desk, and I'm guessing this is a problem because when I moved the bt dongle from the back of the PC to the front, the issue cleared up immediately.  Now, they sound great and maintain their connection. I changed the review to 4 stars, but I'd happily give it 5 stars had I not had such a problem in the first place.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excellent sound, comfortable, good for telephone, but a bit fragile in material.
content: Note this review is from a very recent owner, so no idea how well these headphones will hold up in the long-term. Music sound quality is excellent. Talking on the telephone is good both for the user and the person at the other end. Noise cancellation works decently but don't expect this to be of construction quality if you like listening to music while using jackhammers.  Material quality seems fragile, the item appears prone to easy breakage/tearing. The provided semi-hard case is protective but not crush-resistant.  In the online instruction book if you want to find how out how to watch movies on airplanes using the headphones, good luck finding the answer; you have to plough elsewhere through reviews and ‘questions asked’ for the answer. No airline adapter is included; apparently the headphones can be used with the provided cable on many airlines (but I have not tested this). The headphones work well for a phone or laptop without apps so consider staying away from all the associated apps if you have privacy concerns.

author: Heidi
title: Kick back and relax with these
content: The new style of Bose headphones are awesome! I decided to upgrade from the Bose Quiet 35 to wireless. While nothing was wrong with my old pair, I must say that not having to deal with a cord anymore is amazing and was one of the driving factors in getting a new pair. I travel quite often and the cord would constantly get in the way when I was shuffling through my bag or getting situated in my seat. Technology is always advancing and the Bluetooth capability is a nice added feature that my old pair did not have. Although the price is high, I am happy with my purchase. Bose creates a good quality product that I would highly recommend to anyone. Especially if you are constantly on airplanes and want to completely drown out all background noise.

author: Mike B.
title: Superb sound. Bluetooth range is poor.
content: I purchased these upon the recommendations of a leading consumer magazine. My use for them is primarily for listening to music. In the review of the consumer magazine, it stated the claimed Bluetooth range to be 30 feet, which is the typical limit for such devices. Apparently they did not test them for this, which I find disappointing. Some of the reviews here reflect my own experience, as I can barely walk out of the room while using them. At a distance of 10 to 15 feet, the Bluetooth connection drops out when I move my head slightly from side to side. Bose claims high sound quality at all listening levels, and for the most part, I would agree. I would guess  it would involve provision for equal-loudness contour adjustment, so at low volume,  low and high frequencies would be boosted slightly. At any rate, I have found listening at low volume using noise cancellation to be very good. I am not, however, impressed with the Bluetooth range. I have several MUCH cheaper headphones and earbuds that have better Bluetooth performance.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The Noise Cancelling Headphone
content: All the other noise canceling has a brand name or serious name, but this one is THE NOISE CANCELLING HEADPHONE. I have been using Bose QC25 for 5 years, it was amazingly comfortable I actually slept with it on. But when the cellphone maker no longer put 3.5mm jack hole on their smart phones, I know it is the time to make a change. I waited for the Bose NC 700, but when I finally got it, it was a totally disaster. The new design makes it look cheap and hippie, the 10 level noise cancelling is not necessary at all, the new clamp design put extra pressure on head. I had to return that. Then I turned to Sony WH-1000XM3, because I have heard so many times from my friends that how much progress Sony has made to create this headphone that finally beat the Bose. But again it was another headphone with noise cancelling function. Although it has a good sound quality as any other Sony headphone, but it is not necessary for any situation when you need to turn the noise cancelling function. The other hand is that it is less flexible and wide compared to Bose25/35, so the top and side of your head will have pressure feeling after one hour. Finally I had to go back to someone I am familiar with - Bose QC35ii. When I put it on, the same comfortable feeling that I could wear to sleep for whole night, state of the art noise cancelling function, excellent sounds quality for music and movie and a phone call, last but not the least, bluetooth connection and no AAA batteries anymore. That is THE NOISE CANCELLING HEADPHONE.

author: John Lovelock
title: They're Bose, their reputation trumps any review.
content: But here goes ... Fantastic headphones, so glad I saved for them and finally took the leap to buy. As soon as you put these things over your ears and power on, it's remarkable how much noise they cancel out .. and when the music starts, that's all you hear. In-between tracks you might hear some faint conversations around you, but once the music starts playing again you are back in your own world. Music sounds great thru them, and the bass (whatever level of volume you are listening to) is pitch perfect. The Google assistant (via my Android phone) works brilliantly, hands free, talk-back via the headphones is outstanding. The android app is ok, but a little annoying that it has to restart every time you go back to it even though the headphones remain active. The headphones are very comfortable, they fit like a glove ... I am extremely happy with them. Bose ... the best !

author: Caroline Powell
title: Broken
content: Unfortunately, I think mine came broken.  I bought them for work to cut down on extra noise and also to bring with me when I traveled for work.  The left side works perfectly, but there is something loose in the right side that I cannot seem to figure out and it rattles when the headphones vibrate, which is almost constant since sound is vibration.  Due to the close proximity to my ear, it hurts my ears too much to use and defeats the purpose of having noise cancelling headphones.  I'm probably going to send them back.  My coworker has the same headphones and his work perfectly, so I think it's just my specific pair.

author: Larry Cornett
title: Most comfortable over-ear headphones I've owned
content:
I bought the Bose QuietComfort headphones just in time for a long international flight (over 15 hours). I couldn't be happier with them. They are the most comfortable over-ear headphones I've owned. They're light and cushy enough to rest over my ear and not crush the cartilage. I wore them for hours with no discomfort.

The battery life is excellent and they're easy to recharge. The noise canceling is pretty amazing. It provides 3 levels of cancellation and you don't realize how much it is doing until you switch it off. You'll still hear some minor background noise (like the sound of the jet engines), but it is very quiet and not noticeable when music is playing.

The sound quality is very good. The Bluetooth connects seamlessly to multiple devices, both my phone and laptop. I have also been using them for phone calls and the microphone works well. The noise canceling makes phone calls much clearer than my AirPods.

author: Dan Hahn
title: Traded Bose QC for these
content: I bought the latest Bose QCs and found them to be quiet and shockingly un-intuitive. I exchanged them for these and have been very pleased. The sound quality is way better, they are louder, and the app interface is dynamite. The noise-cancelling capability is so deep it borders on creepy. When you turn off the noise cancelling function, you get this wild rush of ambient noise that you completely forget exists when you are wired in. It is crazy how much sound these actually cut out. The interactive ear cups are also great as they give you the ability to work seamlessly almost forgetting your headphones are on. If you are making a choice between these and the comparable Bose product, go ahead and get these. Sony usually sounds like what you get if you need headphones and only have 30 bucks, but this product places them at the head of the table in the noise-cancelling realm.

author: Benjamin L.
title: Excellent noise cancellation and sound clarity.
content:
I’ve tested other brands noise canceling headphones and these Bose headphones were by far the best in the area of external noise cancellation. Clarity of music and Bluetooth phone capability is also exquisite. The microphone in the headset also works very well while using the Bluetooth feature to make phone calls. The speaker can be heard clearly on the other phone.
During a 737 flight, in a seat near the engine exhaust, as soon as I put on the headphones there was a glorious absence of any sound whatsoever.
While cooking and wearing the headphones, I was completely unaware that I had set off the smoke alarm until someone walked into the kitchen motioning me to remove the headphones, and low and behold that smoke alarm was screaming...
They are also very comfortable to wear for hours on end. They are not heavy which also adds to the comfort.
Battery life is also surprisingly good, even when utilizing the noise cancellation feature, and listening at a higher volume.
Would highly recommend.
I am not being paid or reimbursed for this review. Simply giving some feedback on how impressed I am with these headphones.

author: Cory Foster
title: Most comfortable headphones I’ve used
content: I couldn’t be more happy with these headphones. I am not an audio expert so I can’t get into the technical side of the sound of these headphones, but as a normal everyday listener I would have to say the audio quality is excellent. Call quality, noise cancellation, and battery life is also great. I can not speak to the effectiveness to the personal assistance features of these because I don’t use them. These clamp just enough to hold on to your head but not so tight that they become uncomfortable. The headband and earmuffs are very soft and comfortable. In a climate controlled environment these can be worn all day without any issues but could cause some sweating at ear pads in hotter environments as with most over the ear headphones. Overall, I highly recommend these headphones.

author: HS
title: Noise Cancellation and Sound quality was bad for the price
content:
1)Sound quality wasn't as good as I expected I find myself using my $7.00 earbuds more than this. For the price
that isn't good.

2)Noise cancelling is bad. I can hear everything from conversations to my dog snoring. There are 3 modes: low none and high and there is NO differences between LOW and HIGH. Disappointed.

Overall I am very disappointed for my choice. I do not know if my product is defective or this is how it is.

author: Jake1987
title: Technical issues
content: I get a lot of stutter. It seems like I am not the only one. It actually caused issues with a FFXV for PC. For some reason when the headphones were in 2 way communications mode the game froze every couple seconds. Weird but not a big deal. The thing that kills it is the fact that the sound stutters when I am just listening to YouTube videos. I am right next to the Bluetooth receiver with updated drivers and I still get the stutter. I had the MDX1000 until they cracked and had no issues with the sound or connection. Its disappointing that Sony can figure it out but Bose cant... I guess you have to choose between poor manufacturing quality (Sony) and poor Bluetooth implementation.

author: Era
title: Not surprising...
content:
These headphones are AMAZING. I owned the Bose On-Ear headphones and wanted something that would completely block out other sound, yet remain comfortable. They are fantastic and do both of those things, plus some.
