When the sound canceling option is set to High, it does give me headaches and I can't listen to it that way for very long. When set on Mid, it doesn't affect me as much. I'm not sure why this is the case, but I usually find myself turning off the sound canceling option, completely defeating the purpose of the headphone's main feature. They also heat up very quickly when using the sound cancelling features. The cups are incredibly soft with a leather padding, making them quite comfortable to wear, but I believe this is the main reason they heat up so quickly. I have yet to try different ear cups, but I may do so in the near future. These two reasons are why I had to give them a 4-star rating.

These headphones produce amazing sound, don't get me wrong. I do find myself using my On-Ear headphones more than these, but they're still great. These headphones would be perfect for someone who travels and finds themselves on airplanes often. I know that's rather specific, but blocking out the sound of the plane is an amazing feature. If you're going to pick up these headphones, you MUST download the Bose app to your phone. It isn't necessary to using them, but it is a HUGE help if you find yourself in the same headache-y predicament that I was.

author: jeffrey vincent
title: I like 'em a lot
content: Bought to replace an earlier, wired version. Just great. No wires, a big plus for me. Noise cancelling thing improved significantly, two levels, almost dangerously effective at high. Same Bose sound, which some find a little, what, smarmy? I like it, not an audiophile, admittedly, but I'm 70, the fine points lost to my hearing. One hint, if you don't want the "google assistant" stuff, buy the QC35-1 version for a few bucks less.

author: Jay
title: Good but still disappointed
content:
Will keep review simple: Bose will always be great with noise cancellation. I really like that you're able to change the level of noise cancellation and as always it cancels alot of background noise. I also like that you can use these without having the noise cancelling turned on. Upgraded these from the QC15's which require you to have them turned on. Battery life seems to be alright. Maybe I use mine quite a bit but it seems like they'll need to be charged around once a week. These are super comfortable. I definitely forget I have them on sometimes.

Set up for these was very difficult, both with pairing with my phone and laptop. I had to download the Bose app to connect to my phone which I felt was unnecessary. I've never had this much trouble, even when buying much cheaper brands. I deleted the app after pairing since I've read reviews about the app updating and messing up the headphones. My Biggest disappointment is that you can barely turn your head in any direction without disruptions. For comparison, I bought a generic bluetooth adapter for my QC15 pair and these barely had an issue with disruptions. You basically have to keep your head straight or the music will go in and out. Not sure if other people have experienced this as well.

author: Mr. Scott
title: Product is great, delivery "Not so great"!
content:
Very happy with product, but when I pay close to $400 for an item, I expect the delivery by Amazon (Dynamex) not to
throw the product around on a brick landing.

author: Kubidemon
title: Supremely comfortable. Middling sound quality
content:
I purchased the QC35s2 headphones at the Black Friday special pricing. I own a pair of the now frayed QC15 model. These are absolutely the most comfortable headphones bar none, and the storage box is extremely functional as well.

I do travel quite a bit but am still not a fan of ANC. The QC35 noise cancelling is good, not great. After 2 weeks with the set, I returned them to Amazon. Two main reasons: below average sound quality that made me say “meh” over and over again regardless of music genre. The microphone quality during phone calls was adequate at best.

I have since purchased the B&W P7 wireless as I was looking for better sound quality with acceptable tradeoffs on portability and comfort. I could not be happier.

author: sevyna9
title: Sound limiting, not sound-proof.
content:
For the price, I thought I  wouldn't hear anything once Iput these on,, but I guess that's for people who blast whatever they're listening to.
I travel on planes often and needed something to quiet my surroundings and also for noisy hotels.
I find they do drown out a lot of noise, but aren't totally sound cancelling. I can still hear the murmurs of people talking loudly around me, faintly hear a baby screaming, and definitely heard the chimes when the lav smoke alarm went off.
They were great when I was in a noisy hotel room and didn't want to use earplugs because afraid wouldn't hear the alarm, but used them and my white noise app drowned out the weird stuttering air conditioner, the traffic outside and still heard my alarm in the morning. I thought it would be uncomfortable, but slept soundly. Then noticed after 8 hours of night use, the battery was only at 70%.
Those minimal times I do listen to music loud, I find I don't disturb others around me with sound leakage, which is great too.
So I think it's still worth the cost.
The seller I got mine from (outlet) was an individual who smoked so it about 3 months to get the smell to go away but enjoy the headphones immensely.

author: Virginia
title: I am in LOVE. These have changed my life and my marriage
content: I'm a writer and my husband plays his tv shows and sports or music which really detracts me. I must have ADD or something because I get distracted so easily. In the room I have this ceiling fan that does not know how to move air quietly, the "special silent" motor isn't silent anyore—unless I put on these headphones! I have no idea how they work, but bluetooth connects them to my computer and my phone so I can use them like regular bluetooth speaker headphones. It's summer now and my neighbors always have bbqs with lots of beer. I like to sit by my pool with a glass of wine and write. I can't even hear any of them unless someone shouts I got the silvery ones and am glad I did. They sort of disappear on my head easier than big ol black ones. I have never had pain from these either and wear them all day. When I bought them, I also bought the Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM3 which are actually just as amazing but Bose was just one tiny bit better. But mostly, I didn't like the dull finish on their silvery ones. Looked cheap. sooooo happy with these I'm going to buy my son a pair who is starting college and gets way too distracted by his roommates. His grades are going to improve so much!

author: janel e young
title: Worth EVERY penny!  Seriously.
content:
Never did I ever think I would spend so much money on headphones. I also always previously though people looked goofy and/or pretentious with their enormous headphones. My earbuds are so sleek and convenient. Let me tell you, I was wrong.

Bought this to go on a weekend trip that required me to share a room with a large friend who snores terribly (but swears she doesn’t). Even on the plane, I knew I had made a great purchase but they blocked out the snoring probably 95%. What came through was very faint, almost like a very, very distant white noise machine (of what sound or why you’d want it, who knows). I am very sensitive to noise and a light sleeper in general so these headphones were just a remarkable experience when first turning them on.

I am not on the autism spectrum but, man, I can definitely see why individuals with certain sensitivities and degrees on that spectrum could benefit from wearing noise cancelling headphones. I feel like I’m on my own world where hardly anyone or anything can bug me. I rarely want to take them off when I get to work in the morning!

I now wear these every day on my 2.5 mi walking commute to work across DC. I listen to podcasts and the low noise cancelling feature is great for traffic bc it cancels out most of the blaring sirens, jake breaks and car horns but still allows you to hear them enough to be aware of your surroundings. You can also hear voices enough to tell if someone is talking to you or asking for directions. I just press pause to listen and then play to continue.

My only (very small) complaint is that unless you sleep on your back, they are not very comfortable to sleep with. I have pretty noisy upstairs and next door neighbors. Just a poorly constructed, small condo building with thin walls and objectively *awful* squeaky floorboards. The headphones cancel all that out but due to their bulkiness, it is uncomfortable to have them pressing against your ear/head when on your side or stomach. This is the only way I can sleep so I feel like I’m trading one thing for another in order to sleep well. Still, I’ll take this over that!

Thanks Bose!!!

author: cz85b
title: Comfortable and definitely Quiet!
content:
I am really liking these for the connectivity, as in the bluetooth connection is always solid and dependable...  I am able to have them on my head for longer periods of time.  This being said, I ALSO own a set of Bang & Olufsen Beoplay H9i headphones.  I will say that compared with the Bose, the sound from the B&O is much better, to me.

In my mind it will depend on what people want.  IF you have your phone connected to many different competing sound systems (my car sometimes connects while I have my B&O headphones on and that just sucks!) Anyway, if you want your connection to be undisturbed, the Bose is superior.  If you are wearing them for long periods of time, the Bose is Superior.  However, if you want better sound?  B&O is the clear winner!

author: Mars
title: Brilliant
content:
I bought these to allow me to listen to streaming music while mowing the lawn, which they do brilliantly.  If you have never used a noise-cancelling headset before, you will be amazed.  When I switch them on, the mower noise just drops into the background.
A thoughtful feature is the ability to select several levels of noise-cancellation, or none.  If you want to talk with someone, pressing a button on an earcup allows you to hear normally, eliminating the need to take the headphones off.  It's a small thing, but it's the sort of extra touch that Bose is known for, and which makes their products so usable.
If you use them infrequently, you may find yourself fumbling with which button does what, but that's just a learning-curve thing.  I haven't tried the phone-answering feature yet.
As always, you get the top-quality materials and excellent build quality that will keep these headphones working and a pleasure to use for many years.  I expect that I would wear out 2-3 pairs of cheaper noise-cancelling headphones over the useful life of one Bose QC 35 II, so while Bose's purchase price is off-putting, I expect to more than recoup my investment long-term.

author: jenly
title: Works great for noise cancelling!
content:
I bought these to dull the loud, muffled radio that comes through the wall next to my office. I don't mind music, just can't stand when its muffled and you can't really hear it, just the thumping bass. Can't do anything about it. I tried earplugs from the pharmacy, they work great but aren't very comfortable. These headphones, while admittedly about 1,000 times more expensive are welllll worth it. With the noise cancelling setting on low I can still hear whats going on around me, people talking in the next room, or when someone is talking to me. But I don't hear the boys in the garage blasting their radios at all! I can't hear the clicks of my keyboard when I type, but I can hear my calculator when I'm working on that... to give an idea of how much noise gets blocked. The ear plugs from the pharmacy blocked EVERYTHING, I could only hear myself breathing, which was kinda creepy, lol

They're very comfortable. Yes, I get some funny looks when people come in my office, but then they hear the background noise and understand!

I haven't tried any of the other features yet as far as taking calls, or the google assistant. I don't think I can use that since I'm using bluetooth to be connected to my MacBook instead of using the Bose app on my phone, don't really care, that wasn't why I bought them. Will be great on an airplane I'm sure.

author: J. Pinegar
title: Great headphones. Perfect if you also own AirPods.
content: Perfect if you also own AirPods. Top of their class. But could be better for working out. Especially if the over ther ear cushion was waterproof. Everything I don’t like about one I love about the other. Not to they are not both excellent in their own right though.  Both doing what they do best exceeding well. Together they fulfill all of my headphone needs. The Bose has better sound and superb noise cancellation. I only gave it 4 because it isn’t 100%. But no consumer headphones are. I only have to charge it about once a week. The AirPods are the most portable and convenient to use headphones I’ve ever seen. When you wear them they are practically weightless. And I don’t have to worry about them falling out. Your mileage may very on the fit. Plus being able to hear the outside world is about a plus when you are jogging or skiing. For home, office, airplane, and the like these Bose headphones will not disappoint.

author: nevermind
title: Ok product
content:
For the price I would’ve expected better than that honestly . It excelled in noise cancellation, but other than that.  I would say average at its very best . Sound quality might be for classical music or for audiobooks , it’s too bright ! If ur looking for listening to hip hop , rock , metal etc... search for other brands ! Bass is really mediocre ...
if you’re looking to use these at the gym , make sure they won’t hold like u expect ! They are very slippery ...
another thing I need to mention is the built in quality : for this amount of $$$ i would’ve expected stronger and better quality ...
overall , it’s an ok product . I didn’t find anything interesting other than great noise cancellation and battery life ... maybe for audiobook lovers intellects it will do the job ... but for me it’s a no no !!! Sorry Bose

author: A Customer
title: QuietComfort was not comfortable for me.
content: These headphones really have good sound and the noise reduction really does reduce noise significantly. There are a couple problems though. With a lack of documentation, It was difficult to figure out how to pair with a device other than my phone (hold switch for 2 seconds), but once I figured that out, it was pretty simple. The sound produced by the headphones is definitely superior to that of my previous, $10 headphones, which should be expected, although I don't know that it's $290 more superior. There are some drawbacks, which make me give it three stars. First, the noise reduction algorithm causes a delay. If you are watching TV or a movie through them, the sound will be about a second delayed. Using the "less noise" reduction algorithm gets things pretty much back on track, and still works pretty darn good for noise reduction. The biggest issue I had with these headphones was how uncomfortable they are. Ears hot. Area around ears, where the pads hit, hurt. It's just not tolerable for me. I'm going to send these back (hack, Amazon now charges for shipping things back!) and try the in-ear variety. Sadly, I know noise reduction won't be as good with those.

author: silversmith
title: Bluetooth range limitations
content:
I use semi current Apple products, IPad Pro 10.9 & iPhone 8. I also have (for prior 2 years) the Samsung  Level (SL) (model EO-BN920) Bluetooth neck bracelet style ear buds.  Here are the differences.

1) Samsung Level (SL)  have a greater Bluetooth range
2) The SL is easier to answer the phone.  There are three buttons easily tactally identified to answer, volume up-down and pause.  Also the SL magnetic earbud sensing answers and hangers up / pauses content.  The Bose is hard to identify buttons especially when you install backwards.
3)The Bose negotiates BT connectivity to my devices better than SL. I am constantly reconnecting the SL  after I go out of range especially the iPhone.
4) The SL is better or more handy to wear. You can park the SL earbuds (magnetically connected)  so when the phone rings place them in your ears and your talking. The Bose are so large you are apt to place them down and are not as readily deployable.
5) The SL battery life is at least 1/3 longer than the Bose even on my 2 year olds SLs.
6) The Bose noise cancelling comes in handy when mowing or running noisy equipment. This is probably the most useful feature.
7) The SL cost 10x less.

Summary:
If I could only have one headset device I would chose the SL because it fits the majority of need. Nothing wrong with the Bose just my experience.  Hope that’s helpful.

author: Serious Jazz Fan
title: Good until today .....
content: I bought them in July 2018....good until today. They developed a "tac" noise in one cup when connected to my Mac laptop with a cable. I couldn't find a wireless app to check them wireless.....Now the hassle of calling bose etc.

author: futureboy
title: Best set of headphones I've ever owned - ALMOST perfect
content:
I love love love love love these headphones. I use them daily, I travel with them, I never leave home without them. I used to be afraid of Bluetooth headphones because of concerns over battery life or headaches I would sometimes get from Bluetooth (true story!). That being said, these QC35s are AMAZING and I am so happy I own them.  I used to think the Bose QC20s were the absolute best, but I have since gone cordless and I don't think I can go back.

The battery life is solid - I can use these pretty almost all week without recharging them. The sound quality is solid. I'm not an audiophile but it sounds great to me. The noise canceling is fantastic and I can't really imagine flying anymore without these.

There is only ONE problem with these and the rest of the Bluetooth Bose headphones: the ability to pair with two devices simultaneously is both awesome and super annoying. I tend to pair between either my MacBook Pro and my iPhone, or my iPhone and my iPad, depending on where I am. The headphones will pair with both, but sometimes the headphones will "listen" to one of the devices when I want to hear audio on another, which makes me end up doing some jumble of turning off Bluetooth on one device so I can force the QC35s to listen to the device I want. For example, when I fly now, I try to remember to turn off Bluetooth on my MacBook Pro if I'm not using it and leaving it up in overhead storage, because even when asleep the Bluetooth is still on and the QC35's will pair with them, when I only want to use my iPhone or iPad to watch movies or listen to music. So in these situations, I have to load the app on my iPhone and disconnect the Mac, or pull out my MBP and turn off Bluetooth. Super annoying. Suggestion to Bose: add an extra button that lets users toggle between which Bluetooth device we want to hear. Perhaps even allow a third connection. Then, I could sit there on the plane, paired to my iPhone, iPad and MBP, and I could click a button to toggle between which device I want to hear. Problem solved and I would be super happy. USB-C charging would be great too since this is inevitable for our devices.

I'm still giving these 5 stars because despite this Bluetooth issue, they are still my favorite headphones for daily use. So, in summary, I love these, but here are my three suggestions:

1) Add a button to toggle between paired devices.
2) Increase number of allowed simultaneously paired devices to 3.
3) Switch the port to USB-C for charging since this is the future.

author: RosAnn
title: Life Saver for Me
content:
I have reviewed my review after having these a good while now and have come to the conclusion, though I really could not afford the price tag, it has been well worth it for me here in this place.
If I had to listen to the noise at full volume here, I surely would have gone mad by now, so...

They do have the good sound cancellation however not perfect, but have been a life saver in some respects in my situation here.
Not sure what causes it, but they do cut out now and again.
The one thing I will say is that they are comfortable and do fit around the ear.

author: Amanda
title: Does not actually cancel most noise
content:
I am so disappointmented. When I received this package today, I thought I was finally going to have the chance to get some sleep. I live in a room right next to a noisy person (and rude - phone calls right next to me at 2 a.m. kind of deal), and have neighbors with yappy dogs that they leave out for hours on end at times. I've tried various ear plugs, but those haven't been effective enough for blocking the noises, so I figured I'd try active noise-cancelling headphones. These do not work for that purpose. I have the noise cancelling function set on "high," but I can still hear the TV downstairs, footsteps nearby and chatting a few rooms away. It blocks has blocked out a very limited range of background road noise (noises like revving engines are still heard), but simply isn't doing what it claims to be able to do: cancel noise.

I'm desperate here - does anyone happen to have suggestions for headphones that actually cancel noise? I've been playing brown noise in the background when I try to sleep, but the constant auditory input in my life is driving me crazy and I want to be able to simply block out the noise. I just need some quiet time while I'm trying to rest. :(

author: T. F.
title: The sound is good. Comfort is nice
content: The sound is good. Comfort is nice. But beware petite girls out there. Not for us. This does not fit our heads, it falls off all the time. Sony one seems to fit better, in the sense that it feels more secure. The noise canceling though is best with Bose, no doubt about it, although I will say I was expecting more. I am very unhappy that this is too big for my head. Now I understand why people say it's so "comfortable" compared to Sony's. No wonder. This is for giant heads. Although I am petite, my head is not small. Anyway, I don't know. But the product is good, there is no doubt about that.

author: noway
title: DEFINITELY NOT FOR OFFICE USE
content: Not noise cancelling! I ordered this so that I can work peacefully in an open office. When the headphones were on, I could hear every single word the guy next to me was saying while he is on the phone. Just cancels out background noise which is not what i was looking for. Also, everyone can hear the music you are listening to - not cool for such an expensive set of headphones. I returned it and the return process was seamless.

author: Claveman
title: A Quiet Peaceful World - At Last.
content:
Unbelievably happy with this product.  I cannot live without out my Bose QC 35 II's (even considering a second one to keep at work).  It is empowering to put these on and all the noise pollution just goes away.  I bought them for home and hadn't planned on taking them to my large open floor office.  I put them on and suddenly realized there was a very low and loud humm coming from the ceiling (air blowers I assume).  Now gone.  I sit there in my cubicle and feel sorry for everyone else because they don't have a pair of these.

I tried other brands, but they were simply not properly engineered.  Once you get the pairing "dialed in" it is seamless.  I have a Mac and iPhone but bought the new model (with Google voice button).  I use the button's alternate function of turning on/off noise cancellation -- just for fun to remind me how great this product works.  But remember.. this technology is not going to isolate voices - it is designed to remove motor noises (plane, furnace blower, road, engine, etc).

author: Ray Pitchford
title: I like them
content:
I bought two, these are the first noise canceling head phones i have ever purchased. we are very pleased how well they worked for our trip and now i will be flying with them back and forth to work.one charge has got me from alaska to dallas and back then a trip back up to work in the arctic. i will charege them before going home.
3 levels of noise canceling highest setting the best of course and played with the lower one only to put it back to the highest setting.
 The only issue if you want to call it that we experienced on both sets was upon landing in the plane we got some static sounds when we hit the ground. i dont believe that was an issue with the headphones themselves.
  we did not set up the Alexa crap when we set these up, honestly when i bought these i didnt read enough and didnt realize that was included in it.
 Setting them up was super simple even for me who is not very smart phone literate. just download the app and easy setup.

author: Kindle Customer
title: bluetooth stop wroking after 2 months
content: 4th Bose headphone, this one is real disappointing because bluetooth never get connected after 2 months, tried on ipad, iphone, none works, connection unsuccessful. I have to use it with wire like QC25.

author: Just Jim
title: They sound good and the noise cancelling is great
content:
These are so expensive but what can a person do? It is hard to pass up the benefits. The comfort is great although ears do feel warm after a time. The ambient noise is greatly reduced. The sound is OK for me, but I am no audiophile.  They are big and a little clunky and I can't wear them for more than an hour without airing out my ears for a few minutes. They seal quite well around the ears and there is no air flow, I suppose to make the sound cancelling work. Oh well, tradeoffs.
I find the battery lasts all day at the very least. I don't do any telephone conversations with these as a rule but a time or two and I did receive a call while using them and it went OK. I don't use the Google or the Alexa silliness but I suppose younger folks might like that. I do like that I can control the volume very easily with the control. Also, I have no problem with connecting via Bluetooth  with my iPad and my android phone. It just works. I wish I could pair more than two devices at a time, but I can't say it's really a problem. Things stay connected, too. I've had no communication failures. The radio link is really solid. I maybe should say that I am updated to the latest firmware and had no trauma. It simply worked. I've used these on airplanes and they really cut down the noise. Sometimes I'll just wear them and turn them on and I'm not listening to anything. I'm just using the noise cancellation. Certainly better than the constant noise of the plane, especially if you fly cattle class like I do. To me, Bose is very over priced and they drop products and move on to the next newer thing so in time you end up with an orphan device. Still, they have the market pretty much to themselves with these nifty QuietComfort headphones so props to them for that.

author: natgoo
title: Great headphones!
content: I’ve had these headphones for a few months now and I love them. My experience with ANC headphones is limited but I have used others. Most notably the Plantronics backbeat pro headphones. I purchased the bose headphones because the plantronics set started to rip around the ear cushions. In comparison the bose headphones are slightly more comfortable, have noticbly superior active noise cancelation, but unfortunately in my opinion have inferior sound quality. I’d say if noise cancellation is a bigger deal, go with the bose. If sound quality is a bigger deal, consider the plantronics. I hope the bose ear cushions will prove long lasting.

author: Traveling Fool.
title: Excellent for Open Work Environments
content:
Ah, the curse of the open work environment.  Touted as genius for creating highly efficient teams.  That is, if you can get any work done with the constant high volume conversations around you.  These headphones are the solution.  Not a 100%, but a very decent 90% of the voices are eliminated and the rest are low enough volume that I can ignore them.  And, I'm a big fan of acoustics and bass.  Cabaret Bachata, etc.  Excellent!!

My last headphones were at the $80 price point and had a 4.5 star rating, but completely failed in the noise cancellation department.  These headphones are well worth the money.

author: db
title: Great product, but does not beat out Sony
content:
After weeks of research and comparison, I bought a pair of Sony WH1000XM3.  A week later, my wife surprised me with  a pair of Bose QC 35s (forgetting that I had already purchased the Sony's).  I opened the Bose QC in order to test them, figuring I would keep the better of the two and sell the others.

The reviews I had read were pretty much even between the two.  Nothing really gave me confidence that one was better for my uses or my preferences than the other.  Now after having both, I can say that I strongly prefer and recommend the Sony over the Bose.

First and foremost - the sound out of the Sony WH1000XM3 is not only better, but you can customize it using the app.
 Tweak everything about the sound in the app.  This is, to me the biggest point because the Bose QC 35's are surprisingly lacking in bass.  I own a pair of Bose SoundSports which are great for working out, with great bass right out of the box - which is why I was so surprised that the QC would pack less of a punch than their in-ear buds.  The Sony WH1000XM3 out of the box sounds good, but the ability to customize the sound through the equalizer in the app is a huge advantage over the Bose QC 35s.

The touch controls on the Sony are great as well.  Intuitive and responsive.  The controls on the Bose are straight forward and work fine, but I do like the ability to just reach up and swipe, tap, or put my hand over the ear cup to hear the ambient sounds as opposed to finding the right button (first world problem, I know, but it is a great feature).

The noise canceling is indistinguishable to me.  Both work great.  I could not tell a difference as I switched between the two of them while watching TV, or observing the kids while arguing.  I wore the Sony for a 2.5 hour flight with no fatigue or discomfort at all.  Not sure about the Bose, but I don't think they would cause any issues or discomfort - they feel pretty much the same on the head/ears.

A couple additional small wins for Sony:
The fact that the case comes with small sectioned off areas separated by cloth for your 3.5mm jack and USB.  Bose does not have this, which means you can use the pocket on the cover (one inside and one outside) but if you use the one inside the cords are pressed into the ear cups.
Sony uses USB-C.  No guessing which side is up when plugging into the headphones to charge.
Sony comes with an Airplane jack adapter.  Even though most airlines use the single prong input now, it's nice to have, just in case.

If Bose had an equalizer, the sound could most likely be made to be equal, if not better than the Sony.  But the equalizer feature on the Sony WH1000XM3 enables me to really dial in the sound, leaving the Bose sounding flat in comparison.  That alone puts them over the top for me.  The additional features alone would not be enough for me to accept inferior quality, but I don't have to.  All it together puts Sony way out ahead in my opinion.

author: Real Raleigh Reviewer
title: Very, very disappointed
content:
Very, very disappointed. I really wanted to love these - as I had wanted to when I purchased a pair of original QC35s. I love Bose speakers, esp. bluetooth speakers, and have Bose stereo systems in several cars I currently / recently owned (currently two Mercedes and one Audi), all of which are excellent systems.

These are the most comfortable headphones I've tried - which includes, for reference, Sennheiser HD1, Bang & Olufsen H9 (my personal favorite of all headphones), Bowers & Wilkins P7s, Bluedio, AudioMX, etc. etc. These ARE comfortable.

I do think these have the best noise-canceling in the industry, including the Sony MDR-1000X (or current WH-1000XM2). Much of that has to do with the softness and plushness of the ear pads; you'll notice that about 2/3 of the noise canceling is accomplished simply by WEARING the headphones, even while off.

I like the addition of the multifunction button that toggles between noise canceling high / low / off. Very good.

These are attractive. The ear cups swivel 90 degrees so you can lay them flat on your chest while around your neck. They just look nice - look like quality. The two-tone covers are a great touch and executed with precision.

Audio performance is still in the bottom 25% of all bluetooth headphones I've ever tested. And that numbers somewhere near 50 over the last several years. Here, the Bang & Olufsen just trounces the Bose. Plantronics Backbeat Pro 2 is a runner-up. Bowers & Wilkins P7 is also superb. The Bose sound performance at all volume levels is a forgettable also-ran. Even with the ANC turned off, the bass is wimpy and the mids - vocals, strings - are flaccid, underwhelming. There's no warmth, no voice, no presence. No different than the original QC35, and wholly inferior to the B&O, Plantronics, and B&W named above - by an order of magnitude. This isn't the "Bose sound".

And now the cardinal sin: connection quality. I tried with two phones to confirm (although both work extremely well with all other offerings mentioned above, and many more). On a clear day, the Bose QC35 has about a 15 foot range with a clear line of sight before it starts cutting out. If you put your phone in your pocket and walk outside, the music skips constantly. Unusable. Even indoors, you have to have the phone in the pocket on the same side as the bluetooth receiver - which appears to be in the LEFT ear cup - or it will also skip while your phone is in your pocket. Outdoors it doesn't matter; it skips constantly. If I didn't have a list of 60 or 70 paired devices on my phone - speakers, headphones and cars - I would say, "maybe it's my phone". It isn't. It's the QC35ii. Unfortunately, this is exactly the behavior I observed on the original QC35, which was also unacceptable. And, like the original QC35, I will have to return these.

If you want attractive headphones that are very comfortable and very aesthetically pleasing, and don't particularly care about the quality of the sound they're producing, these are clear winners, best in the industry. They tick off those two boxes very well. But if you want Great ANC and Great comfort, but dominant sound performance, these are not contenders in any way. Regardless of price. Check out Bang & Olufsen H9, Bowers & Wilkins P7, and Plantronics Backbeat Pro 2 for excellent comfort, three very different aesthetic options, and vastly dominant sound quality. Out of the three, the B&O is the top dog, but both of the other two are simply excellent and can't disappoint.

author: Boulderbon
title: Noticeable Audio/Video lag
content:
First off, they are comfortable, I can wear them for a good portion of the day, and not feel pressure on my head.

I have a loud work environment and between my old age/hearing loss and these headphones in noise cancelling mode (even without any sound playing) I can barely hear anything in my office.

I was a little surprised at how fragile they feel/appear. I guess I was expecting something sturdier feeling, but that would probably have been much heavier.

The biggest problem is that they have noticeable audio/video lag while in bluetooth mode. It's a shame that Bose sells a $350 set of bluetooth headphones without low latency bluetooth support. This makes these headphones pretty worthless for watching tv, or watching videos on your computer without a cord.

And that audio cord? It's proprietary, for no reason. It's just a tiny bit smaller than a standard 3.5mm audio cord. This means as soon as you lose that cord, you can't plugin these headphones to anything without buying a replacement. Oh, and Bose doesn't tell you what that special cable/connector is called. And you can see from Bose's Amazon store they don't sell those cables.

Pros: Comfortable
Noise Cancelling is great

Cons: Seemingly Fragile - time will tell
Audio/Video lag is noticeably bad
Special audio cord that is difficult to replace if lost

Overall I'm disappointed with this purchase. For $350 I thought I would end up with something that works well for watching videos on my computer.

author: SD
title: Used headphones
content: I was sent used headphones. They had at least 3 prior owners, evidenced by 3 nicknames when paired with the app. The headphones do not work properly as well. Amazon censored my first review.

author: Adam Wespiser
title: My solution to our open office floor plan
content:
First pair of noise cancelling headphones. My use case is everyday office wear, light music, and using them without music to dampen office sounds. Comfort - Nice fit, without feeling like suction cups. I've worn them everyday for a couple weeks at work with no problem.  My ears sometimes get a little sore after 3+ hours of consecutive use.
Sound - These sound very good, especially at low volumes. Bose just does good speakers.
Noise Cancelling - It took me a day or two to get used to not being able to hear people come in and out of the office! Naturally, the class of sounds that are most easily cancelled are droning noises, so distant conversations, the sounds of people walking down hallways, and air vents are all gone. Two types of sounds do still come through: The first, is that I use a mechanical keyboard, so the sharp click of my keys pierces through. The next, is that deeper voices have a little bit more difficultly being filtered.

Overall, this noise cancelling is great, and I often use the headphones for this without music. It was between this pair and the Sony WH1000XM2. I went with the Bose for a couple reasons: My love of the last pair their headphones I owned (they sounded so good) vs. the current Sony headphones I have of the same type, the reviews stating the Sony NC headphones are uncomfortable and a little hot sometimes, and that the Sony pair requires you to have something actively playing for noise cancelling to be on.

So far, I've been very satisfied with this purchase, and I believe its increased my productivity by isolating me a little bit from my environment. The one thing I would make a little better is comfort into hour 4. I highly recommend these headphones.

author: James B.
title: I give it five stars. My wife hates them ...
content: I give it five stars. My wife hates them she would give it 1. I put them on and that’s it. I can’t hear her any more.

author: WA engineerd
title: Great sound and noise cancellation, like it paired with better with external mic for calls
content: I think the sound quality and noise cancellation is great with the Quietcomfort 35 ii.  During the summer, I usually have an AC unit or a fan going in my office, so I wanted great noise cancellation, and these definitely deliver;; I can hardly hear any ambient noise when they're on.  They are very comfortable to wear too.  For the price, I wasn't real happy with the sound quality from the internal mic though.  It's not bad, but it's not great.  I'm not sure if it's a wired vs. Bluetooth connection thing (I've generally heard that wired connections produce better mic sound quality).  I bought these mainly to use for work, and I spend a couple hours on the phone everyday.  I did some audio tests between its internal mic and my wired Apple Earpods, and I honestly think the mic in my wired Earpods sounds a little better.  I researched headset-type boom mics and found good reviews for the V-Moda BoomPro mic.  The Quietcomfort 35 ii has a 2.5mm audio port (the user manual incorrectly says 3.5 mm), and the BoomPro mic has a 3.5mm jack.  I found a 2.5mm male by 3.5mm female adapter from SFCable, and it works great to connect the two.  I much prefer the sound quality from the BoomPro mic over the internal headset mic, but for most folks, I think you'll be OK with the internal mic. Overall, I am happy with these headphones, and I really like them paired with the V-Moda BoomPro mic for phone calls.

author: Sean Gherardi
title: Firmware Improvements
content:
My original review of these headphones was 3 stars, mainly because the unpleasant active noise cancellation feature had to be manually disabled each time the headset was turned on via the buggy Bose Connect application.  The other reason was that these headphones were not able to decode audio for Skype on Android.

Since my original review, Bose has added the option to switch between noise cancellation settings using the press of the action button.  If you don't mind replacing the virtual assistant function on the action button with the noise cancellation setting function then it only takes a couple clicks of the button to turn the active noise cancellation off when you turn the headset on and put it over your ears.  I would have preferred if this setting could be remembered by the device when it was turned on, but this is close enough not to be too inconveniencing.

To be clear, some users may not be bothered by the active noise cancelling.  My ears are pretty sensitive (I think?) and well-trained as I do some music production as a hobby - so to me it feels like I am 20ft underwater when the active noise cancelling is enabled.  A few other people I know who are not audiophiles have also noticed this.  Some reviewers have not.  Try them and find out for yourself!

As for decoding/encoding Skype audio on android - I am not sure if this issue still remains as I have simply been using an iPad when I need to use this headset for Skype calls.

So I will give this headset 4 stars, because of the other great features which do work as advertised:

1) The headset is extremely light and comfortable.  You will forget you are wearing it.
2) The sound quality is great considering that these are wireless.
3) Battery life is outstanding.  I've used these for 4-6 hours a day about five days in a row without having to recharge.
4) They have not fallen apart on me - the carrying case does a great job of protecting the headset during transport.

author: Mr. Wise
title: Bose
content: The sounds are crisp, clear, and has good range. The bass is not all that strong. So if you're looking for headphones to play music with deep bass these are not for you. The noise cancellation is great. The earphones seal well around your ear  and helps to block out any noises. The battery life last for hours. The headphones fit well over the head and adjust easily. The only negative is that if you are using these to talk on the phone, it picks up a lot of the background noises! So the person on the other end has a hard time hearing you, unless you're sitting in a quiet room.

author: RAMESH GOPALAKRISHNAN
title: Beware of getting a used product
content: Ordered this product twice on Amazon. First time headphones were loose and did not cancel airplane noise properly. Second time it appeared to be used  - tied to pair to somebody else in Spanish could not pair properly to my devices.  Have had Bose products before and disappointed that I have had to return this twice

author: Lisa Finkel
title: I think I should have paid attention to the reviews and bought the Sony .
content: My Bose 35 ii arrived today and I am bummed. 1. They are uncomfortable to wear for any length of time.  Very hot.  Feel sweaty.  2.  The bass is overwhelming.  In most situations that they are used, I cannot adjust that problem (airplane).  3.  I can’t judge the noise cancellation quality because of the sound itself.  4.  Unlike the Sony, which was rated as better, the Bose does not come with the expected adaptors.  5. This may seem petty but I expected some kind of basic instruction booklet to be enclosed so they could be used immediately.  You have to go online to find the info.  I’ve been using Bose noisecanselling headphones since they hit the market years ago so I thought I would remain brand loyal.  Should have paid attention to the reviews.  I am returning these.

author: Kevin W.
title: I love them
content: After reading several reviews I was very hesitant to order these headphones.  I took the plunge though and I couldn't be happier with them.  I'm not a music fanatic like a lot of people are, but I do enjoy nice quality sound.  These headphones do the trick for me.  The sounds are crisp and clear with these.  One thing I did find is that, like others mentioned in their reviews, the range of the Bluetooth is not very far.  For me that's not a big deal at all, but for others it may be a consideration.  Overall I'm very happy with my headphones and I use them everyday.

author: Mike
title: Just threw them in the trash
content: Worthless garbage.  Uncomfortable.  After 6 months, they couldn't even maintain a connection to my iPad for more than 3 minutes.  Sound quality was good when they worked.  Battery life was fine.  Quality was apparently sub-par.  Price was ridiculous.  I'm done with Bose overpriced junk.

author: MercuryMat
title: Way overpriced, a nonsense buy for the embedded functions.
content:
This was a present for my wife that loves branded products (Apple, Bose etc etc)...so I gave it a shot. Noise cancelling is top notch. Period. The good stuff is this. But...it is waaaaaaayyy overpriced considering the sound quality, unless you like tons of bass and a kind of "unreal sound". There is not such a great definition in the sound. Then: build quality is good but again, it is all light plastic and fancy soft material that is wearing very fast even if, because of the price, you'll probably take good care of it. And again: the noise cancelling is especially useful during trips on trains and airplanes (and I bet most people will use it in this situations), where you have a lot of other noises coming from everywhere (because noise cancelling works, but non totally), so the sound quality does really matter? Probably not, and nobody can say the sound quality is good in this kind of environments...
And if you travel on a not brand new plane you'll probably have to deal with the odd dual-jack connector, and guess what? The adaptor IT IS NOT PROVIDED with this headset (well...you pay 350$...you cannot pretend to have a small piece of plastic in such a premium product... isn't it?); I got a great deal the day a travelled with my wife and I had to give her my 10¢ adaptor so she could enjoy the entertainment on our 12 hrs flight!!!
Last but not the least: you'll probably look very fashionable on a plane with this headphones, but you still have to carry them in a case that is quite big, cause over-ear headphones are big, even if foldable. So consider this.
Ah, the charge connector is a mini-usb, sooooo old style, not even a lighting nor USB-C...beware apple fans, you'll need another charging cable! And Bluetooth is not even v5, but the old crappy v4, so good luck with the connection stability and the delay.
Compared to my cheap wired Taotronics made in China (like the Bose) that I payed 40$ and they are small, feather light, in ear (the most comfortable I ever had in my life), with an airplane adaptor, a super good noise reduction and a astonishing good balanced sound for the price, this Bose are a totally nonsense.
This is just my opinion, but maybe you really like to throw your money away.

author: kaesechan
title: best pair with a few limitations
content:
good lord, these things are legit.
couple of good notes: the sound is fantastic. it's not HORRIBLE to wear glasses under these (honestly don't think it'll ever feel good to wear headphones and glasses). the bluetooth connect is easy.
couple of meh notes: cannot charge and listen to bluetooth at the same time. cannot hear yourself talk when using bluetooth calling. windows gets confused when you use an IP phone with the voice bluetooth at the same time as the stereo bluetooth for music.
however, still the best pair of headphones I've had.

author: Vince
title: Excellent, Wireless, Connect to Multiple Devices at Once
content:
It was time to ditch the cord. I swear by noise canceling headphones but wanted wireless. These Bose headphones are amazingly comfortable to wear. Sound quality if excellent, just what I've come to expect from Bose.
It's so freeing not to be tied by a cable to the device playing your audio or video.

Setting them up was seamless, with one important caveat: you have to download a Bose Connect app on -each- device you want to connect to it. This means, you MUST set up each device -before- you get on the plane. (Learned this the hard way.)
Once set up and you turn them on, a quiet voice says, "Connected with X's iPhone, connected with X's iPad." Yes, it can connect to both devices at once; no need to switch back and forth. I'm very impressed by this.
Buttons on the headphones give you control of the volume and between high or low levels of noise cancellation, or none at all.
Another big benefit: these are rechargeable. I don't have to take extra batteries with me when I travel. The headphones and accompanying connector cords all fit in one nice carrying case.

They even include a cable so you could use the headphones with a cord to plug it into a device. (Valuable when I didn't get my iPad set up before getting on the plane.) However, they left one important detail undisclosed; the plugs on this cable are not identical at both ends and the difference is easy to overlook One is 3.5 mm: this one goes into your device. The other end is 2.5 mm: this one goes into the headphone. Be sure to plug the smaller end into the headphones very snugly. It doesn't go all the way in at first attempt.

author: Rachel R
title: Kind of an overrated product
content:
Pros
- comfort A++
- noise cancellation (besides wind) is fantastic
- battery is great (non replaceable but easily recharged)
Cons
- sound quality good with bass and highs, but mid-ranges need more love
- bluetooth connection clips frequently (a few times a day, I used them all day) for 10 seconds or so
- microphone doesn't always work the best for phonecalls

Apparently the clipping issue is a common one for these headphones-- seems like Bose's firmware caters more to Apple brands, so if you use iPhones and such clipping may not be an issue. Bottom line: with the reputation Bose has for top-quality, the kinks were deal-breakers, definitely not worth working around with the high price tag.

author: Marcus O.
title: Poor connectivity, no help from support
content: Great noise cancelling, which is why I got them, but the headphones fail so completely at trying to keep two audio devices connected that I've spent my last molecule of patience. The fix I've found is forever unpairing whatever the other device is so that the audio stream doesn't turn choppy. The problem showed up sometime in the last year, is almost certainly a problem with firmware or the app they have that's managing the connections, and hasn't been fixed. The ear cups also deteriorated in about 6 months requiring replacement. I've had these a little over a year and Bose will do nothing; they want me to buy another pair. After having also used their sports headphones and their wired Quiet Comfort earbuds and having each fail within a year or two, I'm pretty much done with Bose. Very unhappy.

author: R. Marie Miller
title: Not a bit impressed! BOSE should be ashamed!
content: Wow, these headphones are a profound disappointment! They don’t connect easily to Apple products and the overall build quality is a step above garbage. The “wireless” aspect of these, in my experience, is reminiscent of 2002 technology. I never could get these headphones to connect. There is a wire included so users unlucky enough to have these headphones can connect to their devices. This wire is very short and extremely thin. Seriously BOSE, you couldn’t have included a decent wire or cable for this? Not what I was expecting for the price. These things don’t appear sturdy either.  And the sound is good, but it’s not amazing.  Honestly, I’ll never even consider buying a BOSE product again.

author: Vlad
title: A disappointment. Constant bluetooth connectivity issues.
content:
I was excited to get this pair of headphones but after a couple of months of use I am compelled to come back here and write some feedback. I am very disappointed for the reasons listed below.

- constant, and I a mean constant issues with bluetooth connectivity when switching devices. Once you connect you're generally OK, but switching devices often requires multiple retries. For comparison I never have this issue with my Sony HDR. The most frequent issue is the bluetooth connecting to a device after turning the headphones on, only to immediately disconnect.
- intermittent interruptions in music playback (very brief, in the millisecond range). They seem to happen every 30-40minutes to 1-2 hrs. Frankly these interruptions are a minor annoyance, but for headphones from Bose they are unacceptable.
- Stuttering, continuously interrupted sound play when connected to two devices at the same time. This does not occur all the time, it seems to happen when I am connected to a chromebook AND my iMac at the same time. The only way I have found to address this is by disconnecting one of the devices and reconnecting the headphones to the other (turning one of the devices off is not enough, once the stuttering kicks in, you have to restart the headphones and reconnect).

UPDATE: 01/04/19 - bose pushed a few updates to their firmware, but it has not helped at all with regards to the bluetooth connectivity issues. Basically if you have multiple devices (say your phone and then switching between a work and home computer) expect constant issues, with the headphones connecting and disconnecting to the computers all the time. In addition recently (last couple of months) a new issue has come up, where the headphones would be connected the laptop, but would NOT play any sound (even though the laptop sees them as connected and the headphones themselves say they are connected). The solution seems to be turn up the volume to the max, and to press play/stop/play on the laptop to get the headphones to start playing sound. I don't quite get what the deal is with trying to make it possible for the headphones to connect to multiple devices, but in any case BOSE completely screwed up the work flow there.

The stuttering has been fixed by one of the firmwares as I no longer get any stuttering.
END UPDATE.

All in all this is massive disappointment.

So long story short, while I love the look and design of the headphones (very comfortable) and while I love the sound and the noise cancellation (after you get the bluetooth working), they are way too glitchy and require way too much fiddling. I regret that I am no longer able to return this as I've had them for a couple of months already.

I am simply very very disappointed. It seems to be that this pair of headphones is unnecessarily complicated, and Bose never worked out all the details in the many features they tried to cram into it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Ear hurts, Poor ergo design, Awful voice call
content:
I will make myself simple here. Three problems :

1. Ear hurts with noise cancellation.
Literally, noise cancellation annoyingly hurts ears - like you're in airplane. Not just feeling muffled, but pressure cause pain. This gets a bit alleviated when music plays, but eventually so much fatigue to your ear. No no no.

2. Ear pads / housing doesn't rotate 90 degrees.
Depends on which direction. When I want to remove the headphone from my ears and just put around my neck, I want the ear pads to turn 90 degrees so that they touch my chest 100%, because the ear pads are too bulky - feels like a huge muffler around your neck. But it just rotates about 80 degrees or so. It does rotate 90 degrees the other way, e.g. ear pad facing outwards from your chest. But then the caps gets scratched by zippers or other metal parts on my jacket.

3. Awful phone call quality
Noise cancellation on mic just cancels background noise, not the voice frequency components. Otherwise, my voice will be cancelled as well. But that eventually ends up other vocal noise from nearby ppl, etc. are well heard by the other party. This is terrible for conference calls or phone calls.

Don't buy this.

author: Susan M.
title: Pleased with this model so far
content:
After a lot of research and comparison with Sony’s WH-1000XM3 headset, I decided to purchase this Bose model. I have been wearing them for about a week and am happy with the results.

When I am in the office, the noise cancellation at max level does a nice job of silencing almost everything. I can still hear voices but they are drastically muted. The building HVAC sounds completely disappear and I’ve been startled by a co-worker a few times because I didn’t hear them approach my desk when my back was turned.

I work from home twice a week and have been able to completely tune out my husband who plays video games and chats with his friends rather loudly (he plays in the basement under my office). He also snuck up on me when I was wearing them and scared the crap out of me 😆

The sound quality is good - I’ve had multiple conference calls and have experienced no issues. Most of the time, I wear them (without any audio) simply to block out background noise. Seems kind of silly to spend so much money for that sole reason but they really do an excellent job at noise cancellation.

I recommend purchasing the extended warranty - I had issues with Bose earbuds a few years ago so I don’t completely trust the lasting quality of their products.

The only minor thing I don’t care for is the light colored headband cushion and fabric material. I considered this before purchasing the rose gold color and obviously, it wasn't enough of a deterrent for me to choose the black model. It is a comfortable band but I can see it getting dirty quickly. Especially for people who dye their hair (I dye my hair black).

author: MadKhemist
title: Trust me they are worth the money
content:
I have the series I and I love them so much that I had to give a pair to my partner for Christmas. There is no guessing when you use these headphones, voice whispers in your ear the charge level and which of your Bluetooth devices are connected.

The Series II has some neat extras that are not in the Series I, a Google button is the most useful. When you first turn them on you will be instructed to download the Bose+ app, you can move on without it but you really do want it. It allows you to give the headphones a name and other fun things that make your listening experience that much more enjoyable. I think I'm going to secretly swap his for my older (2 years) set.
